PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONSTITUTIONAL COMMISSION: APPOINTMENT OF FEMALE MEMBERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. When the Government appointed only two women out of the 39 people invited to participate in the work of the Constitutional Commission and its committees, was this on the basis of the Government's assessment of the number and quality of suitably qualified women, or was it a failure to match the Government's rhetoric about equal participation, merit based participation, of women with performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat surprised that Senator Peter Baume, speaking on behalf of the Liberal Party as he does, has had the temerity and the thick-skinnedness to draw attention to our record with regard to the promotion of women to participate compared with his own. It is a matter of record that, in contrast to the Liberal Party, Labor governments throughout Australia now have women Ministers in every one of their parliaments. For example, in Western Australia two of the new Ministers who have just been elected to participate in the Burke Government are women and the Whip is a woman. I was pleased to hear, as the final results of the Tasmanian election have become clear, that three Labor women have been elected to Parliament. If we look at the House of Representatives, we find only one woman member on the Opposition side compared with many women members on our side. In this place of course, despite the outstanding record of the former Minister for Finance and Minister for Social Security, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, there is no woman on the Opposition front bench.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a matter of record and, I think, a matter of great concern to women in the Liberal Party that participation by women in the organs of that Party and in parliaments has been in sad decline, just as participation by women on our side of politics has been increasing.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have never found it necessary to make it compulsory.

—It is not surprising that the Liberals are now shouting and trying to distract attention from this abysmal record. When a woman in their ranks was in a position of prominence-I refer to Mrs Rosemary Foot, who was the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales-she was forced to resign, apparently, according to her own words, because of lack of support from her own Party. So that is the record of the Party of which Senator Baume now leaps to his feet to speak on behalf of by drawing attention to a particular committee.

ANSWER.PARA: I also point out that our Government has an outstanding record in appointing women of competence, women of merit, to statutory boards and authorities. Indeed, at the last count we had made some 200 such appointments. I think the most recent was the appointment of an outstanding lawyer, Deirdre O'Connor, to chair the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Of course, appointments of that kind were not made during the time of the Fraser Government. The one woman who was appointed to the Broadcasting Tribunal, Janet Strickland, resigned because of her complete disillusionment with the performance of the Government at that time. It is really quite extraordinary that Senator Peter Baume should rise to his feet and make criticisms of our Government's record in appointing women.

With regard to the particular committee to which Senator Baume addresses his attention, I have not yet had the opportunity to discuss the composition of that committee with the Attorney-General, but it is my understanding that several women were invited to participate but chose not to, presumably because, as a result of our Government's policy, they are already very busy in senior positions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware of a report in the West Australian newspaper of Friday, 14 February, that the Government looks certain to reverse its decision to take income concessions from pensioners? Can the Minister inform the Senate on the accuracy of this report? If the report is accurate, can the Minister inform the Senate on when the concessions will be restored?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department and the Government decided last year to phase out the earnings concession for pensioners, which has been discussed in this place and which was complex, unfair and a major cause of social security overpayments, which are frequently referred to in this place. The concession will be replaced with an alternative which will encourage work force participation. Various options are being discussed with welfare organisations and representatives of pensioner groups in the country at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: It was found necessary to begin phasing out the concession after the High Court of Australia had indicated that it had no basis in legislation. The concession enables maximum rate pensioners to earn up to an annual equivalent of their weekly free income, which is $1,560 for a single person, before the pension is affected. The concession led to serious overpayments at the end of 12 months because pensioners often had other income to declare. The Department then had to recover money from pensioners who had in fact received and used the concession. As earnings reduce the pension by 50c in the dollar earned, it is a serious poverty trap which effectively reduces the incentive to undertake long term employment.

Having no legislative base, the concession was applied inconsistently in the various States and offices of the Department throughout Australia, where in fact it was applied at all, and in many places it was not. This, together with the inherent complexity, led to poor public understanding. The concession is being phased out over this year to November while an alternative is being developed. The Minister for Social Security will be making further announcements on this subject in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Government determined whether or not it will withdraw Australian Government aid from the Philippines, or is it waiting until the United States of America determines its position? What more has this Marcos criminal got to do before Australia would consider withdrawing recognition of his Government?

—As I said last week, on 14 February, the Australian Government will be examining the full range of our bilateral contacts with the Philippines in the light of post-electoral circumstances. This examination will draw on the full range of advice and information which is available to the Government from a wide range of sources. Our granting of aid to the Philippines or anywhere else does not necessarily imply endorsement of the policies of recipient governments or of their conduct of elections. Australia's aid in the Philippines has been aimed at improving living standards of the poor and at fostering equitable development. I think it should be acknowledged that withdrawal of that aid would harm the urban and rural poor in whose interests we have been giving it.
—Are you sure of that, or would it hurt the Army?

—That is, no doubt, a matter for judgment in the light of all the circumstances, and the Government will be keeping all these factors in mind, as I said last week and again today. Withdrawal of recognition from the Marcos Government, as suggested by Senator Chipp, would, I think it needs to be appreciated, constitute a step which would have enormous ramifications for Australian interests not only in the Philippines but in the South East Asian region as a whole. It is not an option which is presently under consideration by the Government. All that said, it ought to be acknowledged that the scale of the abuses which did, undoubtedly, occur in the Philippines elections and which were, overwhelmingly, clearly the responsibility of the ruling party have, to put it mildly, undermined the credibility of the Philippines election. Certainly, widespread perceptions within the Australian community that the conduct of those elections was unfair will necessarily affect the environment within which our future bilateral relations with the Philippines are conducted.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. I refer to an incident involving a jet airliner which was reported as having suffered a turbine failure near Canberra Airport on 31 January. Has the Department of Aviation investigated the incident and, if so, what were the findings? Was the aircraft engine involved of the same type as that which failed and caused the Manchester disaster last August?

—I recall Senator Maguire asking me a question about six months ago, troubled as he then was, as indeed were many people in the aircraft industry, about the tragedy that took place at Manchester Airport in the United Kingdom, where the problems associated with that particular engine resulted in a great loss of life. It is true, as Senator Maguire has suggested, that there was a failure in an Ansett Boeing 737 aircraft engine at Canberra Airport on 31 January this year. However, I am advised that the flight crew shut down the engine shortly after take-off and made a normal single engine landing at Canberra Airport. The safety of the aircraft and the passengers was not compromised at any stage and the engine was shut down due to an internal failure in the turbine area. The Department of Aviation is investigating the incident, but I am assured that the failure was contained inside the engine and is not related in any way to the British Airways disaster at Manchester about six months ago.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. In view of the widespread damage and human suffering caused in northern Queensland recently by Cyclone Winifred, could the Minister inform the Senate of the steps being taken by the Commonwealth to help the situation? Could he also estimate the costs resulting from Cyclone Winifred which will be borne by the State and the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The natural disaster relief arrangements-I do not want to be held to the last decimal point on the figures I am about to give-are of this order: Every State is required to meet from its own resources a threshold level of expenditure. In the case of Queensland I think it is $10.48m. For the next 75 per cent of that base level of expenditure the State is required to match Commonwealth funds on a one to one basis. Beyond that level-in the case of Queensland it would be of the order of $19m-Commonwealth dollars are provided on a basis of three to one with the State. That is the main measure of assistance available under natural disaster relief. There are also personal distress arrangements and under some conditions there are carry-on loans at concessional rates of interest. Under those main provisions, the specific proposals for funding must comply with the Commonwealth guidelines which were set by my predecessor in 1984.

ANSWER.PARA: The latest information I have, which I received at the end of last week although I have not checked it today, was that although there had been a good deal of windy rhetoric coming out of Brisbane and out of the Queensland Government in general, no set of propositions had been put to the Commonwealth by way of application for natural disaster relief arrangement funding. The long established and long honoured procedures in regard to natural disaster relief, by which all other States abided, is that the State submits a wish list, a log of claims, or whatever one likes to call it, which is then tested to see whether it conforms with the Commonwealth guidelines. The Commonwealth Government is ready to receive that list from Queensland at any time. However, as yet it has not been received. So if there is to be any criticism of governments for tardiness in this area, the criticisms should be clearly directed towards the State Government and not the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and relates to the acquisition from Australia of koalas by the Japanese. Can the Minister assure the Senate that only two koalas have died in Japan? Will the Minister make available to the Senate the details of the reasons for Professor Ovington's trip to Japan in December 1985? Will the Minister also make available to the Senate the findings of Professor Ovington's visit to Japan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some information in response to Senator Missen's question. It is the case that two of the seven female koalas sent to Japan in 1985 died. One sent from New South Wales died on 25 September 1985 in Tama Zoo, Tokyo, 20 days after arrival. The other died in Hirakawa Zoo, Kagoshima, on 3 October 1985, 4 1/2 months after arrival. On 25 November 1985 the koala working party met to consider reports on the deaths submitted by Tama Zoo and by the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service on behalf of Hirakawa Zoo. A draft of the report has been provided to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and has been circulated to members of the working party for comment. The draft report indicates that the meeting considered that there is no need to amend the export conditions applying to koalas as a result of these deaths but that the opportunity of the meeting should be used to clarify some aspects of the conditions.

ANSWER.PARA: The working party which considered the reports included a veterinarian undertaking research on koalas and veterinarians from several major Australian zoos with considerable experience of koala husbandry and management. It is expected that the report of the working party will be completed in the near future and it is intended that a full report will be presented to the Parliament at that time. That is the information that is available to me. I think Senator Missen's question referred to Professor Ovington's participation in this exercise. I have no information at this point on that matter but I will seek it immediately from the Minister and let Senator Missen have it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I do not think the Minister gave me any direct assurance that only two of the koalas have died. It may have been five. I would like to know directly whether that is so. Secondly, I asked-and this Government has had several days' notice of my question-about Professor Ovington's visit, why he went and when his findings would be made available. There is nothing in the Minister's information that indicates anything in regard to that. Would the Minister kindly reply to that part of my question?

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. —I think the first part of the question went something like this: Is it a fact that under the imputation system Australian companies with large overseas earnings will pay a higher rate of tax? Frankly, I do not know. It is a rather technical question and I do not carry around in my head all the details of that sort of thing. I will obtain an answer to that from the Treasurer. The other part of the question, which is predicated on the answer to the first part being yes, is whether that would be a deterrent to Australians investing overseas. I really do not know what the Opposition wants. Some people may argue that it is a good thing or a bad thing-I think it is a matter of subjective choice-for Australians to be investing overseas instead of in Australia. But one thing that is unarguable is that if Australians invest overseas they will be less likely to invest in Australia, and therefore any capital which is required for investment in Australia will either not be supplied at all or will have to be imported. There is at least as good an argument, I suggest, for saying that it would be a good thing if Australians with spare capital to invest invested in Australia instead of investing it overseas.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does not the Minister favour deregulation if he is going to put these impediments before people wanting to invest overseas?
—I did not hear the question, Mr President.
—Order! Will Senator Watson please repeat the supplementary question?
—Is not the Minister still in favour of deregulation in view of the fact that the Government is starting to put impediments in the way of shareholders wanting to invest overseas?
—I think I heard it that time, but I still do not understand it! I am not sure who is to blame for that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Did the Minister see the report in the Adelaide News on Wednesday, 12 February 1986, entitled `Acne drug ``carries birth defect risk'' '? In that report, and in other reports on the drug isotretinoin, it is said that the company supplying this drug is providing consumers with advice to take contraceptives as the risk of birth deformities that could result from pregnant women taking this treatment is very high. It was further reported that consumers were required to sign a consent form absolving the drug supplier of responsibility. I ask: Is it a widespread practice that dangerous drugs are supplied to consumers on condition that they, the consumers, sign a form absolving the manufacturers and distributors of such drugs of liability? What legal recourse could a deformed child have in future years, if any, against a company operating in this way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the Adelaide newspapers did report recently on the use of roaccutane, which is, I think, the Roche company's trade name for isotretinoin, which is available in this country under very controlled and very strict conditions for the treatment of severe cystic acne. This is a disfiguring condition. It particularly affects adolescents and young adults and is often severely disabling socially. The drug is to be used only where all alternative treatments have failed because of the known risk of damage to the foetus if the drug is taken during pregnancy. The company, in consultation with the Department of Health, has circulated letters to doctors and pharmacists and has prepared a multilingual patient information pamphlet or leaflet. All documents and labels carry a prominent warning that the drug can cause birth defects. The risk was also highlighted in a 1985 adverse drug reactions bulletin which was sent to all practising doctors and pharmacists in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the specific questions raised by Senator Foreman, it is not a common practice for patients to sign a form absolving a drug supplier of liability. The patient consent form which is used in the case of this drug is designed to ensure that information on a major risk which is known to the medical profession is passed on to the patient. The form also includes an undertaking from the patient not to supply the drug to other persons. It makes no specific statement regarding liability. It would be a matter for the courts to decide the question of responsibility in the case of an action for damages. I repeat that this drug is a useful drug in a condition which, despite the implication in the article, is severely disfiguring, a condition which has severe social effects to the extent that it is socially disabling. In this situation, in consultation with the Department of Health, the action outlined by Senator Foreman was taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The Minister's attention would have been drawn to downward trends in the world price of coal. What is the Government's current projection of the effect of falling oil prices on the tonnage and price of Australian coal exports?

—The Government's general assessment is that unless and until oil prices fall to the order of $US10 or $US12 the impact is not likely to be significant except perhaps for an increase in demand flowing from an increase in economic activity in the industrialised nations which may indeed call upon greater energy resources and give enhanced coal markets. The difference in calorific value between coal and oil is such that coal has a substantial price advantage. A number of existing power stations remain capable of being switched backwards and forwards between coal and oil fired uses and if oil prices go down to the levels that I have indicated, it may become an attractive short term option for some oil to be substituted for coal. Whether there is any danger of longer term substitution back to oil from coal for new power station construction depends very much on the long term price outlook for oil. Only on the basis of oil being very much cheaper than coal over a substantial period in the future would it make economic sense to make such a decision. The general prevailing orthodoxy is still-although, as I indicated earlier, the short term position is extremely volatile-that oil prices will come back again in real terms in the early 1990s and therefore it is not anticipated there will be any longer term shift back or substitution to oil in that sense.
—I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not quite finish off his answer. Is it a fact that he sees no risk of loss of tonnage or of revenue?

—Not in the immediately foreseeable future attributable to the movements in the world oil price market. The short term position is extremely volatile. It is not impossible that the Saudis, who have the capacity, will increase production up yet another substantial notch. They have the capacity to go to another 2 1/2 million barrels a day and they might decide that that degree of discipline remains necessary in order to educate their own maverick Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries members and put a further squeeze on Great Britain. If that is so, it is possible that prices will drop further in the short term or medium term. If that is so we might run into some substitution difficulties in immediate energy production uses overseas, which might have some immediate implications on volumes and prices. However, at the moment, it is not possible to make the prediction that that will occur. The general situation is as I have described it.

—I think he has an answer to this one.

—I hope he can answer all of them; I am sure he can. I ask: Is it true that the real unit labour costs fell by 4.4 per cent for the 12 months ended September 1985 compared with the previous 12 months? Also is it true that Treasury forecasts that real labour costs will fall by about 2 per cent over the financial year 1985-86? Would a deregulated wages policy have achieved this result or is it a product of the centralised wages policy of the prices and incomes accord? Is it true that the business community is reluctant to embrace a decentralised wages policy precisely because it would threaten this sort of achievement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the official statistics with me to confirm the precise figures which Senator Cook has given but I can say that the basic thrust of what he has said is, of course, correct, and that is that real unit labour costs are lower than they have been at any period in the last 16 years-as indeed is the number of industrial disputes lower than it has been in any period for the last 16 years. The converse of that virtually, I suppose, is that profit shares as a proportion of income have risen to the highest levels they have since the late 1960s.

ANSWER.PARA: I guess none of us really knows what motivates sections of Australian business when they assess or comment on the merits of the Government wages policy. Some seem to yearn for some golden age of a free market for labour which, if it ever existed at all-even in Tudor England there were laws about minimum wages and for almost all times since then-certainly it has not existed in Australia this century. Nevertheless they have some nostalgic or sentimental yearning for some system which they think will be better. It would be more sensible if they were to concentrate on the wages policy of this Government instead of an alternative wages policy which could be devised or that which was practised by the previous Government.

Of course, it is a matter of historical record that the previous Government decided that it would abandon centralised wage fixing in May of 1981. The decision was taken precipitately because the then Prime Minister was anxious to hop a Boeing 707 and go to the royal wedding. Nevertheless, the whole Cabinet had to take responsibility for that decision, including the then Treasurer. That Government decided that it would let market forces determine the level of wages. The product of that abdication of responsibility was an average wage increase of 13 per cent in calendar year 1981 and of 14 per cent in calendar year 1982, granted at a time when, at least in the early stages, there was significant economic growth. The achievement of this Government is that it has kept wage increases down to a level where real labour unit costs have fallen appreciably and done it throughout a period of some two and a half years of sustained economic growth.

The Opposition seems to be even slower to learn than some sections of the business community. What it gleefully looks forward to, so it says, is a deregulation of the labour market and to allowing wage levels to be set by market forces, in the belief, I assume, that wage increases will be less than those which have been recorded under the prices and incomes accord. That ignores the fact that there is organised market power on both sides of the labour market, for employees and for labour, that particularly at times of high economic growth some unions could obtain through market forces higher rates of wage increases than they have obtained under the accord, and that, because of the long-established notions of comparative wage justice, to a significant extent at least those wage increase, once obtained by sections of the labour force with some market power, would inevitably flow on to other sections. None of that seems to worry the present Leader of the Opposition. He seems to have learnt nothing from the fact that he presided over a wages explosion in 1981 and 1982 that ultimately induced the deepest recession which the country had seen in 50 years. Not only has he learnt nothing from that; he also compounds his error by gleefully anticipating, to use his phrase, five years of industrial warfare under the Howard preferred system of wage fixation.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Transport seen reports of a recent book by Dr John Adams of University College, London, in which he maintains that compulsory use of seat belts and motor cycle helmets and other safety regulations induce road users to drive faster and more recklessly than before and, therefore, do not lead to an overall reduction in traffic fatalities? Do Australian figures bear out Dr Adams's theories?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the theories put forward by Dr Adams and a number of other academic theories relating to the use of safety regulations in transport. Also, the State Ministers for Transport, in conjunction with the Commonwealth, attempt to set a pattern of universal behaviour in respect of seat belts and other safety matters. However, the theories that are put forward by Dr Adams are not borne out by Australian data. There was a substantial reduction-some 20 per cent-in occupant fatalities in Australia following the introduction of compulsory seat belt regulations. In light of that the Government is entitled to take the view, in association with the State Transport Ministers, that there should be no relaxation of that regulation. There has been no accompanying increase in pedestrian or bicycle fatalities, as predicted by Dr Adams, who believes that the introduction of such regulations induces transport operators to drive faster and more recklessly than previously.

ANSWER.PARA: The view that I have been expressing has been recently reaffirmed by the Australian Transport Ministers, so that the wearing of seat belts and child restraints will be maintained as a priority area. It is interesting that Dr Adams's country, the United Kingdom, has confirmed the trial run that it introduced in 1982. There has been a decision by the House of Commons to adopt compulsory seat belt legislation on a permanent basis. It is worth noting that in the period 1970 to 1984 the road toll in Australia fell by 26 per cent. Fatalities per 10,000 vehicles are down by 60 per cent and fatalities per 100,000 of the population are down by 40 per cent. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the recent report that Iranian troops have crossed the strategic Shatt al Arab waterway, capturing the Iraqi town of Faw. Does the Government appreciate the seriousness of this development? Does the Government believe that Iraq could fall? Is the escalation of the conflict likely to bring Iraq's neighbours or the superpowers into the conflict? In particular, what action is Australia taking in the United Nations Security Council in an effort to promote peace in that region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most recent briefing I have from the Minister for Foreign Affairs on this matter is dated 12 February. It may require some updating in light of the reports of recent fighting to which Senator Hill referred. But the situation in more general terms is as follows: The Government remains very concerned that the conflict between Iran and Iraq should still be continuing. We are particularly disturbed by the latest offensive mounted by Iranian forces-I suppose we are even more disturbed by the possible outcome of the latest offensive which began on 9 February around the Basra region of Iraq. This does represent, as Senator Hill says, a dangerous development in the conflict and threatens to lead to an increase in the level of hostilities between the two countries. The situation has serious implications for regional and international security. Mr Hayden reiterates previous calls by Australia to Iran and Iraq for an immediate ceasefire leading to negotiations, without preconditions, on a comprehensive settlement. This should include respect for international boundaries and an end to further attacks by either side.

ANSWER.PARA: As to developments in the Security Council, Australia, as a member of the Security Council, has been active in the search for a comprehensive settlement. In particular, as President of the Council in November last year we worked to establish a basis for the parties to the conflict to co-operate with the Council. It did not prove possible at that time to secure this co-operation, with Iran maintaining its view that previous Security Council resolutions had not adopted a balanced approach. Both Iraq and Iran expressed their appreciation of the Australian efforts in this respect and agreed that such efforts should continue in the Security Council.

We have been appalled by the destruction, human misery and loss of life resulting from this conflict, which has now entered its sixth year. The Australian Government has expressed its concern to both Iran and Iraq over the attacks on civilian population centres and on merchant shipping, the latter of which have now resulted in the deaths of two Australian seamen, the most recent being that of the late Mr Wayne Spicer on 19 January this year. Recurring allegations that chemical weapons have been used in the conflict are of particular concern to the Australian Government, which has always stated in the strongest terms its abhorrence of chemical weapons. We are working very hard at the Geneva Disarmament Conference to outlaw them. Their use, of course, has been condemned by the Security Council.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FRENCH WARSHIPS: VISITS TO AUSTRALIAN PORTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that two French warships, the Jeanne d'Arc and the Commandant Bourdais, are tied up at the Stirling naval base at Cockburn Sound on the way via Sydney to the South Pacific region? Given the Australian Government's repeated criticism of French nuclear testing in the Pacific and its somewhat belated criticism of the French Government's sinking of the Rainbow Warrior, is it not extremely insensitive of the Australian and French governments to plan visits by French warships to two Australian ports when anti-French Government sentiments are running high in the country? If the Australian Government is opposed to French military activities in the Pacific Ocean, why is it facilitating those military activities by welcoming French warship visits?
—I will seek an appropriate answer from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and hope to make it available as soon as possible this week.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and it follows an answer he gave earlier in Question Time today about the increase in average weekly earnings following a decision of the Fraser Government in 1981. I ask: Is it not a fact that average weekly earnings increased in 1973-74 by 15.9 per cent and in 1974-75 by 25.6 per cent, an increase in two years of over 40 per cent, followed in 1975-76 by another increase of 13 per cent? Is it also not a fact that in those years the Whitlam Labor Government was in power, pursuing, presumably, wages policies which are in accordance with Labor policy? Is it not a further fact that in those early years the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what the relevance of this piece of ancient history is supposed to be, but, if Senator Durack thinks I am embarrassed by it, he is certainly wrong. As with Senator Cook's precise figures down to the last decimal point, I do not know whether the figures that Senator Durack has quoted are correct, but they sound like they are of about the right order of magnitude to me. I will just take honourable senators through them again. I have taken the liberty of rounding them off. There was a 16 per cent wage increase in 1973-74 and a 25 per cent wage increase in 1974-75. It just happens that there was no wages policy during that period-there was no prices and incomes accord and there was no wage indexation-and wages blew out to that extent.

ANSWER.PARA: In May 1975 the predecessor, if you like, of the accord, wage indexation, was introduced. It had widespread acceptance and, according to Senator Durack's own figures, the rate of wage increase in the next financial year fell to around 13 per cent. In other words, the rate of wage increases almost halved in the year following the introduction of indexation in May 1975. I do not know what conclusion Senator Durack draws from those figures, but I would have thought that one not unreasonable conclusion to draw was that the indexation system and the high degree of compliance with the indexation system was one of the factors which helped to slow down the very high rate of wage increases that had taken place in 1974-75. Another factor is that the economic growth rate slowed down very appreciably in 1974-75 and, to a substantial extent, a falling rate of economic growth was associated with a high rate of wage increases without a wages policy, indexation or an accord. That applied in 1974, 1975 and in the second half of the calendar year 1982.

If Senator Durack is trying to prove that rates of wage increases higher than those in 1981 and 1982 have been known in Australia, that is correct. Those very high rates of wage increases which applied at that time slowed down, according to Senator Durack's figures, and almost halved within 12 months of the introduction of indexation. What is most striking about the success of the accord is that not only has it greatly reduced the rate of wage increases but also it has done it at a time when economic growth has been sustained at levels which are, by the standards of the Australian economy, historically high; at almost record levels of economic growth. We have had a near halving of the rate of wage increases and a halving of the rate of inflation; 550,000 new jobs have been created; and we have the lowest level of industrial disputes for 16 years. That beats hollow the record of the last Labor Government and the record of every Liberal Government that has been in control in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the response of the Minister for Education to the report by the Economic Planning Advisory Council on Australia's education performance relative to other countries? In particular, what action is the Government taking to lift the Australian education levels? Are there now signs of increasing retention rates at Australian secondary schools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to note the paper that came forward from EPAC and to some extent I agree with the analysis in it. I point out to honourable senators that the analysis made in the paper is one that was made by our Government in the early months of the first Hawke Government. In fact, the weaknesses identified in the EPAC paper were identified by me at the first National Economic Summit Conference and since that time we have made considerable progress in addressing the defects and problems that have been identified.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, in regard to the criticism that the participation rate of young Australians in the education system is too low-a criticism which was certainly very well founded in March 1983-it is now the case that more than 57,000 young Australians who are in post-secondary education and training were not there in 1983. In years 11 and 12, the last two years of school, there has been a 12 per cent increase in enrolments since 1983. In technical and further education over the same period there has been a 15 per cent increase in enrolments, and in higher education there has been an over 8 per cent increase. As well as that, 37,000 more students are enrolled part time in technical and further education courses. All of these extra students are creating better opportunities for themselves. They are becoming more skilled and therefore more productive and more able to participate in an important way in our economy.

There are a number of reasons for this improvement in participation rates. One of them has to be the fact that our Government in each Budget has increased student allowances. The secondary allowances scheme, SAS, which assists students from poorer families to stay on for their last two years of school, has been increased dramatically and by next year will be the same level as the youth unemployment benefit. Similarly, the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance has been increased successively and at the end of this triennium it will be at the same rate as the equivalent unemployment benefit for the same age group. Thus we will have removed the financial disincentive for young people from poorer families to continue their education and training to get the skills they require.

We have also embarked on a number of quality exercises. The Quality of Education Review Committee, chaired by Professor Peter Karmel, identified four national objectives for improvements in education. The resource agreements, which I am on the verge of concluding with all States and non-government schools systems, will ensure that extra recurrent resources provided by our Government to schools will be devoted to improvements in those four national priority areas. Similarly, we have embarked on a program of improving basic skills required in primary education. With regard to quality and standards in tertiary education, the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has embarked on a series of discipline reviews which will ensure that in all the major vocational areas conducted at universities the question of quality and standards will be addressed.

I think it will be very clear from this summary of actions taken by our Government to overcome problems of low participation, inappropriate courses or poor quality that a great deal of progress has been made. It is the intention of our Government to continue to make progress in this area so that Australia has at its disposal a very highly educated, skilled work force which is flexible and which is able to make a constructive contribution to our economy and, of course, to social equity for all Australians.

The Government is unwilling or is so far not prepared to alter the tax laws to prevent this from happening. I refer to Mr Holmes a Court's bid for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd.

An article that appeared in the Age of 13 February by Kenneth Davidson shows that the Holmes a Court companies have a liability to the Government of $112m. If the Holmes a Court bid is successful and he takes over BHP that tax liability of $112m will be eliminated. The Government will lose that revenue. Even if we take into account the increase in income tax that the Government will presumably get from the current shareholders in BHP from the profits they make as a result of selling their shares in BHP, the Government's loss of revenue will still be $80m. In other words, the Government is prepared to sit back and in one financial transaction lose more than it would have lost if it had eliminated negative gearing on all farms throughout the country. What the Government is not prepared to do for the farmers it is prepared to do for big business. It is not prepared to look at the tax laws and treat--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Is it appropriate, right and proper for Senator Siddons to place this motion before the Senate when he himself is involved in a takeover battle at present?
—That is not a point of order.

—I was making the point that the Government is about to lose $80m of revenue in one financial transaction, namely, the Holmes a Court take-over of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, and that the revenue the Government will gain from the quarantining of all farm losses is only $60m. By any reckoning, I believe that the Government is being unfair. If it is going to take certain action against farmers it is reasonable that it should take similar action against the corporate sector. The Government is losing $80m in one financial transaction.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the loss to Government revenue in the overall take-over scene in this country? In 1982-83 there were 105 take-overs in Australia; in 1984-85 there were 122 take-overs. This year we are off to a good start with the Holmes a Court bid for BHP, and the bid for the Repco company. There are only 980 first-board listed public companies in Australia. If this rate of take-over continues we can very easily see in a few years that we will have one floated public company that has gobbled up all the rest. The loss of revenue from the total corporate sector, as I said, is enormous. The total net profit before tax of all corporations in Australia was $20.146 billion. In 1981-82 company tax collected was $5.053 billion. The figures in 1984-85 are these: Total net profit before tax for corporations is $31.261 billion, and the company tax collected is $5.505 billion. In other words, over that period company tax, as a percentage of net profit, has fallen from 25 per cent to 17 per cent. Many observers claim that nearly half of this is due to the take-over racket. If this is true, take-overs in 1984-85 have cost the Government $1.4 billion. In other words, if the Government had moved to control the take-over racket it would have stood to gain $1.4 billion or would have reduced its deficit by about one-quarter.

Right now the Government is worrying about losing a billion dollars or thereabouts if it honours its promise to Australian motorists to reduce the price of petrol in line with the international price of oil. On the other hand, it has given a very firm undertaking to the Australian motorist that it will do just that. The Government, of course, is in a dilemma. It has two potentially conflicting promises-to keep the size of the deficit down as a percentage of gross domestic product, and at the same time to reduce the price of petrol if the price of crude oil falls on the international market. I know which way I would go if I had anything to do with that dilemma. I would honour a promise that the Government has given to all Australian people and worry about its commitment to big business later. I am putting to the Senate that, if the Government did something about the take-over racket, it could very easily recoup the $1.4 billion and thus honour both promises. Of course, it must also take into account the fact that a substantial reduction in the price of petrol to motorists would have an enormous stimulatory effect on the economy generally.

I am not suggesting that all take-overs are bad. In some cases companies taken over are performing badly. They are revitalised and turned around, and that is a net gain to the economy. Take-overs, or the threat of take-overs, can keep the boards of public companies on their toes, and that is a good thing. The problem with take-overs today is simply this: They can be profitable in themselves. They are pursued as an end in themselves without any regard to their effect on the economy generally and without any regard to the end result of the efficiency of the corporations that are taken over. This happens because there is substantial Government incentive for take-overs to occur. First of all, the Government has allowed to persist the law which enables companies to write off the interest charged on the large amounts of money which they borrow for take-overs against the consolidated profits or losses of the corporations. Both the target company and the raider can consolidate the interest charge and, therefore, very small companies are able to take over very large companies.

The fact that interest is written off means that there is about a 50 per cent reduction in the interest charge anyway. Company tax is 46c in the dollar. That means that the raider's interest bill is reduced by 50 per cent. Because the raider has a lower interest charge on the money he borrows than the ordinary shareholder, he is in a much better position to offer a higher price for shares than the ordinary shareholder who cannot write off interest against the money borrowed. Under our existing tax laws the raider can always outbid the market.

When a take-over is successful the raider must cope with a huge debt. This is often dealt with by selling out parts of companies that are profitable. When this happens jobs are lost and productive capacity in the economy generally is weakened. The fact that the Government is subsidising take-overs in this way means that the tax burden on the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayer is greater than it would otherwise be.

Let us look at the effect take-overs have on our foreign debt. Today companies tend to borrow money overseas to finance take-over bids. For example, Coles borrowed $800m overseas to buy out Myer, Bond recently borrowed something like $1,200m to buy out Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd and Holmes a Court will have to borrow no less than $2,000m to buy out BHP. All this overseas borrowing to finance take-overs has contributed enormously to Australia's external debt. Australia's foreign debt rose from $8.1 billion in 1981 to $42 billion in 1985. Over that period Australia's total repayment for foreign debt has increased from 17 per cent of exports to 30 per cent of exports. The facts of the matter are that take-overs are not leading to the increase in exports which is necessary to finance our foreign borrowings.

Another very unfortunate aspect of the take-over game as it is played at the moment is that it puts wealth into fewer hands. The trend to take-overs financed by borrowings means that equity capital is being replaced by debt capital. That means that ordinary shareholders are losing their stake in Australian companies. The Bond Corporation's take-over of Castlemaine Tooheys is a recent example of this. A $280m company, the Bond company, swallowed a $1,200m company. Castlemaine Tooheys is now owned by the Bond Corporation through the medium of borrowed money rather than by the thousands of shareholders as was previously the case. What is happening is that our economy is becoming increasingly owned by fewer and fewer people and is being mortgaged to foreign banks. All this is being funded by taxpayers. Another unfortunate aspect is that it is increasing market power in fewer and fewer hands. The most notable example of this is in the rural area where we see the two firms, Elders-IXL and Dalgety Farmers Ltd controlling the sale of 85 per cent of Australia's wool. Elders controls 75 per cent of our rural cattle market and it dominates the market for farm credit. Of course this gives that company enormous power over the farming sector.

I turn now to what we believe the Government should do about this. I hope I have established the case that at present the Government is massively losing revenue and that other unfortunate aspects of the takeover scene at present are adversely affecting our economy. I suggest four Government initiatives: Firstly, that the Government should legislate to prevent interest charges on borrowings to fund share purchases from being able to be offset against income other than that which is produced by the shares concerned. In other words, the Government should stop negative gearing for companies. If the Government saw fit to stop negative gearing for farmers then it should stop negative gearing for corporations. What is good for one is good for the other. The elimination of negative gearing for corporations would not prevent take-overs but it would ensure that the smaller companies would have much more difficulty in swallowing up companies much larger than themselves. Big companies would have to be taken over by companies approaching their size and the current move from equity to debt would be slowed, share swap deals would become more attractive and the real worth and profitability of corporations would once again be put into true perspective.

Secondly, we believe that pro rata partial bids should be banned, or at the very minimum partial bids should be allowed only as proportional bids. The Democrats would press for all partial bids to be banned, but at the very least pro rata bids should be banned. I ask the Government: Where is the legislation to bring this into effect? Why is it not coming into the Parliament this week? It has been discussed and talked about and it was announced months ago, yet so far we have not seen the colour of the legislation. The third initiative that I believe the Government should ensure happens quickly is that some exchange control should be reintroduced. The reintroduction of variable deposit ratios would discourage overnight the practice of borrowing overseas in order to finance huge take-overs. Our foreign debt is already far too high and I believe that the Government cannot sit back any longer without taking control of capital flows in and out of the country.

The fourth initiative that we believe is relevant is this: In the public interest the Attorney-General should initiate some inquiry into these massive take-overs. The only forum that is available currently for such an inquiry to take place is under the existing trade practices legislation. The Attorney-General could initiate an inquiry for take-overs which affect the national interest and which affect the productive capacity of this country so that we carefully assess whether these take-overs were in the national interest or not.

How long can a government that pretends to represent the ordinary Australian, the worker, sit back and allow vested interests-large foreign vested interests-free rein to the rape of our large companies. How long can the Government sit back and allow these massive losses of revenue to occur without doing something? How long can the Government continue to discriminate against one sector of the economy, namely the very important farming sector, without treating the rest of the corporate sector in the same way? How long can a government which tells us it is concerned about jobs and about unemployment, sit back and allow productive, efficient companies to be gobbled up and then sold off to the highest bidder whether that bidder is overseas or within this country? It is absolutely imperative that the Government take action immediately and we in the Australian Democrats for a start will not sit back again and listen to the Government talking about $60m loss of revenue for guaranteeing farm losses as being absolutely critical to its Budget strategy, while it insists on doing nothing about the gobbling up of our efficient large corporations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in the discussions currently taking place in the chamber as honourable senators accuse each other of being pipsqueaks and having vested interests in the debate. However, I will get back to the real issues which, supposedly, have been raised by Senator Siddons. The Government has in fact quite grave reservations about the import and effect of this urgency motion. However, in fact, we would look at some other options which would go close to satisfying some of the issues which he raised.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an interesting motion moved by Senator Siddons because no doubt from his own business experience he is aware of the rapidity with which business itself can react to any intervention by the Government in this area; in other words, changes in regulations, changes in rules and changes in laws. He knows very well that these can be circumvented by smart lawyers in no time flat. To go up that path of excessive regulation in order to prevent possible-I use the word `possible'-breaches of public interest or actions which are against the interests of the public at large is in fact to go up a road that can lead to nowhere. Also he would be aware that hasty prohibitionist action in this area on the part of governments can often have the opposite effect of that which the Government originally intended. In other words, good intentions do not necessarily provide a proper base for government intervention in the economy.

I must say at the outset that I share some of the honourable senator's concerns about the nature and effects of the take-overs and mergers currently occurring in this country. I get the feeling that there is a certain macho desire by some businessmen in this community to treat it as a game-as a matter of lifting their own personal prestige at the expense of the community at large. Of course, the media is all too ready to play a part in lifting those sorts of activities to the status of a football game. For example, we hear often about Bond versus X Corporation, Holmes a Court versus the world and Elliott versus the Poms. It is all good media material. To some extent I think that has been responsible for encouraging people such as Senator Siddons to take the populist approach rather than the long view and attempting to base his views on better information which no doubt-

TALK.START.PARA: —You are now a mouthpiece of big business; the same as the Liberal Party.

—Senator Chipp says that I am a mouthpiece of big business. I am absolutely intrigued that the honourable senator should accuse me of that when he has sat here in this chamber and blocked legislation that the Government has brought into this chamber to get back money from tax dodgers and the bottom of the harbour operators in the community. This represents significant amounts of money which should have come to the revenue and significant cheating that went on in this community. The honourable senator sat here and voted against that legislation. Now he accuses me of being a tool of the capitalists in the community. I indicate at this stage that I do not have any companies; I have never had any companies. I have always been a wage employee in this community.
—I am not suggesting you are. You are just a mouthpiece for big business, the same as the Liberal Party.

—I am not bought overnight, as Senator Chipp indicates. However, I do not intend to be put off by his interjections. I gave Senator Siddons a clear hearing without any interjections. I expect the same. There are times when the interests of this country as a whole and the employees of affected companies may be overlooked during mergers. No-one better expressed that than the Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission, Henry Bosch, when he indicated in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 December 1985 the occasional effects of some of these takeovers and merger operations. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The vast majority of takeovers cause considerable hardship to the employees involved, usually in the target company, but also sometimes in the company which has made the offer. People who have given their lives to companies and often made efforts beyond the normal call of duty are frequently swept aside as redundant pawns in the takeover process. Now I do not believe that anyone (not even public servants) should be guaranteed life tenure of their occupation whatever their personal performance, and I could accept it if our system produced some personal discomfort for the sake of general advances in the national wealth. But when grave personal damage is done to thousands of people for no better reason than the aggrandisement of a paper entrepreneur I feel a serious disquiet.
He further stated:

A management which feels under threat will divert part of its energies from the longer-term creation of wealth to defensive measures. After all, self-preservation is a human enough response. Defensive measures take many forms.
Further, he said:
Most serious of all, managements are tempted to maximise short-term profits and share prices by measures that undermine longer-term productivity and growth.

Again, they are serious reservations which are held not only by Senator Siddons but also by Henry Bosch, myself and many other senators on this side of the House. Of course, we must not let that obscure the fact that we live in a fairly deregulated economy. That was a deliberate decision made by this Government with the backing of the trade union movement and with the backing of industry and commerce at large. It was made, I must say, with the backing of most honourable senators in this House. Does the honourable senator wish suddenly to turn the clock back to the period of the 1920s and 1930s when manufacturing industry in this country lived in the feather-bedded situation in which it was simply not able to compete on world markets, where it forced governments through various stratagems to lift tariffs, to provide all sorts of benefits, bounties and tariff protection in order to stay comfortable in its own little backyard? In the long run if we want to go back to that situation basically we would be asking workers in this country to accept all the negatives which that type of economy had. It had negatives. Senator Siddons will recall the number of occasions when major car companies in this country sacked workers-a thousand at a time on occasions-in order to force the various governments of the day to provide further protective measures. Senator Siddons knows that in the car industry there were many occasions when a government moved to open up the economy in order to deregulate and the car company simply reacted by sacking workers to force the Government's hands in a particular direction.

It is certain that takeovers and mergers will increase during this period. We are going through a period of deregulation and economic and industrial restructuring of the kind the Australian economy needed. This applies particularly to industries that are trade exposed. We cannot turn back to that period that Senator Siddons presumably wants us to turn back to. The question we must ask ourselves is whether we accept this current policy of deregulation and whether we accept that the current policy mix that we have is appropriate for this economy. I happen to believe that it is. I believe that at this stage to lose our nerve, as Senator Siddons seems to be calling for us to do, would in fact not serve the interests of the community at large or of the employees of many of these industries which are quietly going to the wall.

Senator Siddons mentioned the question of immediate action. He moved straight into this in his speech. The Australian Labor Party has taken action to ensure that business activities in this area are watch-dogged by appropriate regulatory bodies whose roles are to ensure that we have fair and honest trading. Both the Trade Practices Commission, which is a creation of the Labor Party's policies, and the strengthened National Companies and Securities Commission perform functions which ensure that this fairness does occur.

When Senator Siddons raised this issue as a matter of urgency, he well knew that this Government was about to introduce legislation into this Parliament which would outlaw pro rata partial share bids, one of the problems he raised, as I understand it, with regard to the Holmes a Court processes. It will be before this Parliament very soon. The decision to introduce such legislation was arrived at, as the honourable senator knows, through the co-operative scheme operating under the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities made up of the six State governments and the respective Commonwealth Minister. Does the honourable senator want that process of discussion and co-operation at a national level changed to one in which a full time centralised watch-dog will be operating in every nook and cranny of the business community?

The Government, the unions and State governments also have a role to play in ensuring that those people who are affected by mergers and take-overs, in particular workers, are protected in the most adequate way. I believe that one of the most adequate ways is to make sure that on all occasions there are appropriate redundancy packages, that legislation is introduced to ensure proper long service leave entitlements for all workers to share in and that a proper superannuation scheme is operating in both the public and private sectors across this country. In that way, the cost of making people redundant, the cost of demanning, will be prohibitive for many of those companies which have taken over smaller companies, or in some cases larger companies, with the prime aim of making a capital gain-those companies that per se are not interested in the welfare of workers in the companies that they have just taken over. Those are matters that the Labor Party and the Labor movement have been dealing with over a very long period.

Some of Senator Siddons's counterparts in other States have opposed increasingly generous superannuation arrangements. They have opposed increasingly generous long service leave entitlements. They have opposed those redundancy packages which have protected workers in the way that I have mentioned from sackings of the type that Senator Siddons was so careful to point out are a problem with most mergers in this country. Is Senator Siddons also saying as an alternative that boards of management that are incompetent, lazy, slack or made up of people who have inherited their wealth and who have no motivation to improve the performance of their companies should be sacrosanct and should not be challenged by take-over bids in the community?

TALK.START.PARA: —I never suggested that, and I made that point.
—If Senator Siddons is not suggesting that, where does he make the cut-off point? As with most of these issues, one makes a balanced--
—What is in the national interest.

—Senator Siddons replies that he will make his decisions on the basis of what is in the national interest. Many people, from Adolf Hitler through to the Communist Party and our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), have talked about the national interest.
—Are you putting them all in the same group?

—No, I am not putting them all in the same group; I am saying that they represent totally different parts of the spectrum. Deciding what is in the national interest is a matter of value judgment. Senator Siddons knows that legislation cannot be drafted primarily on what one or other group in the community believes to be in the national interest. That will vary. Business people in this community are entitled to know that a government will not react on the spur of the moment to some emotional blackmail coming from a party which holds the balance of power in the Senate. They want to look for some long term guidelines on where this economy is going.
—Sell the whole place out to foreigners. That's your guideline.

—This place was sold out significantly to foreigners during the period when Senator Chipp was a member of the government of the day that handed over the whole lot, lock stock and barrel, to British and American interests. I do not think that Senator Chipp can come into this chamber and talk about selling out to foreign interests. His record as a Cabinet member of that Government which, to a great degree, sold this country out years ago is appalling. The honourable senator ought to keep quiet and wait for his turn to speak on another occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems with regard to foreign debt in this country are primarily those that arose from the resources boom that was talked up by the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, in the late 1970s and early 1980s, when he encouraged many semi-government instrumentalities to borrow on the world markets to finance particular projects which we now know will never have a return on their capital investment. I include such projects as hydro-electric schemes in various States and other thermal power schemes, borrowings for which were quite significant during that period. I refer to water board and local government borrowings, all of which were encouraged by the Prime Minister of the day simply for electoral purposes. I cannot recall Senator Siddons making his feelings known during that period on the degree of borrowings by semi-governmental authorities that were putting this country into some difficulty. That problem has yet to be met further down the line, if we look at the effect of the exchange rate on Australian borrowings overseas.

What is missing in this debate? Firstly, what is missing is hard, factual information on what has actually happened in this country with regard to take-overs and mergers and their effect on the viability of the economy and of companies at large. If Senator Siddons is looking for advice from me-he does not ask for it very often but my guess is that he would be asking for it today-he should, first of all, listen carefully to what Henry Bosch has indicated with regard to the educative and research role of the National Companies and Securities Commission. He indicated that at the moment the Commission and a number of other academics in the community, particularly economists, have been looking very closely at studying just what did go on with take-overs and mergers over the last decade and what is likely to occur in the future. Unless we have that factual base, I do not believe that we should be bringing legislation into this Parliament. As I said, the problems caused by intervention by governments in the economy without a proper factual data base can be much greater than simply doing nothing at all. I refer to an article written on 25 November 1985 by economics writer, David Clark, entitled `On the Other Hand'. I shall read directly from it just to indicate that I am not alone in my views about the dearth of factual data and that they are shared by a number of economics writers in relation to this whole question of take-overs and merger data. Such data does exist in the American context and it has been very valuable in affecting government decisions and decisions by a number of economic advisers to the President. The article states:

The first responsibility of the NCSC at this time should be public education. Policy decisions should be postponed until we all have a much improved knowledge of the issues involved and have had the opportunity to scrutinise closely and assess the empirical studies still in the pipe-line.
The issues are far too complex and important to be left to ideologues and obfuscators of any persuasion.

I agree with that statement. Until such time as we get that information before us-it may take time-I believe it is very important that we do not go down the track that Senator Siddons indicated without looking at the facts first. Senator Siddons asked when the Government should act. I will put it in a personal context. There is a time to act if mergers and take-overs are of proved negative benefit to the economy and to the country as a whole. I take Robert Holmes a Court's offer for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd as an example. I understand that we can assume that at the moment there is a possibility of Holmes a Court gaining control of a $12 billion asset for just on $2 billion. I think that Senator Siddons would agree with those figures at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do.

—I note that Senator Siddons agrees. Should an examination of BHP's steel division's 6 per cent return on capital investment-I think that is an accepted figure-prompt him to sell off that division, if he happens to get control of BHP, I would personally favour special legislation in this Parliament to prevent such a sale. Then there would be a proved example of Holmes a Court's motivations in terms of his attempts to move against what all honourable senators here would consider to be the public interest. That is the time to move. We should not act on suspicion. The point I am making is that there is a right time for government intervention in these matters. My contention is that the Government should not act on moralistic suspicion or populist viewpoints, as propounded by Senator Siddons. We should be prepared to act when the time is right. Therein lies the difference between the Government and Senator Siddons and his Party.

Ltd. This has occurred after some months in which there has been a very great deal of interest and discussion in the newspapers about takeovers; in particular the question of the takeover of BHP. But there are a number of others and Senator Siddons has referred to them. Another well known one, of course, was the takeover by the Bond Corporation of the Castlemaine Tooheys brewing company.
