The necessity for the Government to take immediate action to prevent company takeovers which add nothing to Australia's economic efficiency or growth, increase Australia's overseas indebtedness, and are used to deny massive revenue to the Government.

Senator Siddons began his speech this afternoon by referring to the loss of revenue that allegedly the Government incurred as a result of the moves by Mr Holmes a Court, or his Bell company, so far in regard to BHP. There has been quite a bit of discussion about the Government's loss of revenue in relation to some of the other takeovers. The whole tenor of this urgency motion and Senator Siddons's speech in support of it has been one which would leave the impression that there was something radically wrong with takeovers. The presumption would be that they were bad and that, of course, inevitably the Government must regulate them or perhaps prevent them altogether. Senator Siddons indicated in the course of his speech that he-and, I presume, the Democrats-is opposed at least to partial takeovers of a company by an offer for a proportion of the shares of a company.

There is, I think, throughout the terms of the urgency motion and Senator Siddons's speech on behalf of the Democrats, a very critical attitude to takeovers and the need for government intervention. The fact is that governments and parliaments have been taking action in relation to takeover offers for many years. I think the first example of such legislation occurred as far back as 1961. In fact many people believe that there are already far too detailed rules and regulations regarding takeovers. For the Democrats, particularly on the very day of the takeover offer for BHP and in the wake of a number of other high profile takeovers, to be demanding immediate action by government in regard to these matters, I believe, is premature and rather naive-all things, of course, for which the Democrats are well known.

The view of the Opposition in relation to takeovers is that there is room for some regulation but that on the whole takeovers-and certainly the likelihood of takeovers occurring-play a very important part in improving economic efficiency and the performance of companies, particularly in regard to their management and also in regard to their general direction. The other important aspect in regard to takeover activity from an economic point of view is that it can greatly increase the market that is available to the company as a result of its gaining a greater size and a greater area of operation.

Australian industry has been unfortunate over recent decades in the size of its market. One of the major characteristics of commercial activity over the last few decades is that companies have been looking more and more to expand their market operation and market opportunities, and not simply to be confined to their traditional areas, whether those areas comprise a particular town, city, State or nation. Indeed, one of the more pleasing aspects of recent commercial activities in the takeover area has been the extent to which Australian companies are now looking to the world scene. They are looking to expanding their markets overseas. This is the sort of outgoing commercial policy which we as the legislators of the nation should be applauding and encouraging. We should not be placing more and more restrictions upon it. We should be seeking more open activities by companies, involving more initiative and more enterprise on a larger scale.

One aspect that Senator Siddons did not refer to in his speech is the fact that an Australian company, BHP, in recent times has taken over a large American company, the Utah Corporation. That has given not only BHP but also the Australian economy a very welcome addition to their resource base and strength by increasing its market operation and the size of its operation. We also see, as a result of the takeover bid by the Elders group for a large English brewing company, the opportunity of greatly expanding the Australian market in that product. I have no doubt that the Bond Corporation, by taking over Castlemaine Tooheys, has greatly expanded the degree of competition, not only in Australia but overseas, in relation to beer. There are now two Australian companies engaging in competition in a very major new market, namely, the United Kingdom, for an Australian product. That is the very thing that we want to encourage our companies to do. We want them to be enterprising, outward looking, and to increase the size of their markets. For heaven's sake, the Achilles heel of Australian manufacturing industry is that it has not had adequate markets for its product within Australia, within the old, traditional, local markets, mostly of a State kind.

A few years ago there was a great deal of opposition by State governments and parliaments to takeovers by well known State companies operating in a State. Legislation was enacted to try to stop people buying up a well known State company. There were pressures on State companies. That is absolutely the wrong direction in which our manufacturing industry should be moving. We are now witnessing, in a very encouraging way, companies moving in the right direction-that is, one of expansion and the creation of new markets. Senator Messner referred to a very well known South Australian company. South Australia is one of the States I had in mind which a few years ago tried to stop takeover activity. An innovative, enterprising South Australian company is taking over a number of Australian enterprises, including David Jones Limited. It is improving not only its own operation but also the operation of the companies that it has taken over. That is the reason why we must not put barriers and roadblocks in the way of these commercial operations. Governments and parliaments should have policies which give encouragement to this sort of activity.

The important point that needs to be kept under review is whether the interests of shareholders are being properly protected. There has been some debate in the past, and there may be some now, as to whether the take-over laws at present are adequate to give full protection to shareholders. By and large it is for the shareholders-not governments, not big brother and not this Parliament-to decide whether they are going to sell their shares. The laws must ensure that they are properly informed. The shareholders should be put in an equal position as far as possible so that the small shareholder will not be squeezed out and his interests totally ignored if control of a company changes. We have to have laws which give a fair go to shareholders. By and large, that is what the take-over laws have been about. We know perfectly well that a change to the present law relating to partial take-overs is in the pipeline. It has been approved by a ministerial council and the Government will be introducing it into the Parliament shortly. It may be a good idea if we had it already. I hope the Government will get on with introducing it so that we can see it and debate it. That is a good example of the sort of activity that it is proper for us to be engaged in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you support that?

—We have not seen the legislation yet. The Australian Democrats seem to want us to undertake a wholesale onslaught to prevent immediately take-overs, many of which may have highly beneficial effects. They are beating their breasts about some of them bleeding the revenues and others increasing indebtedness. One reason why companies are going overseas to the extent they are to borrow money is that interest rates are so high in Australia under the policies of this Government. Interest rates are significantly lower overseas than they are in Australia. The Government ought to be doing something about the sort of policy which results in that happening. But to stop the take-over is really to throw the baby out with the bathwater, which is the sort of approach which the Democrats seem to think the Government ought to be taking.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not support that approach by the Democrats. We believe that a number of Government policies could be changed to give greater encouragement to Australia's economic performance. Once one starts involving oneself in wholesale changes to policies and regulations, one often ends up with the last day being far worse than the first. As an example I refer to investment controls in Australia. Instead of encouraging more equity investment from overseas, we have followed the policy of forcing companies to borrow much more overseas. That is one of the reasons for Australia's high indebtedness. These are the sorts of policies that need to be reviewed and brought up to date. Most of the suggestions that the Democrats have come up with have involved broad Government policies and are not specifically in relation to take-overs. To have legislation which is directly related to take-overs and economic policies there when it would be better directed to other areas of Government policy, such as high interest rates, is to miss the mark in this area.
The Opposition believes that it would give a much more suitable expression of the views of this Parliament if the motion were reworded to read:
The need for the Government to keep the laws relating to takeovers under constant review to ensure that they are fair to shareholders and operate in the public interest.
Pursuant to a contingent notice of motion, on behalf of Senator Chaney, I move:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chaney moving an amendment to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out the statement of the matter of urgency, insert the following:
`The need for the Government to keep the laws relating to takeovers under constant review to ensure that they are fair to shareholders and operate in the public interest'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right to buy and sell and the right to grow and expand without government interference has been a basic right in this country since European settlement. It has enabled us to grow and to prosper as a nation. There is no reason, despite the size of some recent take-over bids, to change the whole approach that government has had to the market in one foul swoop. The recent flurry of take-over activity and the huge size of it are really only signs that Australia, as a nation, is continuing to grow and that business, in its search for newer markets and expansion, is simply looking further afield. There is no reason for governments suddenly to express great alarm because of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that Senator Durack's amendment refers to making sure that take-overs are kept under constant review to ensure that they are fair to shareholders. I would also like to throw in the employees because there is no doubt that any take-over bid must cause considerableheartache and worry among a great many employees as to what their future is likely to be. In some respects that can be a good and a bad thing. There is no doubt that when companies target others for take-over they are very often looking at how good the management is in the company they have targeted. If the management has been sluggish, bad, slow or no good whatsoever, people in that management team ought to be worrying about the bid. I do not want to stop that sort of worry. There is nothing like the threat of the chop in those circumstances to get some managerial people working in a way that they have not for some time.

The whole tenor of this motion that in some way take-over bids are bad per se really ought to be examined. Should anyone have complained about the bid by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd for the Utah company when we had a great expansion by an Australian company in buying into a foreign company? In that sense, why would anyone complain about buying back some of the farm? So far as I can recall, nobody did in this chamber. The BHP bid, which was huge and matched all of the current ones which have attracted so much publicity, did not receive any attention here because that was considered to be the right thing to do. What would people ask BHP to do in those circumstances if they want to agree with the tenor of Senator Siddons's motion? Do they want to put BHP up before some new review board? Is there to be yet another Government board, with more than adequate support staff costing us more and more millions, to look at whether or not it is right for a company to spend more millions in a take-over? I suspect not.

Senator Siddons used the magnificent phrase that we must act in the `national interest'. That is terrific, until one gets around to determining a view, with which we will all agree, of the national interest and how it is best served. I might have some severe disagreements with Senator Durack as to what the national interest will be in these matters, as I am sure there will be disagreements right around the place. In the Australian Labor Party one always pricks up one's ears in a debate when someone uses the words `rank and file'. It usually means that someone wants to do something to our rules. When someone wants to cloak that in the right terminology, the right cure-all for everything, he uses the phrase `rank and file'. I note that Senator Childs is smiling. When it comes to matters of business, the same sort of phrase is used in another context; that is `the national interest'. I think that we would have a great deal of difficulty in trying to determine what the national interest would be in any of these take-overs.

Let us examine Bond and Tooheys, which was a very big take-over, around the billion dollar mark. I am sure that if we had set up this board and had a prominent retired politician to chair it-perhaps Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle will be available in a few years-we could have watched the two parties go before it to argue out the rights and wrongs of the take-over. In determining what is in the national interest, I am sure that Zampatti and the former members of the board would have gone to great lengths to say that they were terrific managers who had run a great company and no one possibly could do better. I am certain also that Alan Bond and his team would have said: `With our unique opportunities with the America's Cup over the next few years and our ability to expand into international markets because of it, obviously we can do more with this company. We can take it further; our profits will be greater; we will expand the number of employees'. In the end, what would be served by all of that talk? The reality is nothing and no one. No individuals could possibly be advantaged by it.

God help anyone attempting a take-over, for all the best reasons in the world, if he is held up for six months going to a government commission to find out whether or not he can go ahead. If we are talking about settling the uncertainties of shareholders, how much uncertainty would be settled during that prolonged period? All it would mean is another bonanza for the lawyers. God knows that governments in this country in the past 20 years have been good at creating commissions; let us not create one more.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better be voting against the Bill of Rights.

—My attitude and that of the honourable senator on the Bill of Rights would probably be a little opposite, but then again our attitudes on many things are. I can learn to live with it; I hope he can too. As one looks at the Bond and Tooheys episode of recent times, there is no question that at the end of the day that take-over will benefit both the shareholders and the employees, but it is a matter which had to be decided in the marketplace. There was no other forum for it to be decided and there could be no other forum. To regulate what businesses can buy and sell and what areas of business activity a company is allowed to go into will spell disaster for Australia. We can forget about any investment or capital inflow coming in from other countries, because people will not want to invest in that sort of environment and why should they? While it is all right for Senator Sanders or Senator Chipp to cry `foreign investment' on every occasion they can in this chamber, the reality is that without it we would be in an awful lot of strife and it is something we have to keep. I oppose any move which seeks in the name of the national interest to try to devalue our dollar further by trying to limit overseas capital coming into Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some inherent false assumptions in the whole approach which Senator Siddons has taken to this debate. The first one that ought to be tackled is that we can determine in advance which take-overs will be advantageous. That just will not be possible. I suppose that if we did not set up the body with Dame Margaret Guilfoyle as chairman, we would have to resort to our own opinions. I suppose that we could have a debate in Parliament about each take-over. There could be the Bond-Tooheys Bill and we could all line up for a division to determine which side we supported, but I am not sure that that would serve the national interest, no matter how one defines the national interest or who defines it. There is no prior method of determining what is good or bad in any particular take-over and there cannot be.

It is interesting to note that in the motion moved by Senator Siddons nothing along those lines is suggested. As is customary for the Australian Democrats in these matters, while jumping on bankwagons-there are no better jumpers in the business than the Democrats-they have not had time to flesh out a policy. I might say that not having had the time to flesh out a policy is not unique. We have watched the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) doing that now for some time, but for the Democrats it is a fact of life that on every populist cause they jump on to they will not have had time.

We have had the bold assertion that the Government should take immediate action to stop take-overs. We are not told exactly what sort of action the Government ought to take; we are told just that action should be taken. I think that there is a central difficulty in Senator Siddons's motion, in that unless we ever find out what sorts of controls the envisages, we will not get very much further in this debate. The next assumption contained in the motion is that all take-overs increase Australia's indebtedness. That is simply not the case. There is no evidence to point to that at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the National Companies Commission in the United Kingdom?

—I think the honourable senator should take a deep breath; he is getting excited. Firstly, it depends on whether the take-over will be financed domestically in Australia or internationally. Obviously a lot of take-overs are financed domestically, or significant portions of them are, and that can hardly add to any form of international indebtedness. Secondly, one has to look at how much capital is freed up here on the local side. In any of these take-over bids, in almost every instance when shareholders of the company sell out to a new bidder, they will be selling out at a profit. The price of the shares will have gone up as word circulates that the take-over is about to occur and either the original bidder takes over or a white knight has been found. In any case, shareholders sell out at a profit. What happens with the profit? These investors obviously will look around for somewhere else to put their money, and that can have only a beneficial effect on our economy. It must lead to an increase in efficiency and growth because more money is circulating into more industries. We have to look at whether or not that money goes into export industries, and there is some evidence that is has. We can import more goods and services, particularly if those goods are in the form of capital goods, and they can be used to restructure and improve our export industries. At this stage of Australia's development anything that can go towards increasing the efficiency of our export industries is obviously to our advantage as a nation and to the advantage of those participating in the industries.

SPEECH.PARA: An increase in indebtedness is harmful if there are no resources to service the debt. So far there are no examples of that having occurred in Australia. I note that in the Holmes a Court bid, which has fascinated the nation over recent weeks, the only real problem will be how far Holmes a Court can go in attempting to take over BHP before the amount he is getting from share earnings is less than he needs to service the debt. If he has a problem on that bid, that is where it will be.

Amendments that will be introduced into this chamber and into the other place in March could have some effect. They may not be introduced in time to have an effect on Holmes a Court's bid. I am not one of those with the knowledge of what the Cabinet is doing-we would have to ask the gods of our Party for an answer to that. The Australian Financial Review of 19 December 1985 referred to the National Companies and Securities Commission having spelt out how it planned to apply its new powers on partial and conditional take-overs. I would like to quote from that article. It stated:

The NCSC, in a policy statement released yesterday, said: the aim of the amendments was to preclude the use of prescribed conditions in offers which conflict with `the objectives of commercial certainty and equality of opportunity among shareholders of the target company.
That, of course, is what Senator Durack's amendment would go to. The article continued:

Among other things, the amendments will give the NCSC power to refuse registration of part-A offer documents which, in the words of the commission, `contain conditions, the fulfilment of which depends upon the subjective opinion of the offerer . . .

The reality is, of course, that that is exactly what has happened in so many of the partial takeover bids of recent times. This makes it harder and harder for shareholders to look with any degree of certainty to their future. The Commission was conscious of the potential for abuse through conditions which are vague or ambiguous. The vagueness of those conditions is something which has been upsetting many people in the country for a long time. I hope that the amendments will go a long way towards sorting them out.

In the very short time that is left to me I would like to deal with the only other matter that I want to refer to, and that is the taxation implications. The broad claim of massive revenue loss just does not hold true when we examine the situation more closely. Interest paid on borrowings which are necessarily incurred in deriving income is generally tax deductible. However, one has to remember, of course, that interest receipts are taxable and that source of revenue already goes some way to making up the short fall. In short, the business of buying and selling, unencumbered by governments, and of businesses being able to determine where, when and how, they will operate on their own, has been a feature of our country since European settlement. No case has been put forward that this situation has changed. On those grounds Senator Siddons's motion should be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of urgency that was brought forward today by the Australian Democrats. I think we would agree that what has been brought forward was predictable in terms of timing and content. The performance of the Australian Democrats is predictable in regard to timing because today is the day on which the Bell Group has lodged its draft part-A takeover document with the Victorian office of the National Companies and Securities Commission. At the time I entered this chamber both the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the Bell Group were not talking about the fine print in that document. That document has been lodged. It is assumed that there will be some changes to the earlier statements that had been made by Mr Holmes a Court. As late as today some of the economic writers have predicted that the document will contain an offer to all shareholders proportionally and that that, of course, will be for a set percentage of the shareholders' holdings.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of points have been made by various speakers, including the Australian Democrats who introduced the motion. The Democrats have asked us to support the four points that are contained in their motion. However, I support the amendment moved by Senator Durack on behalf of the Opposition in which we have pointed to the need for a government to keep the laws relating to takeovers under constant review. We think this is the course that should be followed and that we should not adopt the prescribed way in which the Australian Democrats would deal with this matter. It is always timely to ask whether the broad range of policies of government encourage or inhibit any number of things in the commercial sector. I think governments need to address the question of whether their policies encourage takeovers which may not be in the interests of a number of different groups. It is also always a matter for government to look at whether its taxation policies encourage, inhibit or promote the efficiency and the economic return on capital invested at risk by those who are in commercial enterprise. We need to look at tax policies with regard to capital gains, investment allowances, negative gearing of interest, which has been the subject of some comment today, and company profits. We need to consider whether those policies have an effect on the commercial and trading sectors.

I think we could address some attention to the four points raised by Senator Siddons. The first point made by Senator Siddons related to interest charges. Senator Siddons said that the Government should legislate to prevent interest charges being deductible other than on capital that had been used to produce income. I think that might be one way of looking at dealing with tax. However, it certainly has not been the way in which government policies have been moving. Indeed, government policies have moved in almost the opposite direction inasmuch as one is able to look at taxation as a whole in respect of a group of companies. However, it is moving entirely in the opposite direction if we segregate interest charges on one company or one part of a company and allow deductibility in respect of some isolated capital. Senator Siddons seemed to justify this view by publicly acknowledging that he could not convince the Government to change its taxation measures in regard to negative gearing on the capital requirements of primary producers. That point of view can be taken if one is looking for support from a certain sector of people. The Australian Democrats are standing up for the primary producers but in doing so they are stopping someone else from getting something that they were not able to get for them. I hardly think that this is good policy. It is not the way in which good policy ought to be made.

Senator Siddons's second point was that pro rata bids should be banned or brought forward only as proportional bids. Legislation has been foreshadowed. Like other senators, I am not aware of the fine detail of that legislation which has come forward from the ministerial council. I agree that it would be appropriate that we should deal with that legislation as soon as possible. We should see what has been decided by the ministerial council and the effect that that might have on capital formation in this country. We will have to consider whether we will deal with that legislation when it comes before the Parliament. However, it seems to me that the matter that is now before us is not urgent because of the fact that legislation has been foreshadowed. In fact it means that the matter before us is in hand. The matter before us relates to what will happen on a particular day-that is the day on which the part-A takeover document has been lodged.

The third point made by Senator Siddons was that there should be some exchange control reintroduced. In that context, he mentioned such things as variable deposit ratios. We have moved to a deregulation of the financial system. We have also looked at foreign investment. However, it seems to me that we are moving in the opposite direction from the way in which our economy is heading when we talk about exchange control reintroduction and the disadvantage of variable deposit ratios. I certainly could not give my support to that aspect of the four points put forward by the Australian Democrats. I could not support the way in which this matter has been brought forward or the reasons that have been given for it.

The fourth point, of course, is the other predictable proposal that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) should, in the public interest, initiate some inquiry into massive takeovers. A subjective judgment can be made of almost every word in that part of the Democrats' motion-for example, which is massive and which is not and what is in the public interest. The Democrats talk about the way in which the trade practices legislation can deal with this matter. All kinds of things such as the National Companies and Securities Commission and the ministerial council have already been structured. To set up another inquiry to which people will still talk and talk and which will not deal with the matters that ought to be dealt with again seems to me to be just a very predictable way in which the Australian Democrats would want to deal with this matter. One needs only to look at today's Press to see the variety of things that happen in our corporate structure. There has been a dominance today of Holmes a Court's next move in the battle with Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, with various commentators asking whether there will be some surprises by the Bell company, and so on. It is rather like a national sport to see who is going to win and who is going to lose. In an article in today's Australian relating to this matter, Bryan Frith comments:
It is suggested, however, that the bid will be conditional on Bell obtaining at least 35 per cent of BHP's voting capital . . .
It was also mentioned that Holmes a Court had been assured of resources from an undisclosed trading bank. On page 1 of today's Australian it was stated:
An undisclosed trading bank agreed to advance Bell a credit facility of more than $2 billion for the offer.

It says `an undisclosed trading bank'. I do not know whether it is an overseas bank, a foreign bank trading in Australia, or an Australian bank. That, I suppose, may be known by some, but it is certainly not known by me. When we look at the way in which we have introduced foreign banks into Australia and widened the facilities, resources and accessibility of capital to Australians by that means, to talk of foreign exchange regulations again seems to me to be walking backwards. Someone mentioned Elders-IXL; naturally one would in this context because of its size. Today, there is a report of its forecast of the half-year profit which is to be announced later this week. I found interesting, particularly in this context, the following comment:
The take-over of CUB in early 1984 left Elders with a huge debt load but the company managed a huge reduction in its debt by its 1984-85 balance date through a major asset divestment program.

There are those who have been commending Elders today for the restructuring of its corporate arrangements and for the fact that, when it did take over the Carlton and United Breweries, it had a huge debt but has managed, through an asset divestment program, to move now towards what is regarded as a satisfactory profit to be announced later this week. According to an analyst, as a consequence of this sharply reduced debt, Elders, after divesting itself of some of its assets, would benefit from lower funding charges and enjoy improved earnings growth in 1985-86. We will wait to see what the result of that is later this week. Is anyone to suggest that a corporation or a large structured company in this country should not arrange its affairs-call it divestment of assets or whatever-after it has used the risk capital of its shareholders and when the responsibility of its directors is on the line? Is anyone to suggest that we should be regulating more than we have in respect of those sorts of risks? I think we ought to address ourselves to some of the other economic problems and indicators. When we see the headlines such as `Survey indicates tapering off in business activity' in today's Press and we see that in the most recent survey the number of respondents expecting a decline in capital expenditure rose from 15 to 37 per cent, we start to wonder why it is that government would think that it ought to be regulating and ought to be introducing more difficulties for a corporate sector that is already struggling against high interest rates, uncompetitiveness and other problems. When one looks at whatever area of business one wishes, one finds that there are the take-overs and the restructurings of companies that there always have been in the past, and one needs to look at tax policy to see what inhibition or encouragement it may have with regard to changes. Under the headline `Roxby to embark on on-market raid of CMI' in today's Australian Financial Review one finds this in the concluding comment:

The insurance company has hinted that the sale of its CMI holding would be convenient as the tax changes foreshadowed last year made it less efficient to hold shares through a separate corporate entity.

That is where government comes into these matters-tax policy. I am not passing a judgment on this particular tax change, but when a company can say that the tax changes foreshadowed last year made it less efficient to hold shares through a separate corporate entity, it is no wonder that we find take-overs in whatever sector is affected by government policies through taxation, general economic policies or anything else of that kind.

Another article of interest in today's Press is headed: `Experts to iron out tax imputation plan'. Many people naturally felt that the recent tax imputation changes were to their advantage. We then find that in the meeting to be held in Canberra on Thursday matters to be looked at include the abandonment or referral of imputation which would hammer share markets where the promise of tax free dividends had underpinned prices for months. They are the sorts of things in respect of which government policy makes the difference or otherwise. Someone referred in passing to some of our instrumentalities. Of course, we have the Australian Gas Light Co. situation and the interest of Industrial Equity Ltd in that matter. To suggest that simply because today is the day on which BHP and Bell have the first round of their take-over arrangements, we ought to suddenly rush into a flush of government regulation and legislation to deal with this matter with yet another committee to be set up to investigate, report, delay and do all the other things that committees do seems to me to be no reason at all to support the motion that was moved by the Australian Democrats; and I, in these comments, reject that motion and support what has been moved by Senator Durack on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my friend and colleague Senator John Siddons in the matter of urgency that he has raised today. He has paid a service to this country by simply asking-this is what the Australian Democrats are simply saying today-why we do not become concerned at the spate of, and nature of, the take-overs that are taking place in this country. After having had a look at them and the way in which they have been implemented, we want the Government and the Opposition to look objectively at whether this is good for the country. That is all we are doing. At no stage in his speech did Senator Siddons say that the Democrats are opposed to all take-overs. Yet he has been blackguarded for saying that by speakers from the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia. He never said anything of the kind. Indeed, he said the opposite. He said that a company that is badly and inefficiently run deserves to be taken over. He is saying: `Let us weigh up the new circumstances and ask ourselves whether that is good for Australia'. For this trouble he has been misrepresented. Innuendos have been put in his way by both sides of the chamber. In fact, today Senator Siddons has achieved a mini-political miracle. He has merged the Labor Party and the Liberal Party. I defy anyone listening to this debate to identify which party the two Liberal and two Labor speakers in this debate belong to. One would have thought that the same speechwriter had written all the speeches. It is a total merger of the Labor Party and the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the thread running through the Labor and Liberal speeches today like the thread of Ariadne? It is: `Let us support big business. Let us give the take-over merchants a free hand, carte blanche. To hell with the workers; to hell with the littler shareholders-no regulation. How dare the Democrats say that we must curb people like Alan Bond? We must curb people like Robert Holmes a Court if they are acting against the interests of Australians'. That is what the Labor Party and the Liberal Party are not prepared to say today. All we are saying is: `Let us have a closer look at it'. I could not believe my ears when I heard speeches from the Labor Party today. The Liberal Party at least is honest. It says: `We champion big business; we are for big business; God bless big business; we will give you every encouragement'. I would have thought that the Labor Party should, at least at some stage, give some thought to the workers in big business, to the people who are small investors, but we have not heard one word about it, except in innuendo and snide remarks about the Democrats.

What was the terrible thing that Senator Siddons did? This is what he did: With the unanimous support of the seven Democrat senators and on behalf of the Democrats, he said that there was a necessity for the Government to take immediate action to prevent company take-overs which, firstly, add nothing to Australia's economic efficiency or growth. I might say that the Liberals have moved an amendment which totally destroys everything that Senator Siddons has moved today. Guess by whom they will be supported in this chamber. Every member of the Labor Party is going to support the Liberal Party in the division that is about to come up.

Senator Siddons's motion states that the Government should take immediate action to prevent company take-overs which add nothing to Australia's economic efficiency or growth. Apparently the Labor Party and the Liberal Party believe that take-overs which do add nothing to Australia's economic efficiency or growth should be allowed to take place. That can be read as nothing else. In other words, they support take-overs which add nothing to efficiency or growth.

The second part of Senator Siddons's motion states that the Government should take immediate action to prevent company take-overs which increase Australia's overseas indebtedness. According to the Liberal Party, and the Labor Party, that is another bad thing because they are going to strike it out of the motion. Am I not right in saying that Australia's present overseas debt is the highest in our history and is growing at a massive rate while our exports are falling and the dollar is falling? There are people who are now comparing our overseas indebtedness with that of Argentina and places such as that. The Labor Party is going to say: `No, we will strike that out'.

The third part of Senator Siddons's motion states that the Government should take immediate action to prevent company take-overs which are used to deny massive revenue to the Government. Apparently that is a bad thing. Apparently this chamber should support take-overs which allow people to avoid paying tax so that the workers, the ordinary salary earner, can pay more. That is going to be substituted for Senator Siddons's motion by the collusion of the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. They are going to vote together on this. Unashamedly they are going to vote to replace Senator Siddons's motion, which has teeth, with this motherhood amendment:
The need for the Government to keep the laws relating to takeovers under constant review-

That is an earth shaking amendment. The Liberal Party and the Labor Party are going to keep the laws relating to take-overs under constant review while our overseas debt sky-rockets through take-overs, as I have described. The amendment gets better. It goes on:
to ensure that they are fair to shareholders and operate in the public interest.

What a sham! What a farce it is for all members of this chamber, except the Democrats, to be colluding in voting for that. I wish to add to this debate the contribution of an economist and journalist who, I think, is held in the highest respect in this country. I refer to Kenneth Davidson of the Age. He wrote this biting critique of the Government's policies:
The Government's naturally conservative instinct-

Honourable senators on the Labor side are now being identified as having naturally conservative instinct. They are conservatives. There is to be a united vote from the conservatives in this Parliament, Labor and Liberal. The article continued:
to do nothing to change the status quo fits nicely with its prediction to help only those who help the Government.
I do not know exactly what Kenneth Davidson means by that. One suspects that Mr Holmes a Court helps the Government so the Government helps him. The article continued:
And in general it must be asked whether the whole take-over game, which has accelerated to fever pitch in the past year, has strengthened capitalism or improved equality.
Anyone who votes against the Democrats' motion on this occasion must believe that the take-over game has improved equality in this country. Davidson went on:
The game, after all, is based on replacing equity capital with borrowed capital to transfer the tax burden from the owners of corporations to their workers.

I would have thought that that would be a shameful thing for a Labor government to do. Let me give an example. Let us assume that there is a very wealthy Western Australian who wants to buy a brewery and that the going price for it is $100m. Let us assume also that he goes overseas and borrows money at 9 per cent, which is easy to do. You or I, Mr Acting Deputy President, cannot borrow money at 9 per cent but these wealthy take-over people can do it without any problem. He comes back to Australia and buys out the brewery for $100m at 9 per cent, which means that his interest bill is $9m a year. Let us assume, in this hypothetical example, that the profits of that brewery were, $9m a year. He has added nothing to improve the efficiency of that brewery but he can write off the $9m interest bill against the $9m profit. How much tax would that brewery be paying then? Absolutely none. The tax has to be made up from somewhere else. Who makes up the tax? It is made up by the ordinary workers, the ordinary salary and wage earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the money goes out of the country.

—I am about to come to that. That is not the end of it. Australia's overseas debt is increased by $100m because of that loan, increasing the responsibility of exporters. People on this side of the House are always saying: `Why don't we help the exporters'? God knows they have enough load to carry now with falling prices and whatever. We are putting this additional responsibility on them to pay for this increased debt that is being made possible by the take-over people of this country. Davidson went on:

SPEECH.PARA: To whom should the greatest rewards go? To those who can exploit gaps in the regulatory environment to avoid taxes or to those who contribute to a new or better service, product or process?
A society which reserves its greatest rewards for essentially unproductive activities threatens, first, its prosperity and, ultimately, its survival.
Those are strong words by Kenneth Davidson. I support them. The Democrats believe them to be true. Finally, Davidson said something which Senator Siddons and the Democrats are putting today:

Alternatively, this take-over, and a lot more like it, could be stopped if the Treasurer issued a simple statement to the effect that, as from today, the interest cost of borrowing for share purchases can be offset only against the income from those shares.

He was talking about the Bell group's bid for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. This is negative gearing. All he is doing is saying to the Government: `You have stopped negative gearing with property and for primary producers, who are going broke. Why give the take-over people, the millionaires, the big businesses, carte-blanche in this area of negative gearing? Why don't you be consistent?' I do not have the answer to the question why a Labor government would allow that to continue. I shall read from another article by Kenneth Davidson of 12 February. Once again, he is talking about the BHP take-over. He said:

Once again, the farce of a comparatively small, highly geared company attempting to take over a much larger company, in this case Australia's largest company, with money supplied from overseas must call into question present tax rules which encourage this situation.

The farce could be stopped dead if the Government simply announced that, from now on, companies, like individuals can no longer negatively gear their interest payments so that the losses of one company can be offset against the profits of another.

The most sensible way for Mr Holmes a Court to ease his cash flow problems if he got control of BHP would be to transfer the interest burden to BHP, which would mean to all shareholders in BHP and to all taxpayers.
We have even got Maximilian Walsh saying:
And if he-
that is, Mr Holmes a Court-
is successful he should send John Howard and Paul Keating a special thank you note because it is they who made it all possible.

But I find it grossly unfair that a government can legislate, as this one has done, to outlaw negative gearing in residential and rural industries but allow it, indeed encourage it, in the corporate sector.

I do not know a responsible economist or journalist who is not condemning this practice. Yet in this Parliament all members of the Australian Labor Party and all members of the Liberal Party are voting to continue it. We are now faced with this sham, this colluded solution to get the Liberal and Labor parties off the hook in this chamber, to destroy Senator Siddons's matter of urgency-which would have taken action to protect our overseas debt, to improve our efficiency and to retain taxation availability to the Government which is now being avoided by these people-and to replace it with a feather. Therefore, the Democrats will vote unanimously against this attempt by the Labor and Liberal parties to sweep this massive problem under the carpet.

I conclude by asking a rhetorical question. I can understand members of the Liberal Party championing people like Alan Bond and Robert Holmes a Court. They should be championed; they are great Australians. I can understand that attitude. The Liberals are out in the open, they are honest and they say that they support big business, although they have never shown too much compassion for the ordinary little shareholder or the worker. But it is beyond my comprehension how members of the Labor Party can support such people to the disadvantage of the people whom they allegedly represent-the workers and the salary earners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise reluctantly to speak in this debate because of a certain hypocrisy that I see in the camp of the Australian Democrats. While they seek to condemn big business in take-over roles, Senator Siddons's own company has been a vehicle for acquiring a number of small businesses. While he is quite honest in saying that he has never acquired a publicly listed company and while he is being quite correct-indeed pedantic-I believe that these things are very much in the eye of the beholder. Whether a take-over merchant is named John Siddons-or his company name-or John Elliott or Robert Holmes a Court, there is no difference in attitude. They all believe they are improving the efficiency of the takeover target. The Democrats say that it is not in the national interest if a big company is involved in the take-over, but it could well be in the national interest if Siddons acquires a small business. SPEECH.PARA: I rise because of the comments made by Senator Chipp about `filthy remarks'. I seek to present the facts. I agree with some of the sentiments expressed in this matter of urgency, especially the comments about the use of taxation havens and so on. But that is not stated in the terms of the matter of urgency which says:
The necessity for the Government to take immediate action to prevent company takeovers . . .

The motion does not distinguish between public and private companies, nor does it distinguish between large and small companies and I would submit that many small take-overs involving small companies are just as much against the public or national interest as are some of the larger ones which receive national acclaim.

Therefore I raised a point of order because I believe that an honourable senator in this place who has an interest in the matter before the Senate should declare that interest. It is not obligatory, but it is understood that there is a moral obligation for an honourable senator to declare his interest. On previous occasions Senator Siddons has been good enough to indicate his interest. On this particular occasion he chose not to disclose his interest. True, he did not have to do so, but as he takes such a high moral stand I believe he should have disclosed his interest. It is true that the matter was of a general character and it was not specific to a particular take-over, but during his address Senator Siddons chose to be specific. He named a number of individuals carte blanche and one gathers the impression that all those take-overs associated with those particular persons were not in the national interest. It is quite true that some of them may have been in the national interest--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Siddons

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order Mr Acting Deputy President. I believe that I am being completely misrepresented. I have never at any stage said that I was concerned about take-overs per se. The motion reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . takeovers which add nothing to Australia's economic efficiency or growth . . .

—Had Senator Siddons wished to do so he could have used his extensive expertise as chairman of a publicly listed company to good effect in this debate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate at a late stage because as the general tenor of the debate in this chamber has somewhat degenerated-there is some hypocrisy and paranoia around-I think it would be useful if the Senate were to think of what it could most constructively do in the area Senator Siddons has raised for our consideration. There is much to be said for an examination by this chamber and the House of Representatives-indeed, by the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia as a whole because we are elected representatives of the people-of the whole question of the role of takeovers in relation to the great corporations which prowl around seeking whom they may to devour. There is no doubt about it that this phenomenon which has gathered pace over the past several years is quite startling in its magnitude and something about which most people with whom I have had contact out in the community-have grave misgivings.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that in the old days the classic corporate theory had it that in order for shareholders really to discipline a corporation it was enough that they were able to elect and re-elect the directors at periodic intervals. That was the way in which some sort of discipline and accountability was brought home to bear in relation to the running of the company. However, of course the stock-market and the current price of securities now conveys to the board of directors and management of those companies much more immediately and much more continuously the fact that they are under scrutiny and are under pressure. Added to that change, as I say from the classic theory of corporate accountability which merely had to do with the election and re-election of directors, one of course has the fact now in relation to these very large companies that there are huge institutional investors-I am speaking for example of the great insurance companies and superannuation and pension funds-which do not necessarily have any great loyalty to the company concerned but are merely interested in getting a return for those to whom they in turn are accountable and responsible and to whom they have given undertakings as to putting the funds entrusted to them to profitable use.

The fact is that the costs to the community of this sort of activity are quite properly drawn to the attention of the Senate by Senator Siddons. There is a lessening of competition no doubt as a result of many takeovers. It would be very naive not to be able to perceive the tendency of monopoly or at least the tendency for just a few large companies dominating whole areas of our commercial and trading life in Australia. In that situation small business must suffer. Also the fact is that it is inevitable that there be misgivings on the part of employees. What guarantee can there be and what certainty and assurance can they have that in the amalgamations and break up of the company that is acquired quite often in order that its assets may be separately sold off according to the individual value of that sector of a very large firm. That is they will not suffer in that rationalisation? A very logical and managerial type of noun which covers, I believe, a multitude of difficulties and suffering on the part of the employees and even the community in the disappearance of the very important ties that, for example, a local community might have with a particular sector of a large firm.

These sorts of things are not too often taken into account when one simply is talking about the operations of the stock-market. But I believe the weakness of Senator Siddons's proposal before the chamber today lies in the fact that it calls on the Government to take immediate action. It seems to me that it is difficult to accept this in several senses of the use of the term `the Government to take immediate action'. Firstly, as Senator Richardson I think pointed out: Who actually is to decide what is in the public interest? Who is to take the task of balancing the particular issues that are at stake? Who is to decide on the question of economic efficiency for the whole community as opposed to the returns to shareholders, including as I say pensioners who have committed their funds or superannuation moneys which have been committed to large institutional investors? The question there must be who is to decide this question of public interest.

Actually I want to go a step further and say that it is not merely a question of who should make the decision in relation to these matters outside the operations of the stock market with its disciplines. However, I wonder whether Senator Siddons in speaking of the Government in these matters really is bypassing the Parliament. The Parliament seems to me to have a very real role in relation to these matters. It is a role completely and utterly ignored and submerged in the past several years by the existence of the very powerful Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities and the National Companies and Securities Commission. Of course, what we have about to assault this chamber, which is supposed to be a legislative and deliberative chamber, in a few days time is a Bill agreed on by a Council of Ministers, both Federal and State, which this chamber cannot refuse to pass. Indeed, when the Parliament passes that piece of legislation into law none of the other six State parliaments have to do anything about it. It automatically becomes part of their statute books.

It is my view that this chamber ought to be taking some steps to reassert the role of Parliament in relation to companies and securities laws in this nation. For that reason I think it may be of interest to honourable senators to have some foreshadowing of the fact that their various party rooms will be approached in the next few days. I have had discussions with my Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs with a view to obtaining a reference from the Senate, if the Senate is so minded, on the whole question of the role of the Parliament in relation to the Ministerial Council, the National Companies and Securities Commission and the role of the Parliament in relation to the effective operation of companies and securities law throughout Australia. I believe that that would be a useful step. I think it is a step which would enable us to have better debate, although I think Senator Siddons was quite right to raise the misgivings he expressed in terms of the urgency motion.

At this stage I do not believe it would be useful for the Senate to take this matter to a vote. I think it would be much more useful for the Senate to adopt its usual procedure when a matter of high policy is at stake-it takes the matter away from the drama and the theatrical pit of confrontation, which is the chamber, and gives the matter on the whole to the Senate Committee where in a bipartisan way the six honourable senators can sit around the table and take extensive public evidence and try to present to the Parliament a report which may have a bipartisan basis of support.

I am speaking at this stage continually because, as I said, it is my belief that this matter should not be taken to a vote. I think the other procedures which are open to the Senate could be better utilised in order to get a resolution of the sorts of fears and misgivings which Senator Siddons speaks of. The fact is that the Parliament needs to reassert its role. There is nothing more demeaning or humiliating than to be elected to come to this place and then to find oneself merely rubber stamping decisions made by a ministerial council itself advised by officials whose names we do not even know.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying that Parliament should take more notice of these, yet you are denying the Parliament a vote by talking it out. Where is the logic?

—I am saying in this particular instance that while I agree with much of the principle of Senator Siddons's urgency motion I believe that the emphasis which he has placed on government action is perhaps misplaced and for the Senate itself it is more in keeping with the ethos of the Senate to look to the Parliament to remedy the situation. I have indicated to the Senate where that remedy might lie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a very important issue, of course, especially at this time of the year in Australia. Page 4 of the paper mentions Project Aquarius which was a project run by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to evaluate the usefulness of water bombing-dropping water out of aircraft onto bushfires. This procedure is used widely around the world, in Canada, America and Mediterranean countries, and it has proven to be very useful. Unfortunately, the Australian State governments and the Federal Government wanted to reinvent the wheel, so they undertook a study to see whether it would work here, and it did. But the report is somewhat ambivalent. It says: `Yes, the use of aircraft can be beneficial to put out bushfires'. But in general it thought that its use would be limited.

The CSIRO's figures are quite interesting. It pointed out that the use of a DC6 would have saved $660,000 in costs-it does not define how-and would have cost $524,000. That is a benefit and a saving. The study found that the long term total cost of bushfires in Victoria alone was about $25m a year, so a major saving is possible in this regard. One aircraft that was evaluated which is not found in Australia-the Canadians offered to bring the aircraft here but the Australian Government refused the offer-was the Canadair CL215, a seaplane which has the capability of flying over a body of water and scooping up water without stopping. At flying speeds it can pick up six tonnes of water and dump it on a fire. These aircraft are used all over the world. I think it is obvious that the various State governments will not really face up to their responsibilities in regard to bushfires.

I propose that six of the Canadair CL215s be purchased by the Australian Government, to be based in Canberra. The total cost of purchasing the aircraft would be about $30m. But when one considers, as I mentioned, that bushfires cause the loss of $25m a year in Victoria alone, this investment would pay for itself. The Canadair CL215 has one big advantage over the other aircraft evaluated by the CSIRO; that is, its multipurpose role. It can be used not only to put out fires by dumping six tonnes of water on each flight, but also for search and rescue missions. This fact was not evaluated by the CSIRO. It is expensive to have a single purpose aircraft on the ground, waiting to be used to fight a bushfire. But this aircraft can be used for search and rescue missions. The CL215 has a 13.5-hour endurance. It can be used to avoid tragedies such as occurred in Bass Strait when a land aircraft circled a drowning pilot, but finally had to leave the scene, and the pilot ultimately died. A seaplane such as the Canadair CL215 could have landed and picked him up. It can land in two-metre high waves. It can also play a role in fishery surveillance and anti-smuggling patrols. It can carry 26 passengers. It can be used all year round.

The use of water bombers is quite widespread. I have observed them on the west coast of the United States. I have observed them being used to save homes and the lives of firefighters. Obviously, this method would not put out a massive bushfire on a front of 60 miles, but one could fly out at the first sign of smoke and start dumping six-tonne loads of water on it, thus controlling the fire before it becomes a 60-mile wide conflagration. I urge that my suggestion not go unheeded. The $30m total cost of the six aircraft is a small fraction of the property damage caused by bushfires in recent years. Many lives and valuable forest land could be saved if the Federal Government adopted these water bombing techniques which have been proven to be effective all over the world. It is high time that we gave our fire fighters the kind of modern technical backup provided by aerial water bombers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This paper is actually a government response to two reports-the report of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation entitled `Bushfires and the Australian Environment' and the report of the Australian Forestry Council's Standing Committee on Forestry on the 1982-83 bushfires. Most of the normal bushfire fighting in Australia is done on a State basis and mainly by volunteers in the rural bushfire brigades. They do a tremendous job. But every so often, because of circumstances which are peculiar to an area, a particular set of conditions will occur which means that a fire will be far more horrendous than any that has occurred until that point of time. It could be brought about by the weather, such as a succession of very hot, dry days beforehand. Something could start it off and away it will go. On a normal day there probably would not even be enough fuel to enable the fire to burn to such an intensity. But because of the conditions that exist it may far exceed the capability of any local rural fire brigade to handle it. We have seen tragic loss of life and property because of such bushfires.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is significant that there are many people who do not understand that on certain days almost anything will start a fire. In Victoria and South Australia high winds have caused power lines to touch and make sparks which set off bushfires. We know that during dry storms, or heat storms, lightning strikes will set them off. A farmer might be repairing a piece of machinery and a spark from a welder will set off a fire. It is not only people on the land who should be aware of these situations; people everywhere should be made aware of the fact that these conditions apply at certain times of the year and in certain places and that only a spark is needed to set off a major conflagration.

I support Senator Sanders in his call for the use of the CL215 in Australia. One thing that has disturbed most of us for a long time is the reluctance of Australian authorities to do more in regard to the water bombing techniques that are used overseas by the use of aircraft such as the CL215, the C130, the DC6 or whatever. Fortunately, at long last experiments have been carried out. But not nearly enough, to my mind, has been done, when one knows full well the conditions that obtain in Australia. I understand that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has a further report to prepare and more research to do to take into account all the data it has received from the experiments which were conducted when the DC6 came into Australia.

Australians have been air-minded over the decades and, having the massive bushfire problem that we have, one would have thought that the two would have come together with results long before they have. Unfortunately, that has not happened. Significantly, in the two reports there were 48 recommendations. The Government has accepted 23; it has not accepted one; it has noted 17; and seven have been with comments. One comment was that Defence Force personnel whose base is in bushfire-prone areas are, as a matter of priority, trained mainly in defence. This is a matter that we should bear in mind because our Defence Force is a resource which can be tapped immediately and quickly. Significantly, the recommendation that has not been accepted referred to funding for the CSIRO to do further work. That should be looked at a little bit more closely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1982-83 bushfires are now part of history. History gives perspective to events, placing them in order of their significance to the life of a particular group, a particular community, a particular nation or the world generally. Consciousness of history is crucial to the quality of any of these entities. Bushfires have been an elemental force in Australian life. Much of our literature expresses the truth of this and it comes out strongly in Henry Lawson's works, for example.

SPEECH.PARA: The image of the 1982-83 bushfires which has been left most vividly in my mind is the scene it produced along the southern coast of Victoria. I have enjoyed the beauty of that area and, in particular, the beauty of Anglesea. In my view it is unsurpassed anywhere. The change the fire brought to the green covering of the land, making it into a forest of blackened stakes sprouting from a carpet of grey and white ash, was awesome. During the fires farms were reduced, homes were lost and, most tragically, life was forfeited.

It is difficult for history to reproduce the drama, the emotion and the immediacy of the human reactions which rear up when the bush is ablaze. Their force abates with time. Investigations into and analyses of the fires tend to discount the emotional profile of their advent. The response of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) is the result of investigations and analyses of the fires taken over time. The report contains recommendations which are crucial to the occurrence and control of future fires. We should act on these recommendations. It would be well if the dramatic experiences which people have as they face the approach of fire become less and less a feature of our history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bushfires are a hot issue, but only when they are burning. At this time of the year bushfires are a menace around the nation and we now pay the price of our inaction during the rest of the year. I highly commend the recommendations of the original report to which the Government is responding. However, I must criticise the Commonwealth Government for its attitude on this matter. The Government says that `the prime carriage rests with the States' and, therefore, the Commonwealth is under no obligation to develop a national body for fighting bushfires. It says there is no obligation to require the armed services to undertake fire-fighting as part of our national defence or even as part of their training. There is an urgent need for us to support a co-ordination at the national level relating to national disasters.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to canvass particularly the view that we need a national grid to describe the advance of a fire. It can be used to describe uniquely and accurately the location and motion of a fire so that it is possible to speed up the initial measures to control it and get help immediately into the right area. The project entailed an exploration of the causes of spouse abuse; interpretations of why men are violent; why women stay in violent relationships; and the overall extent of the problem in Australia as compared with America. The research project took on an interviewing process after the violent men were identified and had volunteered to participate in the project. There was no requirement on these men to participate; it was, importantly, a voluntary participation. A number of the spouses of these violent men participated also. In the study were 40 men and 31 women. The study gives a profile of the 40 men and some of their characteristics as violent spouses.
