DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL REFORM

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Representation in the Commonwealth Parliament

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present Report No. 1 of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform entitled `Determining the Entitlement of Federal Territories and New States to Representation in the Commonwealth Parliament', together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report that I have just tabled is the first report from the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform appointed for this Parliament. It discharges that part of the Committee's order of reference requiring it to inquire into and report on the establishment of fixed formulae for determining the number of senators and members of the House of Representatives to which the Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory and other Territories are entitled.

The Committee in the previous Parliament commenced this inquiry after the Hon. I. B. C. Wilson, MP, had moved amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1983. His amendments sought to insert fixed formulae in the Commonwealth Electoral Act to determine the entitlement to representation of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory in the Senate and the House. This reflected his concern and that of others on the implications of section 122 of the Constitution which provides in part that `the Parliament may allow the representation of a Territory in either House of the Parliament to the extent and on the terms which it thinks fit'. Earlier, the first Committee on Electoral Reform in its first report had noted `the potential peril, however remote the implementation may be of a Government commanding a majority in both Houses exploiting section 122 by legislating to increase Territory representation in either House to advance its own political ends'.

Mr Wilson had also sponsored a resolution at the Australian Constitutional Convention the effect of which, if adopted by the people in a referendum, would have been to amend the Constitution to insert fixed formulae. As an interim measure, pending the Constitutional change that he sought, Mr Wilson proposed that the concept be given effect by the Parliament in the form of provisions in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. It is these matters which are addressed in the report that I have just tabled. The report considers the three matters mentioned above, namely, amendment of the Electoral Act to provide formulae to determine the entitlement of Federal Territories to representation in both Houses; the outlook for, and desirability of, constitutional amendment to achieve the same end; and the implications for representation of the admission of new States to the Commonwealth. The report also considers the implications for Territory representation of proposals considered by the Constitutional Convention to break the nexus between the size of the House of Representatives and the Senate.

The Committee has concluded that the entitlement to representation in the Commonwealth Parliament of Federal Territories should be prescribed and not subject to alteration by the Parliament `as it sees fit'. Formulae to achieve this should ultimately be included in the Constitution. Initially the formulae should be enacted as provisions of the Electoral Act. The Committee also concludes that the entitlement of new States to representation in the Senate and the House of Representatives should be prescribed in the Constitution. For a variety of reasons we conclude that it would be premature to submit a proposal to the people concerning the representation of new States and Territories. Further clarification of the issues is needed before an acceptable proposal for change can be formulated.

As an interim step, however, the Commonwealth Electoral Act should be amended to give the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory an entitlement to representation in both chambers. Currently any increase or for that matter decrease in entitlement would require a separate amendment to the Electoral Act. Under the Committee's proposal entitlement to representation would be determined automatically by the Electoral Commission when it is conducting its triennial distribution of seats. Other Federal Territories, under our proposal, could become entitled to representation provided that the population of that Territory exceeds more than one-half of a constitutional quota for the election of a State member to the House of Representatives. This would give rise to an entitlement of one member in the House. Until an entitlement to separate representation vests, arrangements should continue to be made to include the people of other Commonwealth Territories in electoral divisions of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. Broadly this would mean that the Territories would obtain an entitlement in accordance with their population on similar principles to those applicable to other States. Under our proposal representation in the Senate would also be related to population. The entitlement would be on the basis of one senator for every two members of the House returned from the Territory with a guarantee that the Northern Territory and Australian Capital Territory would retain at least their existing entitlement. This would mean that the Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory would each become entitled to three senators upon becoming entitled to return six members to the House.

The report also discusses the representation of new States in the Parliament. The majority of the Committee believe that when the Constitution is amended to provide for the entitlement to representation of Federal Territories the same principles should also be made applicable to the representation of any new State that might be established or admitted. The Constitution deals with this matter in sections 121, 123 and 124 respectively. Section 121 provides that upon such admission or establishment the Parliament may make or impose such terms and conditions, including the extent of representation in either House of the Parliament as it sees fit. It is clear from the Convention debates that the founders considered that new States should be admitted to the Federation only on conditions acceptable to the Commonwealth, that is to say, the original States. In summing up the effect of the provision, Quick and Garran state:

Under the Constitution of the Commonwealth the Federal Parliament has a free hand in deciding the terms and conditions under which a new Member may be admitted into the Federal family system. It will be at liberty to impose such stipulations as it thinks fit, unhampered by considerations of equality of original States.

It would appear to the majority of the Committee that the Constitution ought to contain some limit on the ability of a Commonwealth government to grant statehood. Its `free hand' in this respect should be restrained on the same principles as its free hand on Territory representation is to be restrained. Senator Macklin has dissented on this aspect of the Committee's report. I may comment on that in a later debate.

Our proposals for amendments to the Electoral Act are an interim step. In amending the Electoral Act to make provision for the entitlement of the Territories to be determined automatically the Parliament would be relying on the power under section 122. Amendment to the Electoral Act would, of course, not affect the constitutional power itself, and it would still be theoretically possible for an ill-disposed government with control of both chambers to legislate to stack the Parliament. Amendment of the Constitution alone would prevent this possibility. But, if the support of the Parliament can be obtained for the Committee's proposals a significant obstacle will be placed in the way of a government seeking to exploit the Territories' power for electoral advantage. A government seeking to change the process, once these provisions are enacted, would need the support of both Houses. It is some years since a government has been able to rely on Senate support for all its legislative proposals. The deadlock, double dissolution and joint sitting provisions of the Constitution provide additional obstacles that would need to be cleared before such a program could be implemented. If, as we believe, the formulae we propose provide an equitable basis for the representation of the people of the Territories for the foreseeable future, the task of some future government in persuading the Parliament and the people that these arrangements are defective would in itself constitute an obstacle to such a government seeking to replace the provisions with self-interested proposals of its own.

In conclusion I would like to thank all the members of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform for the work they have put into this report. Particularly, I would like to pay tribute to Mr Donald Nairn who is Secretary to the Committee and who had a very large input in helping us produce this report.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be opposing these Bills and will be voting against them at every opportunity, and in that I will have the support of all my Liberal Party and National Party colleagues. We are opposing these Bills for various reasons. I want to make clear to the Senate this afternoon the two broad groups of reasons why these Bills are unacceptable to me. In the first place, I do not believe that the rights of citizens in Australia can be protected simply by passing a Bill of Rights. I do not believe we can legislate for those sorts of things. I ask the Government to show me where those rights are at risk. Where is the demand that this legislation be introduced? The second ground on which I oppose this legislation is the fact that the Bill itself is so badly drafted. It is so badly drafted that it does nothing at all to preserve the rights of Australians. In fact, it threatens those rights that we have enjoyed for generations since Federation. Even someone who supports the introduction of a Bill of rights for Australians could not support this one if he or she read the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that we can legislate for rights in Australia, and in that I share the view of the present Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs. In a recent speech he said:
If society is rational and tolerant it does not need a Bill of Rights. If it is not no Bill of Rights will protect it.

I agree with those sentiments completely. We are a free and open country, and the rights and freedoms that we have come from two sources. At the Federal level we have a democratically elected Parliament which can be voted out of office, and which is voted out of office, when the public disapproves of what it is doing. The second great support we have is an independent judiciary which administers and interprets the laws made by the Parliament. Lord Wright, in a debate in 1942 in the House of Lords said:
But in the Constitution of this country-
he was talking of Britain-
there are no guaranteed or absolute rights. The safeguard of British liberty is in the good sense of the people and in the system of representative and responsible government which has evolved.

Those words can be applied to Australia. We are a free country. We enjoy more personal freedoms, I believe, than any other nation in the world. We are not a fragile society. We are not a newly emerged or newly created nation which has no traditions, no systems and no rule of law. We have all those things. We are the inheritors of a social and cultural system whose origins go back thousands of years.

We have made mistakes. We have evolved. We are still evolving new systems, and are adapting those to our needs. The system we have in place has protected since Federation the freedom of individual Australians. I have every confidence in the good sense of the Australian people, operating through freely elected governments and through an independent judiciary, to maintain those freedoms which we all cherish so much.

No mature Australian has come forward with a reasoned argument for this Bill. There are no people meeting in front of Parliament House, such as the farmers, turning up in their thousands, protesting about the need for a Bill of Rights. Have you seen them, Mr Acting Deputy President? I have never seen them. That is a very relevant question to ask. For many years now we have had intense propaganda on this matter from the Australian Labor Party. When former Senator Murphy was in this chamber he told us every day of our lives that we needed a Bill of Rights. We have had his accomplice, or his understudy, Senator Gareth Evans, telling us the same thing ever since he has been here. Yet there has never been a protest meeting on the steps of Parliament House of people saying: `Please give us a Bill of Rights'.

If one looks carefully and analytically at the legislation that is on the books in Australia one will see that the need for a Bill of Rights cannot be demonstrated. There is no deficiency in the legislative program in Australia which shows the need for it. Finally, there is no risk at all to the present system. No one has demonstrated that what we have in place will not continue into the future. Therefore, in a free society such as this, to legislate for a Bill of Rights is to put the Government in an unfavourable light. It looks as if the Government is trying to hide something. It makes the Government look as if it is wanting to reassure the Australian community as to the legitimacy of its actions. In effect, Mr Hawke and the Attorney-General are saying to the Australian people: `Look, we are not going to take away from you something that you hold dear'. Obviously the Executive of this Government feels that the legitimacy of its actions is viewed with concern by the Australian community and the Government has brought in a Bill of Rights to reassure the Australian community.

As a legislator I am opposed, on personal grounds, to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. However, I must say that I recognise that a Bill of Rights is probably inevitable in Australia. Most countries of the world-I am not talking only about the Western democracies here; I am talking about totalitarian regimes; that is, those of the Eastern European countries and the Soviet Union-have gone down the path of setting up a Bill of Rights in some form or other. So on those grounds alone I guess that we will get one in this country at some time. Irrespective of which party is in power, we have a regrettable tendency in Australia to follow what is done overseas. We tend to follow 10 or 15 years after it has been done. When the country that has made the move has recognised the errors of the introduction of that legislation and is climbing out of the trough on the other side, we embark on a legislative plan and do not learn from the mistakes of other countries. On those grounds, I guess that some sort of Bill of Rights is inevitable. But, if we are to have a Bill of Rights, for goodness sake let us have one that is effective and adequate to preserve the rights of Australia. That leads me to the second point. This Bill has been hopelessly drafted. It has been intentionally drafted in a hopeless way because the Bill threatens the rights of Australians where it ought to protect.

Let me turn to the contents of the Bill. I am not going to be encyclopaedic and dissect every clause. The Liberal Party and the National Party speakers have very adequately and very eloquently dealt with many of the points of this Bill. The assumption should not be made, that those points I have omitted are of lesser or of no importance to me. The points I want to raise seem to me to require a little more emphasis. I start with the beginning of the Bill. I refer to page 9 of the Bill, which deals with Division 2 and Division 3. Honourable senators will see that it deals with various articles under the headings `Equal protection of the law', `Rights of minority groups', `Right of participation in public life', `Freedom of expression', `Freedom of thought and conscience', `Freedom to have or adopt a religion or belief', `Right of peaceful assembly' and `Freedom of association'. Those are very important rights. I am not belittling them in any way at all. They are absolutely fundamental to the way we live. But they do not need to be enshrined in legislation because they have adequate protection in our society at present. As I said earlier, those rights are not at risk. There is nothing on the horizon that will take them from us. We move from the superfluous part, Division 2 and Division 3, to the absurd when we turn to page 12 and come to the Division headed `Life, Liberty and Criminal Process'. Under Article 20 the heading `Slavery and servitude' appears. Article 20 states:
No person shall be held in slavery or servitude or be required to perform forced or compulsory labour.
When was the last time anyone was held in slavery in Australia? Has it happened since Federation? Under Article 18 and the heading `Right to life' it is stated:
Every human being has the inherent right to life and no person shall be arbitrarily deprived of life.
When have we had summary executions in Australia? What is the need to put this sort of nonsense in? There is no place for this in the Australian legislative pattern.

What are the omitted fundamental rights of an Australian? They are the right to own property, the right to send one's children to a school of one's own choice, and the right not to join a union. Those rights are very basic to the way we live. They are freedoms we hold dear. There are not too many Australians who would deny themselves or their fellows the right to own property. Yet there is not one word about that in this travesty of a Bill of Rights for Australia. There is not one word because the Labor Party did not want it in as it does not fit in with its socialist, totalitarian dogma. That is why it is not in. That is why this Bill is a badly drafted Bill and why it is irrelevant to the needs of Australia. It is not too much to say that this Bill is a confidence trick when it is called a Bill of Rights.

I turn to Part III as outlined at page 14 under the heading `Operation of Bill of Rights'. This part troubles me greatly. It is one of the fundamentals of our legislative system that no parliament can bind its successors. Yet in sub-clause (1) of clause 12 this Bill sets out to say:
This section applies to every Act enacted after the enactment of this Act that is, in whole or in part, in conflict with the Bill of Rights.

In plain English that means that no parliament can move any legislation which is in conflict with the intent of this proposed Act. I believe that is absolutely untenable. It flies in the face of all the legislative practice of our Parliament. I believe that that will be challenged by someone and taken to the High Court. There is no doubt that the High Court will uphold the invalidity of that part of the proposed Act. But this is not a little slip. This is a very crafty piece of drafting on behalf of Messrs Bowen and Evans. It is very easy for them to get this through and then in the future, in association with their surrogates, the Australian Democrats, they can amend the legislation and move into any field that they so wish. This provision, denying us the right to legislate in the future with any legislation which is contrary to the Australian Bill of Rights, is untenable. We simply cannot bind future Australian parliaments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner I was saying that along with my Liberal and National Party colleagues I was totally opposed to this Bill on the grounds that first of all, the rights of Australian citizens are guaranteed by the freely elected legislature which is subject to change, as history has shown, ever since Federation; and secondly, apart from the legislature, we have the support from the judiciary to apply and interpret those laws. The second point of opposition is that this Bill is so badly drafted. I instanced examples of superfluous and absurd matters, such as the prohibition of slavery and of summary execution. I made the point that insofar as the Bill legislates on or proscribes actions in such a way that no future parliament can legislate against its intent, it breaks new ground in legislative practice in Australia and in that sense it is untenable. I foreshadowed a challenge before the High Court which I believe will be upheld.

SPEECH.PARA: I then moved to the way in which the Bill abolishes the Human Rights Commission, imperfect in action though that body might have been, and creates a new monster, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, to replace it. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission as proposed by this Bill is a non-elected body which has quite enormous powers, powers that are without parallel in a democratic community. This body's powers are comparable to those of some inquisitorial body in a police state. Quite simply, this body is answerable to no-one. If one looks at Part V of the Bill, beginning on page 23, one sees clause 29 which deals with the secrecy of accusers, clause 31 which deals with documents to be declared, clause 33 on compulsory attendance and clause 38 on obstructing or hindering the Commission, which show that this body is being given powers that are quite frightening to anyone who has an interest in democracy.

In summary, the Bill that relates to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission provides that witnesses who are called before the Commission must provide under signature any information that it demands. They must produce documents which the Commission may keep for as long as it considers necessary. They must testify under oath in hearings from which the public is excluded. They must disclose facts which may render them liable to criminal penalty. They must do all this without the normal protection of legal representation. They must attend compulsory conferences, again without legal representation. The Commission is given a blanket charter to make its own rules. The most elementary rules of natural justice may be denied to those who are forced to appear before the Commission; namely, the right to be informed of the charges made, the right to cross-examine witnesses, the right to call evidence and especially the right to have legal representation. While there is no appeal against the Commission's decisions, it may imprison any person who refuses to attend hearings, answer questions, produce documents or be sworn on oath. Is this really Australia in 1986? Those powers are more at home in an Idi Amin type regime. They have absolutely no place at all in a democratic Australia as we have known it. Never since Federation has any government tried to move down that totalitarian path.

Why have we gone down that path? Because it is pure socialist doctrine written into law. It is absolutely intolerable for a democracy. Quite clearly under that doctrine we will see the Labor goal of the abolition of the Senate, the setting up of a unicameral legislature and a movement down the path to a one-party state in which we all genuflect before the leader of the time, whether it is Bob Hawke or one of his natural successors.

Other speakers have spoken and will speak on the rights of children. I wish to touch on the rights of one minority that has not been mentioned so far-the handicapped. This Bill deals with civil and political rights which are not at risk, as I have pointed out in the earlier part of my speech, but there is nothing in the Bill at all to deal with the economic or social matters which apply to the handicapped. I wish to quote from a speech of a former human rights commissioner, a person of great intellect who, with enormous courage has overcome physical disabilities that would have daunted most of us in this chamber. In a recent speech Dr Chris Gilbert said:

Disabled people are mainly concerned with rights of an economic and social nature. We might call these `quality of life' rights. Matters such as the right to medical, social and educational rehabilitation; the right to vocational counselling and training; the right to economic and social security; the right to work; the right to have the needs of the disabled person taken into account at all stages of social and economic planning-these are the kinds of rights that the disabled citizen has the greatest need of. These are the kinds of rights that, speaking generally, the proposed Bill of Rights is not concerned with.
That statement is perfectly true. There is nothing in this Bill which helps the physically disadvantaged members of our community.

I wish to turn now to one of the matters which relate to the origins of this Bill. The Labor Party makes much of the fact that this Bill is based on an international convention. I guess that if one is running a Labor party or a Labor government and this is the sort of legislation that one wheels up, one must seek the imprimatur of another body to give it some authority and respectability. The Labor Party has leant very heavily on the fact that this legislation is based on an international convention. But there are three important points I wish to make in relation to that charge. The first is that to rely on an international convention is dishonest when it is used to outflank the Constitution of Australia. It is also dishonest in this case because the convention that most people assume applies here is not the one on which the legislation is based. The third point in relation to international conventions is very real in my opinion; that is, that such conventions debase Australia's essential sovereignty and every time we supinely sign some international treaty of a social or political nature we diminish our own authority in this Parliament and diminish the respect which Australians have for us.

My first point about the dishonesty of the path the Labor Government is treading is that this Bill outflanks the Constitution. The Constitution is an excellent document which has served Australia very well. It enshrines our freedoms, and freedoms are what we are talking about in this legislation. The Labor Party, for its own reasons, is always wanting to change it and it is a matter of great wonderment in other countries that this should be so. If one talks to an American legislator or to people from other countries with constitutions, one finds that they see their constitution as being the touchstone of their liberty and the way they run their country. They would not tolerate the constant attacks on it or the attempts to change it that we see in Australia all the time. Insofar as this Government is using section 51, clause XXIX, to give itself the external affairs powers, it is outflanking the intent and spirit of the Constitution. It signs an international treaty and then introduces supporting legislation because it has signed the treaty and that legislation overrides anything else.

The second point of dishonesty is the fact that the impression is given that this legislation is based on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights of 1948. It is not based on that at all. The 1948 declaration recognises the basic human rights and it recognises those rights that we, on this side of the Senate, are very concerned about. But the operative document for this legislation is the 1966 International Covenant of Human Rights. That is a wonderful document that is acceptable to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Libya, Afghanistan and East Germany. It is a document that sits very well with the Labor Party ethos and dogma.

The final point I wish to raise in relation to international agreements is the diminution of our sovereignty inherent in the signing of such international treaties. I do not believe that in Australia we have to borrow legislation to govern this country. I am very proud to be an Australian. I have lived a long part of my life overseas and by choice I choose to live in this country. I believe that the freedoms and standards and the way we live in Australia are second to no other country. I do not believe that we have to get a leg up on any sort of legislation by signing any sort of international agreement. If people in other countries want to join us and to follow us so much the better but it is not for us supinely to follow them.

What is the future of this Bill? Regrettably I think it will become law because quite clearly a deal has been done by the Australian Democrats to support the Australian Labor Party on this issue. I think it is highly probable that the Labor Party will move to accept the Democrat amendment that seeks to control electoral boundaries in the State parliaments in Australia. That would be a catastrophic abuse of Federal powers. We had the hypocrisy of Senator Haines here earlier with her shrill cries against Queensland and the gerrymander that exists there. Everyone knows there is a gerrymander in Queensland. That rare animal, the thinking National Party voter in Queensland, justifies that gerrymander on the basis that he believes that the country vote deserves more value than the city vote. I can respect that argument. Neither I nor my party agree with it. I believe that in a democratic society one should have as near as possible one vote one value.

However, for Senator Haines to get up here and rail against Queensland and its gerrymander while being party to a bigger gerrymander insofar as she is a member of the Australian Democrats really is the height of hypocrisy. Senator Haines and her seven colleagues are in here on a base vote of around 7 per cent of the Australian community. The Australian Democrats elected as senators represent about 7 per cent of the Australian community yet they boast of, and actually do, hold the balance of power; they hold the other 93 per cent of the Australian community to ransom from their 7 per cent base. If we are to talk about gerrymanders that is the first point we ought to start from. We should clear up that anomaly before we start moving into fields which are purely a matter for the people of Queensland. If the Labor Party picks up that amendment of the Democrats I forecast the greatest fight in this country since Federation. It is a fight which the Labor Party will lose because it is up to us as residents of Queensland to fix up the problems we have there. It is not up to an overbearing Federal Government to move in to try to clean it up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you do it then? When are you going to start?

—If the honourable senator comes up to Queensland and helps the Liberal Party it will be fixed in pretty quick time. As I wind up I am conscious that I have left out many important points in this legislation. The Bill is unnecessary. The Bill is unconstitutional. It threatens rather than protects the rights of the Australian citizen. Insofar as it sets up that horrendous body the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission it takes us down the darkest paths of government that we have ever seen. It leaves out the important right to own property, the right to send our children to a school of our choice and the right not to join a union. The Opposition is totally opposed to this Bill. For those few members of the Labor Party who are in here, and the even fewer who will be able to follow what I am going to say, I give them this to think about: It is a Government's role to protect the rights and freedoms of the citizen, not to grant them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill to which have been foreshadowed amendments by the Opposition relating to the right not to join a trade union or association, rights in respect of education, the right in respect of property and the right in respect of scientific research and creative activity. I have read a great deal about this matter. I have read every word that has been spoken in this chamber on this subject in this debate. I listened attentively to what was said by the previous speaker. I have read and studied the foreshadowed amendments of the Opposition. It is my intention to vote against the Bill and to vote against at least two of the amendments of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Some time ago I spoke about the problems of instituting a Bill of Rights in Australia. I suppose I was one of the very few parliamentarians at that time to have written about the matter because, as has been said in this debate, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission was the creature of the then Fraser Government. To be fair to the government of that day it did not intend that the legislation would be clothed with the powers which it is now intended to be; nevertheless, Blind Freddie could have seen that that would have been the ultimate objective both of the Human Rights Commission and of any successive government.

What is wrong with a Bill of Rights in general terms? What is wrong with a Bill of Rights is that the whole concept is not clearly established or put to the people of Australia. Indeed, it has been repeated time and again in this chamber that insofar as this Bill of Rights is concerned there has been a great deal of secrecy and furtiveness on behalf of the Government to keep the Bill and its contents and actual meaning away from the public. Today if one goes into the Australian Government Publishing Service in Hobart in Tasmania one cannot even get a copy of the Bill of Rights. The list of people trying to get a copy of the Bill of Rights is as long as your arm. Is that democracy? Of course it is not democracy. The Government unfortunately has attempted to hide not only what was proposed in the Bill of Rights-I remember questioning Senator Gareth Evans constantly here about that-but also the Government has refused to tell the people what the ramifications of a Bill of Rights are.

People might get the Bill but may not understand the ramifications. So far as people's rights are concerned the provisions in the Bill are unexceptionable if they are read as any normal person would read them. However, if one has regard to what has happened in other countries and to the fact that excessive individualism has at times created problems for society as a whole because of certain Bill of Rights provisions in other countries one will see what I mean.

Before anyone endorses the Government's Bill of Rights they should look carefully at the fine print. They should have the opportunity and the time to do that. Also Ministers should be available to travel around the countryside describing precisely what the Bill will do and what ramifications it will have. As I wrote years ago: People are entitled to be concerned that the Bill of Rights strikes at the principle of near democracy and further undermines the rights of electors. They should be concerned if it extends the scope of non-elected persons to impose on the Australian people in effect what are non-parliamentary laws relating to cherished values and social and community standards.

This Bill will disturb the fine balance of powers between the Executive, the judiciary and the legislature. Effectively, it will usurp the role of elected parliamentarians to ensure that the contents and ultimately the administration of laws safeguard human rights. It will effectively deny to the people their ultimate sanction-that is, the sanction of the ballot box-over those to whom this Bill will give the power to make value-interpretative judgments which will have or could have significant social ramifications. This Bill has the potential to deny to certain human beings their fundamental human rights. If the individualism and privatisation inherent in this Bill are taken to excess, it will have the potential to undermine the values upon which our society is founded and which provide the cohesive force of the law.

What are rights? What are human rights? How are they to be distinguished from claims that are made when one's interests are threatened? I think we all know what human rights are. A number of people have talked during the various debates on this matter about the United States experience. Many of them forget the words of the free-thinking Thomas Jefferson who said:
. . . the only firm basis of a nation's liberties is a conviction in the minds of people that their liberties are the gift of God.
The same idea was expressed by Jefferson's rival, Alexander Hamilton, who said:

The sacred rights of mankind are not to be rummaged for amongst old parchments or musty records. They are written as with a sunbeam, in the whole volume of human nature, by the hand of the Divinity itself; and can never be erased or obscured by mortal power.

The situation in the United States has changed somewhat. In certain respects, the excessive individualism in that country has threatened concepts of the common good. I cite as an example the striking down of a number of obscenity and anti-pornography laws in the United States as a result of an appeal by the pornographers to their rights under the American Bill of Rights. That is just one example. We know that liberty is not the natural state of a bruised mankind, but it should be the obligation of the organised state and the organised society to ensure it. The ideal society is one in which the practice of good and what is beneficial is made easy, but free; and where an atmosphere is encouraged so that people are encouraged to choose what is good or what is better. For example, the taxation laws of a country should not force both parents out to work in order that a family can live with some degree of dignity and economic security. At the moment, the taxation laws do not do that. Another example is that taxation laws of a country provide taxation concessions to those who contribute to charitable causes. If the individualism and the privatisation inherent in this Bill are taken to excess, it has the potential to undermine essential societal values.

I shall give a couple of examples. I believe that it is imperative that the Minister speaking on behalf of the Government refer to these at the Committee stage of the debate because of the operation of the Acts Interpretation Act and because what is said in this Parliament by a responsible Minister is to be taken into consideration in the administration of the law. Let me give the Senate two examples among many. I note that Article 6 of the Bill states in part that every Australian citizen has the right:
. . . to vote and to be elected at genuine periodic elections, which shall be by universal and equal suffrage and by secret ballot, guaranteeing the free expression of the will of the electors . . .
I wonder whether the group system of voting in the Senate truly meets that test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes! That's why I am here.

—Senator Aulich says that it truly meets the test. The first test of a democratic system of voting is that it truly reflects the intentions of the voters. Let us look at what happened in Tasmania, where workers in the pulp and paper industry and the woodchip industry put a No. 1 for the Australian Labor Party in the box on their ballot papers. Those to whom I have spoken did not know that by so doing they would elect Senator Sanders. It will be very interesting to see whether that system meets the test. I am being diverted, even though that question is pretty relevant! I come back to Article 6 which states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Every Australian citizen has the right and shall have the opportunity-
(c) to have access on general terms of equality to public employment.

How will that redress the discrimination that has taken place with regard to youth employment in the Public Service? I have been calling on the Government to redress that situation whereby employment of youth in the Public Service has fallen from 23.6 per cent in 1969 to 6.3 per cent today. Will Article 6 (c) affect the Public Service Board when it tries to put on a youth and someone who is better qualified fronts up and says: `Here, put me on under Article 6 (c)'? What about a homosexual teacher in a public school? He would be entitled to `general terms of equality' with regard to employment in the Public Service. Article 7 states:

Every person has the right to freedom of expression, including the freedom of the press and other media of communication, and the freedom to seek, receive and impart ideas or information of any kind in any form, without interference and regardless of frontiers.
What will such excessive individualism do to the basic values upon which our society is founded? This Bill is an anti-union Bill. Any dinkum trade unionist--

TALK.START.PARA: —How?
—Let me just show the Senate how it is an anti-union Bill. Any dinkum trade unionist ought to reject this Bill, particularly that part of it dealing with the freedom of association. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Every person has the right to freedom of association with others, including the right to form and join trade unions for the protection of that person's interests.

Senator Haines said that she had been given some advice that the positive also implies the negative. In other words, if the freedom of association and joining of a union is included in the Bill, the reverse is the fact as well; the freedom not to join a union is included as well. I do not accept that. Nevertheless, the Opposition will move an amendment-and Senator Haines on behalf of the Democrats has said that she will accept a streamlined version of that amendment-to ensure that what is included in this part of the Bill is the right of a person not to join a union. That is a fundamental attack on the principle of trade unionism. All of those preference clauses-I think there are 300-odd-in Federal awards will be wiped out overnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope so.
—Somebody said: `I hope so'.
—If she is right.
—No, not if she is right; if it is carried here. That is a threat to orderly industrial progress.
—Do you mean if their amendment is carried?

—The amendment will open the way or the very inclusion of this article will open the way for any successive government to amend the Bill and include the anti-union amendment. In my view it is a disgraceful thing for a Labor government to have opened the way for that possibility. Why did the Government not leave the right under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act? It might be said, and it is true, that when this matter was dealt with by the United Nations it was clearly understood that it did not refer to the right not to join a union. If the head of power in this Bill were only the external affairs head of power, of course the possibility is that the amendment would be invalidated at some stage. But I cannot see anywhere in the Bill a provision which specifically excludes all the other heads of power. So, in respect of Commonwealth awards, this is a threat to preference for unionists. That is what I say about the excessive individualism and privatisation of this measure and the effect that it will have on societal formations and values. I have always upheld the right of persons not to join a union if they have a conscientious objection based on religious grounds. That is not contained in the amendment and presumably that is not what the Democrats will go along with. As I say, I have always believed in the right of individuals, if they have a genuine conscientious objection based on religious grounds, to be exempted and that is the trade union movement's attitude. But this Bill will mean the demise of all preference clauses.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point that I made was that the Bill has the potential to deny to certain human beings their fundamental rights. I am talking about the fundamental right to life. Why was the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights changed? Why were its terms changed? I will deal with that point in the Committee stage. I do not have time to deal with it now. The International Covenant states:
Every human being has the inherent right to life. This right shall be protected by law. No one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his life.

What does the Bill state in this regard? It is almost precisely the same except that is says `every person'. This Bill, of course, applies to natural persons. Unfortunately, in various laws in the Commonwealth natural person means after birth. There is, therefore, the potential for the destruction of the right to life of the unborn child. I am interested to see that there is nothing in this Bill of Rights which protects a pregnant woman from a death sentence. There is nothing of that kind in the Bill, although it is contained in the International Covenant. Why is it not contained in the Bill? If I were to go one step further and move the amendment I would be inclined to move that no person shall receive a sentence of death.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody does in Australia. There is no capital punishment.

—Senator Ryan says that there is no capital punishment. Let us go through a few of the other points. What Senator Ryan said was very interesting. On each of these occasions she would have to prove to the Senate-if her basis for including things or excluding them is that these rights do not exist in Australia or that they are already protected in Australia-that if they are already protected in Australia they are not included in the Bill. She would have to state in the Committee stage, with regard to every one of these articles, whether they are not protected in Australia. I will remind her about that.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the Bill effectively denies to the people their ultimate sanction over those who, by this Bill, are given the power to make interpretive value judgments which could have significant social ramifications. What will happen because of this Bill is that a non-elected, non-judicial Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission will usurp the responsibilities of the elected Parliament. This Bill deals with equal protection of the law and equality before the law; namely, the content of the law and the administration of the law. This Parliament-we, the elected representatives of the people-surely have the responsibility to ensure that the content of the law does not transgress human rights. After all, why do we have the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations? Why do we have the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills? Why do we have the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs? Why do we have a Senate? Should it all be handed over to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission?

Honourable senators should look at what Odgers says about the responsibility of this place, the review chamber, in respect of human rights to ensure that the content of law is safeguarded. We should ensure not only that the content of law is safeguarded, but also the administration of the law. I am the first to admit that we cannot possibly take every complaint of persons who feel that they have not been treated equally under the law by the administration of the law. But I put it to the Senate that it is very strange that this Bill establishes a bureaucratic structure, and executive structure formed by the Executive Government, to vet executive decisions. If it vets those executive decisions it may be said that it has no real power to determine absolutely whether the content of the law or the administration of the law transgresses human rights. It has got awfully strong persuasive powers which strike, in many instances, against the very rights that this Bill seeks to uphold. Again, that will be elaborated on at the Committee stage.

I believe that the Human Rights Commission is the body least capable of dealing with this matter. I will refer in the Committee stage to its occasional paper No. 10, on the management of defective newborn children where it proposes to take away the right to life of those children and provide a system of euthanasia. That is in the Human Rights Commission's occasional paper No. 10. I suggest that honourable senators get this paper and read it. It is very interesting. The Human Rights Commission's kit for schools will get a run around the course in the Committee stage as to what it says about the traditional family.

I refer to the question of clothing the courts with power. To ensure that the courts are required to deal with questions emanating from this Bill is to give them enormous powers and to disturb the balance between the Executive, the judiciary and the legislature. The courts are required to determine, when it is raised, whether the laws are in accordance with the articles of the Bill of Rights. But they are to do so `subject only to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can demonstrably justify it in a free and democratic society'.

I point out to the Senate that our own Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee stated that that is `an overt political criterion'. It is an overt political criterion; there is no doubt about that. I mean no disrespect to the judges at all but when a question was raised about whether it is proper to give over to a non-elected judiciary what truly ought to be the rights and responsibilities of a parliament, somebody said in answer to that question in the debate: `Oh, that is terrible. You are reflecting on the judiciary'.
I helped organise the Thomas More quincentenary celebrations in Tasmania. Sir Stanley Burbury who was formerly Chief Justice of Tasmania and Governor of that State, said in his occasional address:
I do not wish to be misunderstood when I say that I do not think it possible to establish a Court which we could trust with such a solemn judicial task.
That is the interpretation of a Bill of Rights. He continued:

The interpretation and application by any Court of fundamental laws necessarily expressed in wide general terms leaves an immense area for the exercise of judicial discretion and for sharp differences of opinion between judges . . . Nor can many decisions in this area be based on bare legal reasoning. The personal attributes of the judge will often be stronger factors in moulding his opinion-his social, religious, political, philosophical and cultural background and beliefs. Complete objectivity is impossible. Judges who are entrusted with the solemn task of judicial review of Acts of Parliament to determine whether they should be declared void as infringing fundamental laws inevitably become legislators; legislators who are beyond the control of the democratic will . . .
I leave it at that. Those words, coming from a judge, should be seriously considered by this chamber.

It had not been my intention to speak during the second reading debate on these four Bills, yet I consider now that I must make a contribution following some outrageous statements which were made by one particular speaker. I suppose there have been some outrageous statements made by many speakers and I should imagine there will be more outrageous statements to be made before this debate is completed. In particular, last Friday the Senate was subjected to some vintage boisterous Boswell baloney. Like many of his Party colleagues in Queensland, he tries to prove that white is black and brands anyone who disagrees as a left winger or an Australian Democrat. SPEECH.PARA: It is always interesting to hear Senator Boswell attempting to defend the indefensible. Since the Queensland redistribution of boundaries occurred late last year, our National Party colleague has claimed that Queensland has a satisfactory set of electoral boundaries. Different zonal quotas and vastly differing enrolments within and between zones are of no concern to the close confidant of the small town Marcos. What does Senator Boswell do? He goes on the offensive, brings forward some spurious quote proudly but incorrectly claiming that he has reached a stage of quod erat demonstrandum, and attacks as left wingers, Democrats or both anyone who fails to agree with his so-called proof. For instance, in his speech last Friday he quoted an academic finding relating to distributions in 1972 and 1977. I always knew the National Party in Queensland was behind the times, but I did not think it was eight or nine years behind. For the good senator's information, there was a redistribution last year and the gazettal of the final boundaries after objections were considered was made early this year. So it is this redistribution which should be considered if there is a need to determine whether Queensland has a fair redistribution. I intend to make the necessary analysis because it is pertinent to the Bills we have under discussion, especially to Article 6 of the Bill of Rights Bill. Article 6 of the Bill is based on Article 25 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Article 25 states:
Every citizen shall have the right and the opportunity, without any of the distinctions mentioned in article 2 and without unreasonable restrictions:
(a) To take part in the conduct of public affairs, directly or through freely chosen representatives;

(b) To vote and to be elected at genuine periodic elections which shall be by universal and equal suffrage and shall be held by secret ballot, guaranteeing the free expression of the will of the electors;

Article 6 in the Australian Bill of Rights Bill follows very closely. It states:
Right to participation in public life.
Every Australian citizen has the right and shall have the opportunity-
(a) to take part in the conduct of public affairs, directly or through freely chosen representatives;
(b) to vote and to be elected at genuine periodic elections, which shall be by universal and equal suffrage and by secret ballot, guaranteeing the free expression of the will of the electors; and
(c) to have access on general terms of equality to public employment
My remarks will be related, in particular, to paragraph (b), namely:
To vote and to be elected at genuine periodic elections, which shall be by universal and equal suffrage . . .

In particular I will be speaking about the equal suffrage aspect. Before speaking about the electoral redistribution in Queensland, however, I should make my position clear on a couple of matters. I have steadfastly held that Federal legislation is necessary to rid Australia of rigged boundaries at the State levels. There is no justification for electoral cheating anywhere. In a country such as Australia, which claims to uphold the principles of democracy, it should not be contemplated that electoral cheating could be a factor to be given even a passing thought. But in terms of malapportioned electorates and classic gerrymanders, it is a problem at the State level. I mention also that it is an equally severe, or maybe a more severe, problem at the local authority level. This too is an area which must be given attention by those who know that the best interests of democracy will be served in Australia by a one vote one value electoral system.

If the Bill of Rights, which is one of the Bills under consideration, can be amended to counter the cavalier way in which electoral boundaries are grossly malapportioned by some State governments, those amendments should be supported. Of course we will have people such as the Senator Boswells of this country bleating about States rights, but do they ever consider the rights of the citizens in those individual States? Of course they do not. The one vote one value principle does not suit their political purposes and therefore, according to them, it must be a left wing or Democrats plot to undermine agrarian socialists.

What is really needed is a provision in the Australian Constitution to enshrine the principle of one vote one value for elections in this country. It will not be an easy task to have the Constitution altered in this way. We know how many amendments to the Constitution have been proposed and how few have been passed by the people of Australia. If such a provision were inserted in the Constitution, it would be next to impossible for any future maverick government to have the provision removed. The Legislative Council in South Australia does not appear in the table because Legislative Councillors in that State are elected for the State as one electorate.

The next State in the table is Western Australia. The Western Australian Legislative Assembly appears to be grossly malapportioned. Only four of the 57 seats vary by less than 10 per cent from average enrolment. Thirteen seats are in the range of 10 to 20 per cent and a massive 40 seats vary by greater than 20 per cent from average. The Legislative Council in that State has 17 seats, each of which varies by greater than 20 per cent from the average enrolment. The record in the House of Assembly in Tasmania is excellent, principally because the multi-member electorates are based on the five Federal electorates in that State. Ten of the 19 seats vary by less than 10 per cent; five are in the 10 to 20 per cent bracket; and four vary by greater than 20 per cent from the average enrolment. In the Northern Territory House of Assembly there are 25 seats, 20 of which vary by less than 10 per cent from the average; four are in the 10 to 20 per cent range; and one varies by greater than 20 per cent from average enrolment.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal effect of having zones is to produce a malapportioned electoral system. Nevertheless, the zonal system could be regarded as a gerrymander in its own right. The system reduces the value of some citizens' votes and increases the value of others. Almost all of the electorates where the value of a vote has been enhanced by the zonal system are held by members of the ruling National Party of Australia. The zonal system, together with its unequal weighting of electors between zones, is a deliberate attempt to corrupt the electoral system in Queensland. The corruption, however, goes further than this. An additional system of gerrymander overlays the zonal system. I have previously outlined the manipulation of boundaries which occurred with the Aboriginal community of Wujal Wujal in far north Queensland. Wujal Wujal was transferred by an Act of parliament to the western and far northern zone from the provincial city zone electorate held by the Queensland Minister, Mr Tenni. Wujal Wujal is now a land-locked island wholly surrounded by Mr Tenni's electorate, but not part of it. Mr Tenni said he was sorry to lose Wujal Wujal but I dare say he was only shedding crocodile tears. While speaking of far north Queensland, it is worth noting that Mt Isa is an electorate within the western and far northern zone. The average number of voters in this zone is 9,386. It is no coincidence that Mr Isa is held by the Australian Labor Party and the higher quota enrolment locks Labor votes in and makes other electorates safer for the National Party.

I must also mention the degree of malapportionment within the provincial city zones. Five different areas are treated separately, namely: Bundaberg, central Queensland, Townsville, Cairns and Mackay. The average enrolments in these areas vary. Of the 13 electorates in this zone, the highest enrolment is 20,520 and the lowest is 14,730. I believe that these are sufficiently close to indicate that the electoral system in Queensland could by no stretch of the imagination be regarded as a fair one. For the Senator Boswells of Queensland to suggest otherwise is to live in fairyland.

c I must say something about the comments that were made earlier in the debate by Senator MacGibbon. Senator MacGibbon said that it is up to us as residents of Queensland to fix the system. Let me put to rest another argument proposed by Senator Boswell last Friday and again in a notice of motion he put down in the Senate today.
