SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I tend to think that we should get the debate back to the matter before the Senate-the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. The message that must go out to the people of Australia is very simple and very serious. It is that Australia simply does not need a Bill of Rights; it most certainly does not need a selective and destructive catalogue of so-called rights; and least of all should we entrust any authority to a commission. My opposition as a Liberal to these Bills is not based on a total rejection of the concept of a charter of rights overriding some powers of a legislature. There would be some value in a declaratory statement of rights to bind together a society suffering from deep community trauma.
—We are in Queensland.

—A Bill of Rights supported by both communities would make sense in Northern Ireland. If Senator Reynolds can associate herself with Northern Ireland, good luck to her. The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms is largely directed to the solution of Canada's linguistic and cultural divisions. For all its diversity, Australian society has no comparable divisions. Moreover, unlike the United States of America, Ministers are directly responsible to our State and Federal parliaments. Unlike Great Britain, a written constitution limits the powers of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that a Bill of Rights cannot guarantee or enhance our freedom. Freedoms in our society have been developed and safeguarded by the empirical wisdom of common law. Has the existence of a Bill of Rights in the Soviet Union or South Africa, for example, done anything for human rights in those nations? The whole argument was summarised superbly way back in September 1981 by Sir Harry Gibbs when he said:
If society is tolerant and rational, it does not need a Bill of Rights. If it is not, no Bill of Rights will preserve it.

The Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrat senators who mean to afflict us with this legislation would be hard put to claim that it reflects deep-seated pressure from ordinary Australians. When I talk to people I find that they want efficient management and less tax and regulation from government. They are getting all of that in large doses in increases from this Government. The more they are aware of this legislation, the more concerned they become.

If Labor senators and the Democrats cannot see what is happening by the volume of mail alone and public opinion, I feel very sorry for them. I know that Senator Haines, for example, could not care less about what the community has said on this Bill. In a speech the other day she said:
. . . I have never before run into so much misinformation that has been spread around the community about any piece of legislation . . .
She went on to say:
Sadly, they are often masquerading as Christians.
She further went on to say:
. . . peddling lies and stirring up fear in the minds of ordinary, honest, reasonable people in the community.
It just goes to show how much Senator Haines, in the whole emotional hyperbole she went on with at length on Friday, cares about what real Australians think of this so-called Bill of Rights.

The Australian Bill of Rights in fact reflects only the values of a self-proclaimed, self-serving cultural elite. This legislation is a monument, not to the cause of personal liberty but to its reverse-state interventionism and social engineering. The essential hypocrisy and dishonesty of this Bill is encapsulated in the fact that it has not been put before the people of Australia as an amendment to the Constitution. The ALP and the Democrats, of course, know full well what the result of such a referendum would be. The electors would simply reject it. They do not have the nerve to go before the Australian public and justify their selective list of rights. It is as simple as that-they do not have the nerve. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its exposure report on a Bill of Rights for Australia noted that `there is no prospect in the foreseeable future' of any such proposal being passed in the referendum. How ironic that those who are intent on using the Bill of Rights to impose their idea of democracy on State parliaments should be at pains to avoid the democratic vote of the Australian people. We can appreciate that their strategy is to impose the Bill of Rights by these indirect means in order to soften up the electorate for radical change later on. And mark my words, radical change it will be! The Democrats and this Labor socialist Government are committed to that type of change.

The crude and immediate political objective of this legislation is to break the remaining autonomous powers of State parliaments. Do not be misled at all by that. Unfortunately the Australian Democrats do hold the balance of power in this place. Senator Haines once said on Friday that: `The legislation ought to be extended to States so that States and their bureaucracies cannot trample over them. Therefore, let us try to wipe out the States'. Through Article 6 of the Bill of Rights and through the investigative powers of the Human Rights Commission we have problems in the States. We should not for one moment be impressed or grateful that the Bill of Rights does not as yet apply directly to the States. The fact that the Human Rights Commission will have the power under clause 27 to investigate State legislation under ministerial discretion shows that it will be used to coerce the States. The threat is implicit that if they do not co-operate the Act will be amended to apply the Bill of Rights in total to the States. On 26 November the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) expressed his eagerness for the Human Rights Commission to report on the Queensland and Western Australian electoral systems, after which he foreshadowed legislation pursuant to the international covenant in order to compel the States to have equal size electorates. We have been warned. Let us take on that warning; let us heed it. This legislation is to be the means whereby the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats-I should put them all as one and the same-will dictate to the State parliaments what their electoral systems will be. Once a parliament ceases to have the right to determine its own electoral ground rules, its legislative autonomy is finished. It will have as much autonomy as a shire council. It might as well close up shop. Mind you, closing up shop, of course, is the long term objective of the Hawke socialist Government and the Democrats.

Article 6 of the Bill of Rights, insisting that elections guarantee `the free expression of the will of the electors', is intruding into an essentially subjective area. We should note that the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms avoids making any such guarantee. The fact is that, while we can guarantee that an election is honestly conducted, there is no true way of ensuring that the wishes of the electorate will be faithfully mirrored in the political composition of an elected House of parliament. Because a parliament chooses to have electorates of different enrolments does not of itself mean that the election results are any less likely to give a party or a coalition most acceptable to 50 per cent of the voters a majority of seats. The term `one vote one value' used in the explanatory memorandum is meaningless and just a stupid catch phrase that illustrates the shallow hypocrisy of this Bill. Can somebody explain to me how an ALP vote in the seat of Curtin in Western Australia will ever have the same value as an ALP vote in the marginal seat of Stirling or a blue ribbon seat like Fremantle no matter whether these seats have equal enrolments.' This inane and witless slogan is to be the excuse for the destruction of our State parliaments.

We have just heard Senator Colston, who has not had the courtesy to remain in the chamber, talk at length about the Queensland Parliament and the Queensland electoral system. Yet the other day the Labor Party held a meeting to decide to firm up the Bill of Rights. The Committee recommended that the Bill be altered to give the Commonwealth power to override State electoral laws if they did not provide for fair elections. We have just heard Senator Colston go on at length about how that should happen. Yet at that very meeting last week he saw fit to abstain from voting. So much for what we can hear from the Government side on this important issue. As a Liberal and a federalist it is anathema to me that legislation of this Parliament should have the potential to override State parliaments on such a basic matter.

Passing from this most blatantly partisan objective of the legislation, I must now examine how the 32 Articles of the Bill of Rights protect or enhance our personal liberty. The short answer to that, of course, is that they do not. They fail to safeguard freedom because they are selective and at times carefully limited. One omission alone renders this Bill of Rights useless and morally bankrupt. There is no guarantee of the right to private property. Without this right all other rights and freedoms become meaningless because they cannot effectively be exercised. It underpins the right to engage in commerce, for example, and is the platform for a whole range of social activity. We would be totally dependent on the state if we were denied the right to hold property and to use it productively, and as such we simply would not be free. To quote Professor Alice Tay:
Property is that which a man has a right to use and enjoy without interference: It is what makes him a person and guarantees his independence and security.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that property is more important than people?
—Obviously, yes.

—Obviously, the Democrats and the Government do not want this freedom that we should have as an inherent right, to own private property. They are quite happy to do that. It is not surprising that a socialist government wants to negate this essential source of personal liberty. We have been hearing interjections ad infinitum from both the Government and the Democrats implying that they want to do away with it. So let there be no mistake that they are trying to take away this essential source of personal liberty. Equally, it is convenient for them to base this legislation on the 1966 United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which is careful to omit this essential human right. Not that we should be surprised that an organisation comprised mainly of nations with a vested interest in maintaining state control over their populations should wish to ignore the basis of personal freedom. Significantly, the right to property was recognised originally in Article 17 of the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights, but omitted from later covenants as the numbers of Marxist and authoritarian nations grew in the United Nations. However, the 1961 European Convention on Human Rights does recognise the right to property, reflecting the values of Western democratic nations. Yet the ALP and the Democrats prefer to link Australia with the warped concept of rights as expressed in the United Nations covenant. The fact speaks for itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Other notable omissions from the 32 Articles underscore the selective nature of this Bill of Rights. The family receives only a cursory mention in Article 13, and nothing is said about the fundamental right in a free society to establish independent schools and to choose where children will be educated. This silence shows up the mean-spirited authoritarianism that underlies the socialist education philosophy.

Just as property is not guaranteed, there is no mention of the freedom to dispose of our goods and our talents, to engage in commerce or to enter a chosen field of employment. The influence of the Australian Council of Trade Unions over the Bill of Rights is obvious in Article 11 which ensures the right to join and form trade unions but is silent as to any right not to join an association. The European Convention on Human Rights does in contrast uphold the freedom to disassociate. Whereas clause 2 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states: `No-one may be compelled to join an association', the ICCPR carefully avoids this statement.

Examining the 32 Articles in the Bill of Rights, we find a potential for destructive social engineering, interspersed with sufficient qualifications to ensure that a Labor government will not be restricted in its actions. Article 4, while providing the accepted principle of equality before the law, ensures the unrestricted continuation of reverse discrimination for favoured groups that has reached a fine art under this Government and has yet to go further. Senator Zakharov may well laugh because she thinks discrimination is an absolute scream. Article 7, enshrining freedom of expression and the imparting of ideas and information of any kind and in any form, could be dynamite in Australia's school classrooms. It is not hard to imagine that this Article could justify a teacher expounding an extremist ideology or even a perverted mode of behaviour against the wishes of education authorities or, more particularly, against the wishes of parents. Once again Senator Zakharov thinks that it is a bit of a scream, a bit of a laugh to usurp the role of the parent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. I take objection to the honourable senator imputing motives to another senator in this place.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable senator was merely asserting what she heard the honourable senator say. If the honourable senator objects, she can make a personal explanation at the end of Senator Knowles's speech.
—I agree with Senator Baume on that point. There is no point of order.

—Equally dangerous is Article 14, which deals with the rights of the child. The studied vagueness of the comment that children are to enjoy the freedoms of the Bill of Rights `to the greatest extent compatible with the age of the individual child'-whatever that means-could prove an invitation to older children to rebel against parental discipline. I see that Senator Sanders thinks that that is a bit of a laugh. The extent of independence given to adolescents is a matter for parents, not governments. I realise that Senator Sanders is trying to move closer to the microphone to get his views across, but I believe the role of parents is distinctly important in the formulation of children's behaviour and attitudes.

SPEECH.PARA: While saying little about the family, the Bill of Rights thus actively seeks to weaken parental authority-all too often the objective of the extreme left of politics. The qualifications that hedge these articles are reminiscent of Orwell's Animal Farm. Article 28 appears to promise a timely repudiation of retrospective penalties that have disgraced this Parliament, until we realise that it applies only to criminal penalties. Governments can therefore continue to impose retrospective taxation and other civil liabilities while upholding a principle of common criminal law that has not been seriously challenged, any more than that we in Australia are threatened by torture and slavery. It brings to mind a little saying that in this Bill the Hawke Government is compounding sins that it is inclined to by damning those it has no mind to. Because sub-clause (3) of clause 9 ensures that the Articles apply only to natural persons, it has been pointed out by Professor Cooray and others that the consequent denial of rights to companies could allow Press freedom to be restricted.

Turning to Part V of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and to its companion legislation, our opposition is based on one overwhelming principle: Justice should be dispensed by courts of law and must not be exercised by semi-judicial bodies that are biased to a particular set of values. No matter what excellent qualities the personnel of such tribunals may have, a combination of educative and judicial functions runs counter to the essential principle of justice-that it be disinterested and seen to be disinterested. It comes back to the words of Judge Learned Hand, who said in 1958:
For myself, it would be most irksome to be ruled by a bevy of platonic guardians, even if I knew how to choose them, which assuredly I do not.

It is not government by platonic guardians that this legislation will produce, but rather the rule of thought police. The Senate Committee's exposure report in fact questions whether the so-called determinations of the Human Rights Commission are compatible with its educative and conciliatory functions. It is a question we should all be asking. It is acknowledged that the Deputy Chairman of the Commission, Mr Peter Bailey, has this same reservation. We cannot accept, however, the argument advanced in chapter 5 of the same report that it is useful for aggrieved persons to have a forum that departs from legal formalities and that need not produce winners or losers. In practical terms, the dispensation of justice in a supposedly informal manner runs the risk of depriving people of the trained legal protection that they require and thus creates a sense of injustice, whether imagined or real.

There can be no question that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has been granted real coercive authority under this legislation. Under clause 29, the Commission is empowered to take evidence in secret and suppress the publication of any document produced before it. In the name of privacy, we are traversing the same path as prerogative courts of 400 years ago, such as Star Chamber, designed to override common law justice by operating in secrecy and making their own rules of procedure. Clause 31 allows the Commission to direct that any document be produced before it and to summon any person to attend an inquiry or a compulsory conference, as in clause 33. Nor can we doubt that we are dealing with a judicial tribunal when under clause 29 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill the Commission is able to recommend the payment of compensation for those it judges to be victims of human rights violations. Equally, the power that is given to a member of the Commission in clause 32 of the principal Bill to administer oaths and affirmations and to examine people on oath is a power that properly belongs to traditional courts alone. Fines of $1,000 for a natural person or $5,000 for a body corporate, coupled with three months imprisonment for those refusing to be sworn and produce information, show clearly that the Commission has direct coercive powers.

We are not dealing merely with the usurping of justice by an outside body. What we are now facing is injustice in the extreme, the outstanding example of which is the power of the president of a compulsory conference, under clause 34, to deny a person or corporation the right of legal representation. For all the platitudes contained in the Articles contained in the Bill of Rights as to legal representation in criminal trials, this same principle of elementary justice is denied those who will appear before the socialist Star Chamber. Furthermore, under clause 43 the Commission may delegate all or any of its powers to its staff members or to any prescribed person under its regulations. Can we imagine the consequences if this open-ended delegation were practised in courts of law? Presumably in the name of flexibility, we have a recipe for tyranny. The combination of propagandist, investigative and judicial functions in one body, able to make its own rules, is nothing less than a direct assault on the rule of law. At earlier stages of our history these functions have been combined with unfortunate results. We all know that to be true. There would be enormous risks in giving any person the type of authority conferred by this legislation, be they platonic guardians or more fallible mortals.

Situations which bother me and which can be a direct result of greater powers granted through the Bill are those such as we saw last August in Western Australia when a body was able to override the wishes of parents and school principals. It was proclaimed last August that single sex sport in schools could constitute discrimination, despite the overwhelming practical evidence that in a number of sports girls simply lack the physical strength to compete fairly with boys. The person concerned gave away their real motivation by indicating that competitive sport must be downgraded anyway because `only an elite minority compete in top level sport'. Therefore, because of this anti-competitive ideology, parents are being told that their children are to be discouraged from competitive sport. At one Western Australian primary school over 97 per cent of parents opted in a survey for seperate sports activities for girls and boys. Clearly, we are up against the philosophy that the instruments of the interventionist state know better.

Surely we should all be concerned about freedom of speech. Yet we saw suggested amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act in 1983, which would not be far off again should this Bill be passed. Those amendments would have created a new crime of group defamation on the extraordinary collectivist principle that offensive remarks directed against a group are as hurtful and defamatory as personal libel or slander. We can illustrate the absurdity of this idea by asking ourselves whether we in this chamber would be as damaged in our reputations by a remark that all senators were crooks as by accusations that we personally were dishonest. We cannot at any cost be prepared to sacrifice free speech on the altar of collectivism through a measure that could result in the silencing of commentators or any individual. Freedom of choice and freedom of speech must be paramount in our community. With this in mind we should be fearful that the passage of these Bills, with the aid of the Australian Democrats, will mean that Australia will be subject to a new kind of censorship in conformity with the values of the leftist interventionist elite.

Last year we saw the disgraceful situation where the Queensland Government was declared guilty of transgressing the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights through its legislation that sought to guarantee the electricity supply. It was recommended that the Federal Government should simply legislate to overrule the State law. Of course the proponents of this action said nothing about the rights of tens of thousands of ordinary people who were the victims of the earlier industrial banditry and whom the State Government was trying to protect. I note that one honourable senator who is sitting on my left thinks that that is amusing. If she thinks it is amusing for the people of Queensland to have their power cut off, then Lord help her. We simply cannot afford to have a group of people playing Pontius Pilate, which is what this group did. Who said that the States were not in any danger and who said that there will not be an enormous aid to union bullies who have no thought for individual unionists and workers?

I greatly fear that Australians will have cause to regret deeply the action of this Senate should it pass this legislation. It is legislation designed not to uphold human freedom, but to promote mean spirited, partisan social engineering. It is designed to smash the federal system through the enforcement of the electoral platforms of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. It promotes only those so-called rights that are compatible with a leftist interventionist agenda. It ignores or downplays those rights upholding individual freedom and family and it will create partisan and lawless tribunals that will overturn established principles of justice. It gives power to a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that is determined to enforce a collectivist ideology on this country. It is a disgrace to this Parliament and a retrograde step in the cause of civil liberties and social justice. Its supporters will not let the Australian people decide upon it in a referendum. The Liberal Party stands proud in the fight against this evil legislation and we will fight desperately to avoid the passage of this Bill. Unfortunately, we know that the Democrats are just as determined to see it pass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be very tempting to use my half hour to refute the claims of Senator Knowles, the speaker who has just finished. I thought her remarks were extraordinary, but I hope that as we are being broadcast the members of the Australian public who have been listening will be able to formulate their own judgment about her speech which was full of hyperbole and wild claims. I draw attention to only one or two points that she made, particularly the very disparaging remarks about the old adage `one vote, one value'. To most Australians that is well understood and it is well taken that it means what it says. If Senator Knowles needs to have it explained or taken out, I suggest that she speak to some of her colleagues in the Liberal Party who no doubt could explain to her what one vote one value is held to mean by a State like South Australia, certainly, where Steele Hall and Don Dunstan, when each was Premier, fought for many years to implement those values in the State legislation. It is my understanding that almost all States have moved to that principle. Although it has taken time to effect those changes, no State that has such legislation apologises or expects that there is anything other than the straightforward understanding of that simplified expression `one vote one value'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Knowles also insisted that everything would be better if it went to a referendum. I draw her attention to a number of referendums in which a majority of Australians voted in favour of change, but as there was not a majority of States in favour, the referendums could not proceed. Those are the rules of the game, and nobody objects to them. I would simply say that they call into question Senator Knowles's claims about what is due process and procedure. Finally, I draw her attention to her complaints that sometimes people who appear in front of the Human Rights Commission, for example, may be asked to take the oath. The honourable senator should know by now that Senate committees also have that power. It is not a power confined only to courts of law where legal representation of people pertains. In fact, many years ago when I had a job sorting mail during the Christmas vacation, as many of us might have done in those years, I was required, as a member of the Australian post work force, to take an oath too. Therefore, the honourable senator is not correct on that point.

I wish to commend the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 as I stand in support of it. I also draw honourable senators' attention to the excellent second reading speech by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) which set out very precisely and cogently the history of this Bill-the history of the emergence of rights established through the United Nations with its universal declaration of human rights in 1948 and, following that, the procedures through the United Nations until the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights was eventually developed. Subsequent to that in this country, the Australian Government became a signatory to that Covenant in 1972. In 1980 the then Government ratified the Covenant. In fact it was quite interesting for me to hear some of the Opposition senators speaking so vociferously against many of the points in this proposed legislation, in particular the changes in the Human Rights Commission, with no regard, so it seemed to me, to the origins of the Human Rights Commission Act in this Parliament. That legislation was introduced by the Fraser Government and to the extent that it moved to honour Australia's ratification under that International Covenant, I think it was a very useful first step. This Government is arguing that it is insufficient to have administrative procedures only. It is important for us to move towards a Bill of Rights specifying what those rights are.

The second reading speech also develops very well arguments why rights under common law are insufficient. I wish to move to some specific examples of where the common law has certainly failed to preserve rights and it may come as no surprise to the Senate and to certain honourable senators that I wish to take up that argument in terms of the history of the rights of women. I found it very interesting to discover some of the history of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. This Act really was a sequel to an Act known as Lord Brougham's Act, an Act for shortening the language used in Acts of Parliament. This was introduced into British law in 1850. It stated:
In all Acts words importing the masculine gender shall be deemed and taken to include females.

Henry Brougham, after whom many streets in South Australia are named-I would be pleased to know whether there are streets named after him in other States-was one of the members of a group of reforming Whigs associated with the Great Reform Bill, the abolition of the slave trade, restrictions on the use of child labour in factories and others. He is best known for his efforts in the field of law reform, having staked his claim with a speech that lasted six hours and three minutes in the House of Commons on 7 February 1828. I am sure that Senator Harradine, for example, might be positively envious of that kind of opportunity. He finished his speech with the following quote and I wish to read it into the Hansard record because it goes very much to the heart of what the Bill of Rights legislation is about:

It was the boast of Augustus . . . that he found Rome of brick and left it of marble . . . But how much nobler will be the Sovereign's boast, when he shall have it to say, that he found the law dear and left it cheap; found it a sealed book-left it a living letter; found it the patrimony of the rich-left it the inheritance of the poor; found it the two-edged sword of craft and oppression-left it the staff of honesty and the shield of innocence.

I think that is what the Bill of Rights legislation proposed here is all about. In fact, that speech resulted in the appointment of, in effect, the Law Amendment Society or one of the early what could be called law reform commissions established in 1844. It looked at much of the law in England at that time with a view to what changes were necessary. Lord Brougham introduced his Act for shortening the language used in Acts of Parliament but, as the note I have here says, he was not necessarily inspired by any view of the status of women in society. In fact, he was trying to make sense and order of the legislation in Britain at the time. In particular I shall read again this line:
When the word he is used or the masculine gender it shall be taken to include she.

However, this clause was not included in all Acts or even in the majority of them. Some statutes used the word `person' to cover both genders, others used only `his'. However, the article explains that if it should say `having explosives in his possession' it was highly likely that the court would interpret that to cover a woman, if she should have explosives in her possession. That kind of consistency was not applied through legislation. I move to some specific examples. Lord Sankey, in reviewing the law in the course of his judgment in Henrietta Muir Edwards v. Attorney-General for Canada in 1930, a case concerning the rights of women to be summoned to the Canadian Senate, commented:
The passing of Lord Brougham's Act in 1850 does not appear to have greatly affected the current authority.
In Chorlton v. Lings in 1868, for example, it was held:

That the statement in section 3 of the Representation of the People Act 1867 (U.K.), that every `man' was entitled to be registered as a voter did not mean that women were entitled to vote despite Lord Brougham's Act.

Lord Sankey in Edwards v. Attorney-General for Canada noted that John Stuart Mill had moved an unsuccessful amendment to the Representation of People Act 1867 to leave out `man' and insert `person' in an attempt to secure women's suffrage. Even this right might not have had the desired effect, however, since the House of Lords held in a case Nairn v. University of St Andrews in 1909 in the Representation of the People (Scotland) Act that the word `person' did not entitle women to be registered to vote. The basis of this decision appears to have been that at common law women were under a disability to hold public office, vote or take part in the administration of justice and that it could not have been the intention of Parliament to remove that disability without express words to that effect.

I find the examples cited are very telling even in the case of the common law that specified rights for man to include woman where judgments clearly indicated that was not the understanding means that we have evidence, even under the common law, going to rights for citizens that have been used to exclude women from those rights, in particular the right to vote. Our country has, I think, a fairly honourable history of giving the right to vote to women. I certainly stand proud as a member of the South Australian community because that was the first State in Australia to give the right to vote to women. However, it is also a matter of history that the common law has not guaranteed rights for women. I think there are any number of telling examples of rights under the law which were not held to be available to all citizens. One only has to look to the history of Aboriginals in this country to understand how those rights did not pertain to Aboriginals. No doubt Aboriginals had a different set of difficulties to contend with but, under the common law, women were held to be in disability. Some 100 years later I am pleased to see, without even specifically being so worded by judgments of the court, that women no longer are seen to have that disability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Marvellous. They have that without it being mentioned in a Bill of Rights.

—I will come to Senator Lewis's interjection in a minute. I ask the honourable senator to bide his time. In 1959 Mrs Jessie Cooper was elected to the Legislative Council in South Australia. She was elected legitimately but her right to take her seat in the Legislative Council was opposed by a lawyer claiming that she was not eligible to take her seat in the Parliament on the grounds that she was a woman and therefore not a person under the Act. I understand that in fact that case was defended by a lawyer at that time, Don Dunstan. It was judged in favour of Mrs Cooper. The then Premier, Sir Thomas Playford, immediately introduced a constitutional amendment Bill to correct the anomaly. Let it be said that, consequent on Senator Lewis's interjections, specific legislation had to be introduced to guarantee woman's rights under the Common Law that supposedly covered them. Further, one has to look only at the history of sex discrimination legislation in this country, either in the State legislation or the Federal legislation, to know that in spite of Senator Lewis's interjection we achieved a lot of those gains without a Bill of Rights. It is quite clear that we achieved a lot of those gains by specific legislation going to those rights precisely because under the common law insufficient guarantee of rights was established.
—That is our argument.

—That is our argument entirely. I am delighted to hear that Senator Lewis agrees with us. The point I have been making is that the common law is insufficient to guarantee specific rights. I think the history of women's rights bears clear evidence of that. Another point made about the Bill of Rights legislation is that it will have a vital educative function. As was stated in the second reading speech, it will have:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the capacity to inspire respect for fundamental freedoms and liberties by setting out rights in positive declaratory form.

Lest it be wondered by honourable senators opposite whether it is necessary to have an educative function about rights, it certainly is. While I may be quoting from 1925, any of those of us who have gone around the country speaking in support of the sex discrimination legislation knows the battle we have in changing the minds and hearts of men and women. If any honourable senator has any further doubt I refer them to Senator Austin Lewis's extraordinary speech opposing the sex discrimination legislation in this place early last year.

I think it is important to understand that what we also are dealing with are prejudices and attitudes in society. A Bill of Rights will go a long way, through its very passage, to provoke society to consider those rights in a more specific and considered way. I think legislation has a considerable educative role. When we have to contend with remarks such as the one I am about to read I think it is vital that we have a Bill of Rights. An MLA in the New South Wales Parliament, one Theo Hill, was opposing on a number of grounds a Bill by Lang to clarify the rights of women to be appointed to the Upper House. It put women into a position that `the Almighty Himself never intended they should occupy'. It meant unsexing women. He stated:
. . . the women of the party I support do not believe in unsexing themselves . . . very few decent, pure-minded women . . . believe in this kind of game and want to come into Parliament.
He further stated:
It has been asserted by biologists and other scientists again and again that the brain of woman is much less than that of the average man. What we want in Parliament is brain power.

That, I must say, was in 1925. However, if one reads the history of the advancement of women in a book recently released through Melbourne University called Liberation by Degrees we see that the most thoughtful academicians of the time presented just that sort of argument, seriously and over and over again. Somehow biology and science was in support of the denial of rights of women. It is interesting even to consider that if science should indicate that somebody had a lesser brain, for example a retarded person, would the law, according to this logic, deny such people their appropriate rights? I am pleased to say that the Bill of Rights and the associated Bill to establish the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will go directly to the rights of those people who may have less than full capacities.

I would like now to move to a few comments about the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill. The arguments opposing this legislation I find are quite remarkable especially as they are coming from the Opposition which, when in government, introduced the original Human Rights Commission legislation. The proposed changes I think go to strengthening that Commission to being more clear and precise about its powers and to incorporate the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and the Race Discrimination Commissioner within that general commission. Before I move to more specific comments about that I draw the Opposition's attention to a quote by Senator Durack when he summed up the need for the Commission in introducing the Human Rights Commission Bill in 1981. He said:
I believe, and the Government believes-
that is the then Fraser Government-

that in an era of social change in which governments exercise wide powers and corporations and large institutions greatly influence the lives of individuals, it is important to have an agency that is active in the protection and promotion of the rights of individuals.

I presume that Senator Durack still stands by that quotation and that position; in fact, I certainly hope he does. Of course, the Government has no objection to the establishment of the Human Rights Commission, although any opposition would be on the basis that it is not a sufficient way of dealing with the consolidation of rights under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That is why, as I said earlier, the Government has moved to establish the Bill of Rights to go, so to speak, hand in glove with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill and the modifying Bills.

It is important to deal with some of the wild claims of Senator Knowles about the Human Rights Commission. In particular, I refer honourable senators to the report last year of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Pam O'Neil. She reported that within 12 months 877 complaints had already been brought before that Commission. Prior to that report, Peter Bailey, in an argument addressing criticisms of the Human Rights Commission, said:
. . . some 10,000 people have sought help from the Commission . . .-
that is the Human Rights Commission-
In almost all these cases, the complainant had nowhere else to go.

I think the evidence of how the Human Rights Commission has functioned, albeit it struggling with the vast area it has to cover, and, more recently, the Sex Discrimination Commission in the Commonwealth sphere and, in my own state experience, the Sex Discrimination Commission under the Equal Opportunity Commission in South Australia, shows that those establishments, those institutions, are remarkably effective.

Many of the complaints brought against this kind of proposal go to the fact that the solution to many problems will be reached by conciliation rather than by a judicial, adversary, confrontationist approach. On any examination of the evidence of the cases already brought before those commissions, it is quite clear that the conciliatory approach is most effective. Apart from anything else, it is very much cheaper. If people wish to argue in terms of the hard dollar, they would certainly have to come down in support of conciliation. More importantly many of the complaints brought before these commissions deal with matters that go to the hearts of people as much as to their heads. People are aggrieved; people are angry; people are suffering a sense of hurt as much as a sense of injustice and the conciliatory approach allows for that dimension of a human to be dealt with very effectively rather than any hard calculation of what one's just deserts might be. I do not think that the importance of that approach can be understated. The clear, satisfactory resolution of something like two-thirds of the complaints brought in South Australia through the Equal Opportunity Commission have proved without any doubt that the conciliatory approach is very effective. In shorthand, it leaves people in a win-win situation rather than a win-lose situation.

The confrontationist approach, which is sometimes the way we have to go and sometimes necessary, does not necessarily deal most satisfactorily with problems that we could call very often human dilemma problems. The conciliatory approach that is present and provided for under the structure of the commissions and the process for their dealing with complaints have to be strongly supported. I would certainly speak strongly in support of it.

Much can be said about these pieces of legislation. I will leave other senators to take up many of the issues that I have not touched on. In summary, it seems to me that support for the Bill of Rights can be argued on any number of grounds. I wanted to argue in particular that a Bill of Rights, specifying which particular rights we are addressing and guaranteeing those rights for every citizen in this country, is not, as Senator Knowles would suggest, a litany of the things that this Labor Government, and all the other things she called it, using colourful adjectives, is intending to do. In fact, we are writing certain rights into the Bill to ensure that they never become problems in this community. We may not ever have had slavery, although I would have thought that the conditions of some people in this country in the early nineteenth century might have been approaching slavery. There were certainly people who lived in wretched poverty, and their conditions were akin to slavery. The rights of the Chinese in the gold rush days were certainly very much held in question. I would have thought that to enshrine things that we perhaps have never done does not mean that we intend to do them in the future; in fact we are writing into the Bill of Rights our proposed guarantee that they will never occur in this country.

In talking briefly to the legislation, I mentioned how the law, except in a few very select cases that I used to make a point, under the common law has not guaranteed rights for women. Under the Bill of Rights legislation, those rights for women are specifically guaranteed and mentioned. I commend the establishment of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. By this Government's specific legislation and this proposal it is to include the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and the Race Discrimination Commissioner to allow them more properly to continue with the tasks that were originally intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on this legislative package-the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill and cognate Bills-has been long by any standards and it will be fairly long from now on. I do not wish to hold up the Senate for an unduly long period. It is quite interesting to see that 19 speakers are still listed to speak on the Bills and, of those, only three are from the Government side. That shows the concern that this side of the chamber has for this piece of legislation. I do not believe that any senator on this side of the chamber ought to let this legislative package pass without registering the strongest objections. I believe that the community has been kept in the dark. I believe that the government of the day has not informed the people about this piece of legislation and that it should be left to lie on the table for some time so that the people in the community can really look at it and understand it before it is passed through this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The best and kindest thing one can say about this legislation is that it is unnecessary. Unfortunately, I am also a part of the so-called lunatic fringe to which Senator Haines and others have referred that believes the Australian Bill of Rights Bill to be more than just unnecessary. There are some very worrying aspects in this legislation.

Senator Parer expressed my sentiments very clearly when he put three simple propositions. He said that the Bill was not necessary to protect rights; it was not sufficient to protect rights; and, as presented, it would simply serve as a political weapon for the Federal Government to use to attack State governments of different persuasions. The Senate is a States' House. Basically, this Bill is an attack on this House. One must ask why the Government felt it necessary to bring on this legislation. At best, it has had a checkered history. When it was last mooted prior to the Federal election in 1983-might I add that it was hushed up before the election-the present Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, was reported as saying that he thought the Bill should be thrown out.

I regard the Bill as unnecessary as in Australia people already have their rights listed. People have the right to marry. They have the rights to have children. They have the protection of the law. They have the rights of free speech and of free association. They have the full protection of the judicial system. They have the right to elect governments of their choice and to remove them if they want to-and that is what will happen at the next Federal election.

Two arguments are involved. Firstly, if legislation is required to enshrine those basic rights, why is it not necessary to enshrine others? The most common examples are the right to own private property, the right of an individual not to join a trade union and the right to send one's children to a school of one's choice. Why have these rights been left out? Surely it cannot be a mere drafting error. This legislation has been wallowing around Labor Party agendas for years. Why have these anomalies not been corrected and why can they not be corrected now? If the Labor Government is genuine in its efforts to provide basic rights for all Australians, why does it not put those rights in? Is it because those basic rights-the right to private ownership of property, the right not to join a trade union, and the right to send one's children to a school of one's choice-are not acceptable to the trendy Reds who support this Bill? Maybe the burgundy socialists on the other side do not like those rights being included.

The second argument concerns the form in which these rights that the Government says so desperately need protecting are written. If the Government is genuine in its desire to enshrine these rights for all Australians now and forever, why include them in a piece of legislation that will simply be thrown out after the next election? How genuine is this Government in claiming that it wants to protect the rights of all Australians? If it is genuine, why not have a referendum on the subject and change the Constitution? The answer is very obvious and it knows it: The majority of Australians simply do not want this legislation and would throw it out if a referendum were held. They are not persuaded by the rhetoric of honourable senators opposite.

Of course, that same majority of people would also not be impressed by what the Australian Democrats say on the subject, if only they knew the Democrats' view. Maybe it will change during debate on the subject. The Democrats have such a knack of vacillating that one could be forgiven for not knowing what they think of the Bill of Rights. However, it now appears that the vote of the Democrats will allow this legislation to be passed. That same majority of Australians who do not want the Bill of Rights will remember who supported its passage and at the next election will vote them out of this place.

I am sure that every senator has received mail similar to that which has poured into my office at the rate of some 100 letters a day. Some letters are from organised groups such as church, community or business groups. Many are from the proverbial `fair-minded person' who is not in the habit of taking on ratbag issues or ratbag causes. I would like to quote from a letter written by a Mr E. O. O'Donnell which was published in a newspaper recently. I think it sums up the matter pretty well. It reads:
Why Australians should need a Bill of Rights such as that passed by the House of Representatives is a mystery to me.
This Bill of Rights is being foisted upon us. There is no popular demand for it.
In fact many Australians are so busy trying to balance their budgets that they don't really know anything about this dangerous Bill of Rights.

The rights which Australians already have are freedom of thought, conscience, religion and expression and also the right to own property, the right to utilise our natural wealth and talents and to dispose of them as we think fit.
Australians have the right to marry and to found a family, the right to rear their children and instruct them in the religion of their choice.

Australians also have the right to join a union or association or not to join a union or association, the right to question those who invade our rights and to invoke the protection of our courts, the right to a public and fair trial, the right to confront and question those who accuse us, the right to call witnesses, and refuse to testify against themselves.
Australia's heritage of rights and freedom is protected by the accumulative process of statute law, common law and precedent.
Our system of checks and balances protects against the abuse of an individual's dignity.
If rights are defined in an Act of Parliament does a right exist if it is not included?
It seems that the right to own property may not be in this Bill of Rights.
A Bill of Rights can only work to protect civil rights when it is sponsored by the people to correct abuses by a government.

The Australian Bill of Rights seems to be the machinery being set up to control us while we are being made into a Socialist Republic and then taken into a World Government, which will not respect the rights nor the dignity of the individual.
This Bill of Rights must be defeated if we are not to live in fear and insecurity.

TALK.START.PARA: —What idiot wrote that?
—I do not think this gentleman is an idiot. He is one of the voters in Australia. Senator Chipp may find at the next election that he will have his say. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The money, tax-payers' money, used to set up and maintain the Human Rights Commission would be better spent to lower the taxes of the struggling rural community.
In my opinion all politicians trying to foist this Bill on us should be sacked at the next elections.

An enormous mass of people are genuinely frightened about this legislation and they have every right to be. That is why I suggested earlier that it should most probably be allowed to lie on the table. The Government, in every debate on the subject, has not answered the simple question: Why is this legislation necessary? It keeps quoting the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. My good friend Senator Cooney on the other side of the House talked at some length on this point. I might add that he interspersed it with a great deal of legal history. It is good to see that he has not been so entirely corrupted by this place that he cannot remember some of his former vocation. However, I regret that I cannot agree with his arguments, and I am not sure that he is being entirely consistent. He said that the Bill cannot include things such as the right not to join a trade union and the right to private ownership of property because only rights that can be enforced against the Commonwealth and Commonwealth officers can be included. But he went on to quote Lord Scarman who stated:
A new Bill of Rights could establish guiding principles that would set standards for politicians, administrators and judges.

What sort of standards are we setting if we are not being consistent? If we include the right to join a trade union, surely if we are to establish guiding principles, we must include the right not to join a trade union. It is these sorts of omissions that frighten the average Australian. It is the comments from those opposite about using the Bill of Rights to change electoral systems in States which are of a different political persuasion from that of the present Government that also frighten people. Will we become the equivalent of the Philippines where, if one does not like the election results, one just changes them? Where does that leave basic human rights and basic democratic rights?

The final point I wish to raise-and it is one that has been raised by others-is how one explains why countries which do not have a Bill of Rights are able to operate in a fair, democratic manner with a most workable common law system--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is that?

—The United Kingdom-with freedom of the individual assured, and at the same time we have countries with rights listed in great numbers while the citizens of those countries have few basic rights of freedom of speech, association and religious persuasion. The Soviet Union, of course, is a classic example. Of what value is its Bill of Rights? The legislation is all the things that the Opposition has claimed it is: At best unnecessary, at worst a dangerous threat to democracy in Australia. The Government's arguments in support of the Bill simply do not stand up. Its motives in introducing it are purely political. It has nothing to do with wanting to protect the rights of all Australians, because we have that already. But those people who are concerned about this legislation will have to wait only until the next election to have their say and express their will on the Bill of Rights. I have no doubt that the Bill of Rights, and those people who thrust it on the community, will be removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) introduced the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 he made the claim that a Bill of Rights will `provide real and significant protections for rights and freedoms essential to real democracy'. The point, of course, is that this Bill does not even guarantee the citizens the right to vote at State elections. The type of claims and counter-claims that have been made must leave members of the public who have read or listened to this debate utterly bewildered.

SPEECH.PARA: Probably one of the best speeches made to date on this Bill was made by a Liberal senator, Senator Missen, when he referred to the various letters that have been written in this campaign and pointed out the fallacies they contained. He pointed out that time and again the gross misrepresentation that has been going on has obviously been done with a view not to informing the public rather, to misinforming the public. The activity has been one of generating whatever political head of steam it has been possible to generate and then giving it a twist and a bit more of a distortion, regardless of what the Bill says, regardless of what the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights says and regardless of what the legal situation will be after such a Bill is enacted. One expects this type of thing fairly constantly but I do think it is quite extraordinary that we have had standing in this place so many honourable senators who obviously have not even read the Bill of Rights. If they had, they would understand its legal extent and its legal capacity; they would understand where the thrusts are and where they cannot be; they would understand the problems of the International Covenant and the adherence to it in cases such as the Tasmanian dams case and the Koowarta case; and they would understand what the Federal Government is about and what it was relying on, as a head of power, in putting this piece of legislation into the Parliament. I can understand people disagreeing with it, bringing arguments forward as to why it should not be in its present form and suggesting improvements or even suggesting that the whole Bill should be thrown out. Some of those arguments have been put forward, but very few.

The simple and indisputable fact in this whole debate is that, if one accepts that there is a need for a Bill of Rights, it logically follows that it must apply not only to Commonwealth law but also to State and local government law. The absurdity that we are about to have thrust upon us in the Bowen Bill is that somehow the individual citizen is divisible. An individual citizen in this country is governed by Federal law, by State law and by local government regulations. We are saying: `We will fix up the Federal law, but we don't mind really whether those rights-and almost identical rights-are denied to you by State law or by local government law. We don't mind that and we don't intend doing anything about it, but we will get terribly concerned if it is Federal law'. If one looks at Federal legislation, one has to go a long way to find a breach of human rights. Indeed, in the last few years this chamber has been responsible for scrutinising every piece of legislation that comes into this chamber with that as one of its criteria. A fair amount of the work has been done by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

The Veterans' Entitlements Bill which we had before us and which will be coming back, presumably, in a few weeks readily illustrates this point. The Liberal Party of Australia picked up some 33 suggested amendments from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee; the Government has accepted 32 of them. That is the type of work that is currently being done on this issue at the Commonwealth level. We are going through an exercise which is exclusively concerned, in a legislative way, with the laws which are passed by the Commonwealth Parliament. Under the terms of this Bill, those laws will not be affected for another five years. So we will find ourselves in the situation five years down the track of having to look at some of the legislation that has already been passed. Insofar as the Parliament requires it, it will apply to new pieces of legislation. It has been pointed out in the report of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, a report signed not only by Labor Party members of that Committee but also by Liberal Party members, that the major abuses of human rights in Australia occur at the State and local government levels, not at the Federal level. It is the States which control the police; it is the States which, by and large, make industrial relations laws; it is the States which have electoral laws which rort the system; and, according to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, it is the States which most frequently violate the civil and political rights of Australian citizens.

When a State is run by a non-democratically elected minority government, such as my own State of Queensland, there clearly has to be a tendency for such a government to pass laws which are ill-conceived, badly drafted, authoritarian and against the citizens of those States. Time and again we find that the moderate voices within my own State of Queensland are not heard; they are brushed aside. The State Government does not have to respond to political or public opinion. In those circumstances, the Government becomes more and more authoritarian and passes more and more laws which violate the basic rights of its citizens. It is able to do this because it is quite capable of ignoring public opinion. But when one looks at other States and at the Commonwealth one finds that, under any political party, the governments there must pay close and continuing attention to public opinion and to the niceties of the laws which they are passing. There is not a wide range of things about which any government can legislate; it has a very narrow band indeed, provided that government is democratically elected and can be voted out of office. We find ourselves now with a proposed law which has been brought in by the Attorney-General that does very little other than regularise what is already being done at the Commonwealth level and it is being called an Australian Bill of Rights.

I and other senators have received hundreds-in fact, in my case thousands-of letters. Most of those letters are merely roneoed letters. Many of these people have never read the Bill and have accepted in good faith the propositions put to them by whoever has handed out the piece of paper. I suppose we must expect those types of things to occur. When one reads those letters one finds, time and again, the suggestion that somehow or other the legislation will apply to State laws or to local government laws. It will do nothing of the sort. It will allow a commission to make a report on those matters. I think every honourable senator in the chamber is very much aware that, if the Government has not got the guts to take them on in this Bill, this exercise is simply a sham exercise for the purposes of political consumption.

If we look at the debate which took place in the House of Representatives on 14 November last year, we will see that five Labor members stood up and cited the infamous Queensland gerrymander, the draconian industrial laws and so on as an excuse for passing this Bill. They were offering them as examples of why we need this Bill of Rights. They are good examples, but the fact of the matter is that the Bill does not even apply to them. The Attorney-General reiterated in Question Time today the point that it does not apply to them. It will not do a lot about those types of offensive laws and practices which Government members have identified as the reason why this Bill should be voted for. Not only have many Opposition members not even read the Bill but also, obviously, a considerable number of the Labor Party members who spoke in the House of Representatives had not bothered reading their own Bill and were in total ignorance of what their Government proposed to do. They were lauding it about doing something about those laws in Queensland, when it does not do anything except give the right to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to make a report. I understand that there is a move by some Labor Party members to remove from the Bill the right of the Commission to make a report; to fill up another piece of paper, to put it on another shelf. That particular exercise, if it is for the consumption of the Labor Party members and their branches, is an exercise in the utmost political cynicism.

Many people in Australia have fought for years and years to try to have a Bill of Rights and they do not want this type of sham exercise being perpetrated. If we are to have one, let us have a genuine attempt, not this exercise that is trotted out as genuine with a title such as the Australian Bill of Rights.

This Bill is based on Article 50 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I admit that in listening to Senator MacGibbon I had not heard of the story he mentioned, but I had assumed that everybody was aware that this Bill is based on the International Covenant. Article 50 of the International Covenant is the cornerstone and the head of the Commonwealth being able to get a lever on this particular Bill. For the information of a number of senators on the Opposition side who did not seem to be aware of it, I point out that the Covenant was signed by the Menzies Government-the Menzies conservative Liberal-Country Party Government, if they cannot remember who Sir Robert Menzies was. It was ratified by the Liberal-National Party Government of Mr Fraser. I heard three speakers today referring to it as having been ratified and signed by the Hawke Government. I wish that honourable senators would have a look at the history of what has happened to that International Covenant and how Australia got involved with it. Under article 50 our Government willingly and of its own accord undertook:
The provisions of the present Covenant shall extend to all parts of federal States without any limitations or exceptions.

There were reservations with regard to a number of sections and those reservations have been removed by the Hawke Government which refers to all parts of federal states without limitations or exceptions. The October 1984 withdrawal of the reservations to that Article were undertaken by the Hawke Government, presumably to bolster Australia's standing in the international community. If it is going to seek to bolster its own image and the image of Australia in the international community by withdrawing those reservations, I suggest that it ought to undertake the obligations that those reservations place upon us, otherwise why go through that exercise? Why would Government members tote themselves around other countries saying: `Aren't we good fellows? Look what we have done. We have removed these reservations. We will now apply it to all parts of our federal system'? Then they sneak back here and bring in this type of bill and expect people to say: `Good on you'.

We believe that if there is to be an Australian Bill of Rights it must extend to States and to the power that is contained within the States to deny Australian citizens those human rights which are detailed in this Bill at the Federal level. I draw upon an example used by Senator MacGibbon when he said that he did not see any reason for there being a reference to slavery. It is an interesting section. The Federal Government is proposing to say that the Federal Government will not be allowed to enslave anybody, but it is all right if State governments do. That is an utter absurdity. Even if the thing itself is a bit of an absurdity in Australia's political life-I take Senator MacGibbon's point and I think we are both thankful that Australia is not a place where such a thing would occur-I draw the analogy that it is an absurdity to make such a proposition, again because a citizen is not divisible in terms of his human rights. There is one set of rights for one citizen, and this notion that it can be divided is a quaint one for the political purposes but an utterly useless one when it comes to the rights of those individual citizens.

The Attorney-General is not serious in his commitment. He is not serious about having a committment to implement in Australia that International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. He is not or he would have brought in a Bill to do so. The shame of the exercise is that to date the Labor Party has stood behind the Attorney-General on this. Many of those people who in their private lives and public capacities have fought strongly on past occasions now intend presumably to roll up their blanket and steal away in the night. For what reason? Essentially because the Hawke Government does not want to buy a fight with the Queensland Government. It is as simple as that; it is scared. So we find ourselves confronted with this anaemic operation; so anaemic that we will be very lucky if the thing does not bleed to death before we get to the end of it.

The Australian Democrats, as our spokesperson Senator Haines has already foreshadowed, will move a series of amendments supporting some of the amendments proposed by the Opposition. I put on record now that it is my intention that if this Bill does not apply to States, I will not support it, because I have absolutely no intention of taking part in the sham which is contained in this Bill. Serious denials of personal liberties and civil rights are occurring in Australia every day. We wring our hands at the international scene with regard to the Philippines, but when it comes to home we do not do a thing. We are very good at lecturing people around the world about how they should treat their indigenous people, but when it comes to the people of this country we will not do a thing. The hypocrisy of the whole exercise might be able to be undertaken by others, but I will not lend my vote to it. Unless this Bill applies to all citizens and all jurisdictions, I do not intend to vote for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are opposed to the Bill now?

—If the amendments which will be moved by Senator Haines on behalf of the Australian Democrats are not accepted, I intend to vote against the Bill, yes. I believe that it would be far better to go on outside of this place fighting for a genuine Bill of Rights, although it may take another 20, 30 or 40 years, than to subscribe to this little exercise of political opportunism because members of a few Labor Party branches want to make themselves feel good. We have a chance to do something for the citizens of this country in a way that has to be done because we know what is going on. We have all seen what is going and those of us who have lived in Queensland have experienced it, even if people in other States have not. It might be all right for people in some of the other States-where some of the rights put on the agenda by State governments are in excess of those given here-to say that there is not much of a problem, but I suggest that they should think beyond that to all of the citizens of Australia and think about what is needed in all areas of Australia with regard to this matter. The Attorney-General's actions are particularly disturbing in the light of the number of statements he has made.
