DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Sydney, New South Wales: Second International Airport-Balance of Payments-Australian Capital Territory: Fire Service

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under the sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of issues tonight, the first of which is the announcement this evening by the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) that the Government has decided that Badgerys Creek should be the site for Sydney's second international airport. As I said here the other day it was an open secret that the Premier of New South Wales was rushing around the place touting Badgerys Creek in a private way. Heaven knows why! It was inevitable that in those circumstances the right wing machine in Sydney would do whatever Neville Wran wanted. The fact that it is a ludicrous decision is, of course, beside the point.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also significant that the Australian Labor Party members from the Illawarra region who at least told their constituents that they were fighting for Wilton as the potential second site for an airport have had such a dramatic impact on the Cabinet that in fact the decision that has been made totally rejects everything that they suggested. I must say that the failure of the Labor members for the Illawarra region to have their point of view accepted is most unfortunate for the Illawarra region itself. However, it is perhaps even more unfortunate for the people of the south-western region of Sydney-the people living in the Badgerys Creek area-whose worst fears will now be realised.

Apart from anything else, the decision is curious in the sense of the extraordinary costs that will now be involved. The acquisition of the 1,770 hectare site which is 46 kilometres west of Sydney at Badgerys Creek is estimated to be in the range of $33m to $34m whereas the Wilton site would have cost about $1.8m. There is an incredible difference between $33m and $1.8m. Only one dwelling would have been affected on the Wilton site. By comparison, 750 people will have to leave their homes as a result of the Cabinet decision to site the second airport at Badgerys Creek.

Frankly, I do not believe that the airport will go ahead. The clear and sensible alternative is the one that the previous Federal Government endeavoured to convince the State Government of New South Wales it should proceed with, and that was, of course, the parallel runway system at Mascot. It is all very well for Ministers in this place to say that the Fraser Government managed to achieve nothing in respect of a second airport or Mascot and that it has been up to this Government to do something. It is all very well for them to say that the people of Badgerys Creek in particular have been held on a string for so long because the previous Government failed to come to a conclusion. The reality is that the previous Government favoured, supported and struggled to get the parallel runway proposal at Mascot accepted by the New South Wales Government and that the New South Wales Government simply point blank refused to accept that proposition. The New South Wales Government even threatened not to supply services provided by the State to the Commonwealth at Mascot if in fact Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport was expanded in the way the previous Government had required it to be expanded in order to meet the air traffic requirements of Sydney.

There can be nothing to justify the choice of Badgerys Creek except one thing, and that is that it provided Neville Wran with a very good weapon with which to beat the Federal Government over the head because at this stage there is simply no major trunk road going to Badgerys Creek. In other words, if the Federal Government goes ahead with this expensive acquisition it will then have the massive expense of providing the infrastructure, the roads and perhaps the rail link, to service passengers who arrive at Sydney's fanciful-in fact it will no doubt be mythical-second airport. I say that because the airport will not go ahead. However, Wran will no doubt be seeking to get the Federal Government to meet the costs of providing those services. So naturally it is a sensible, if slightly cunning, approach by the Premier and more sweat to his elbow if he can screw some money out of the Federal Government to provide the transport links to this place. If he can do so, so much the better for him.

The reality is that Wilton is very close to a major trunk road, the Hume Freeway which, of course, links Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne. In addition, a new railway line runs alongside the boundaries of the area. For the most part the site is on the Metropolitan Water and Sewerage Board land. Although some people have suggested that such a development could pollute Sydney's water supply, the information that I have is that that risk is simply non-existent, that such a claim is a device simply to substantiate some of the emotional protests which simply do not stand up.

The fact is that the Wilton site would provide a magnificent service to the southern parts of Sydney and to the Illawarra region which are growing areas with some of the worst unemployment levels in Australia. The Wilton site would be within a reasonable driving distance of the south-western suburbs of Sydney which, as you would know, Mr President, are major growth areas. Certainly the rail link would have the capacity to provide very quick transport. In fact, I would suggest that although Wilton is 80 kilometres from Sydney one would be able to travel far more quickly from that site than one could from the Badgerys Creek site which is 46 kilometres from Sydney. In addition, according to draft plans, the very fast train proposed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation would be able to travel very quickly past the Wilton site.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would stop there; it would not go past.
—As Senator Harradine quite rightly says, air travellers will hope that it stops at Wilton; travellers like us going to Canberra will hope that it goes past.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is, of course, that neither site will proceed. It is all pie in the sky. There is no way that this project will go ahead. This is simply a device by which the State Government of New South Wales has done a deal with the Federal Government to make it look as if it is trying to protect Labor seats-the wobbly Labor Party seats around the Botany Bay area where there has been continual protest about Mascot. I would be very surprised if we do not hear shortly from the Minister for Aviation that Mascot is to be upgraded and expanded; who knows, there may be a subtle decision to construct a parallel runway. I believe that this is what will happen, despite all the talk about the construction of another airport in Sydney.

I wish to refer briefly to another matter. I want to follow up some of the remarks I made on Thursday night about the balance of payments figures. On that occasion I said that the Government clearly had to revise its balance of payments current account deficit forecast for 1985-86 which has already worsened from $10.7 billion to $11.25 billion. I suggested then that the joint economic forecasting group's predictions, as reported in the leak to the media, that this deficit would end up worse than $12 billion, if correct, should in fact now be formally acknowledged by the Federal Government. Whatever the latest forecast really is should be acknowledged by the Federal Government. There is no doubt now that, following the January figures, there is no chance of the published Government forecast being anything like reality. I know that in things like monetary targets the Government has in the past changed the target halfway through the game and has said: `Is it not marvellous that we have reached our target, having changed it?' Quite frankly, I much prefer it to do that. This is one of those occasions on which the Government is required, obliged, to advise the market of its view about the current account deficit.

I am getting even more concerned about the continual attempts to talk the situation up-to make it sound better than it is. All through the second half of the last calendar year, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was busily saying, as was Senator Walsh, that the Government's targets on the current account deficit were always on track and that there was no need to change them. We, on this side, kept saying: `Oh yes, there is'. Eventually, they did get changed a little. But what concerned me was that on Friday, as I understand it, the Treasurer addressed I think, the foreign exchange dealers in Sydney and said that he thought things were going wonderfully and that the January figures for the current account clearly showed that the positive impact of devaluation was now being felt on the balance of payments. Frankly, that is just bunkum. The figures dramatise it.

We had all these once-off elements in the January figures which simply are not going to be repeated. In the first place, we had a once-off switch from $200m-it was described as a downward timing adjustment by the statistician-because in fact the November figure had been understated as a result of some delays. I remind the Senate, of course, that the November figure had been welcomed with open arms by the Government because it was only $758m. It said: `Is it not wonderful? It shows that things are good'. In fact, that figure is now shown really to have been about a billion dollars.

We had another one-off element-$500m of cereal exports in January as against about $300m as the normal level. That, of course, related to a once-off wheat sale to Russia. We had the incredible situation of Australian oil exports exceeding imports for the seven months to January. That situation certainly will not continue, especially now that we have these massively falling prices. We are going to be hit harder by oil prices because we are exporting more now than we are importing. In any event, we are not going to be able to export for much longer because of the inevitable downturn in our production. So we have all these once-off factors which have certainly influenced this $944m January deficit and clearly indicated that, far from showing that things are improving, it is a particularly worrying figure. On top of that, there is the seasonality impact of about $241m because according to the statistician there was, in fact, a trade balance of $14m which, when adjusted for seasonal factors, ended up as a trade deficit of $227m. That is the essential figure. That is roughly in line with the average seasonally adjusted trade deficit for all the seven months so far this financial year. For Mr Keating to find in that figure any solace shows that he is, in fact, a most energetic seeker after the vaguest hint of an upturn. It is simply not there yet.

I plead with the Government, as I did last year: `Please come clean on telling the people of Australia what you really now believe the current account deficit will be for the current year'. We know perfectly well that it cannot reach its target of $11.25 billion because that would mean reducing the present average monthly deficit achieved so far in the seven months to January of $1.2 billion down to only $550m. That is simply impossible. I ask the Minister: `Please, come clean'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The people of the Australian Capital Territory have not been getting an adequate fire service for far too long. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) has admitted this, and we are entitled to ask what the Government is doing and what steps are being taken to provide adequate protection. I shall go through in precis form some of the background. We did not have complete peace in the fire service prior to October 1984 when the present Fire Commissioner took up his appointment. That was greeted with pickets on the brigade headquarters, a ban on the skyjet ladder vehicle, and a reassurance the next day that the union reaffirmed non-co- operation with the new fire chief. I shall not refer to everything that has occurred but merely highlight some of them.

SPEECH.PARA: By January 1985 we were told that 50 per cent of the fire engines were off the road due to breakdowns. Subsequently there was an article suggesting that many of the fire stations were in risk of closing, and it was disclosed that in the 1984-85 Budget the fire service had received $285,000 and not the $5m which it had sought and which was intended to upgrade and renovate buildings and replace equipment. It went on from there with bans on certain equipment. We were told by the union that five of the units were unsafe. Part of the problem is, of course, that the people of Canberra, who rely on this service to protect their property, do not really know where the truth lies in all of this and whether they are at risk. So it went on during 1985 with firemen occupying department offices, the Charnwood station closed and threats of further industrial action.

In July 1985 the Minister established an inquiry into the fire brigade. It was to be a formal inquiry to examine all aspects of the brigade. We were told that it would be wide-ranging, would not rule out the possibility of an inquiry examining the appointment of the Fire Commissioner, and would probably examine the administration operations, equipment, financial control and accountability of the fire brigade. At the time the unions described the inquiry, as quoted in the Canberra Times of 13 July, as a `delaying tactic'. I am beginning to wonder whether that was right.

That did not actually stop everything. Later that month, fire-fighters stopped work over disputed claims and there were a number of strikes threatened. Six fire stations closed down during lightning strikes in July 1985, and later that month most fire stations were closed because of stoppages. In early August 1985 we were greeted by a newspaper report which told us that no rolling stoppages had occurred for one week. I think most people would agree that, as far as adequate fire services are concerned, it is an extraordinary situation when we start boasting about there being no stoppages for a week. The Minister then placed a letter in the Canberra Times, at I imagine considerable expense, setting out his views of what had occurred and what the argument was all about. In it he said:
The people of Canberra are not getting an adequate fire service because of the industrial tactics of the Australian Capital Territory Branch of the Federal Fire-fighters' Union.

That may be perfectly true, but the important thing from our point of view is that we were not getting an adequate fire service, although one may think that in August it does not matter too much because it is not a likely time of year for a fire to be a serious problem. I will not read out the whole of the letter, or incorporate it because I think it would be unnecessary. It has been published and is readily available. Near the end the Minister says:

For all these reasons I am very concerned about the Fire Brigade. I am particularly concerned about the current and future management of the Brigade and that, primarily, is why I am establishing an inquiry to look at the Brigade's structure, its administration, financial controls and operations.

It is right that the Minister is concerned. I think it is right to say that we are entitled to be concerned, but as yet we have not had any solutions to it. The inquiry did not end everything. We still have not had a report. We have not received answers to the questions that were raised. `Stop work continues' was a headline which appeared in a newspaper in mid-August of last year. In September we were told that the dispute was to be heard. In October the headline `Firefighters dispute gears up again' appeared. The Phillip and Kambah fire stations were inoperative for a time and Phillip and Charnwood fire stations were closed for another period. In January certain bans remained. On 12 February the Fire Commissioner deplored the closure of the Ainslie fire station. Last Friday, 14 February, there was a fire at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. It was reported:
The ACT Fire Commissioner, Mr Bill Kerr, police officers and CSIRO staff fought a fire in a building at Black Mountain for about 30 minutes yesterday because fire-fighters were on strike.

The firemen had voted the previous day to go on strike. Apparently the first of four units did not arrive until 11.10 a.m. The police withdrew and the fire-fighters joined their Commissioner in putting out the fire. The union secretary affirmed that no fires would be attended by fire-fighters during the strike and the Minister issued a strongly worded statement condemning the strike. Nobody would disagree with him for doing that, but I come back to the point where I started: I think we are entitled to ask the Government what it is actually doing to give fire protection to the people of the Australian Capital Territory, especially at a time when the weather is probably as hot as it has been this summer. There is a lot of growth around and the fire danger must be fairly high. As I said, last August the Minister agreed and stated publicly that we were not getting an adequate fire service. It seems that nothing has improved.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the right honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The sum allocated in the current financial year for official entertainment and overseas representation allowance is as follows:
(a) By the Department including the Australian Development Assistance Bureau $1,896,007.
(b) Statutory Authorities.
(i) by the Australian Japan Foundation $16,000; and
(ii) by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. No specific allocation is made for hospitality/entertainment expenses.
2. The guidelines in force as at 1 September 1985 for expenditure from and overseas representational allowance official entertainment were:
(a) For Heads of Mission on long term overseas posting the guidelines are as follows:
Procedures on Head of Mission Representation Allowance and Representation Supplement

Upon commencing duties associated with his/her appointment, the Head of Mission shall be advanced an amount equal to one-fourth of the annual amount of vouched representation allowance as determined by the Minister. Three months after the day on which the Head of Mission commences duty at the post an advance equal to one fourth of the annual amount of representation allowance shall be payable to the Head of Mission of expenditure incurred in the previous three monthly period against the advance made. Advances are paid automatically and there is no need for the Head of Mission to apply for them. It will be appreciated, however, that if a vouching statement is not received following an advance, the Department cannot authorise further advances.

Expenditure is recorded by the Finance Section cumulatively (but separately from the advances) on the Head of Mission's ledger card, so that there is a running total of both advances and expenditure. Expenditure in non-Australian currency is recorded as closely as possible to the rate of exchange at which it occurs by using a weighted mean of exchange rates, i.e., the average of the rates used each fortnight over the vouching period for salary purposes.

The Department's check of vouching statements is limited to the arithmetic, the personal contribution percentage level, plus an examination of guest lists and incidental expenditure. It suffices for this purpose if the Head of Mission sends: (i) a financial summary sheet; (ii) his/her secretary's working copies of guest lists-with adequate description of principal guests-and jottings on these lists of the cost of the functions (in the currencies in which expense occurred) and a note of what receipts are held; (iii) a sheet recording incidental expenditure; and (iv) if they prefer to vouch that way, copies of accounts for bulk liquor/tobacco purchases. On the last, a minimum of five per cent and usually ten per cent should be deducted from the total purchase cost. Such deduction is to cover not only personal consumption by the Head of Mission and/or spouse, but also drinks and tobacco consumed (and catered for by representation supplement) in more informal entertainment and as gifts or tips. Clearly, if the amount so consumed is more than ten per cent, then that higher figure should be deducted. The only receipts to be sent to the Department are those for these bulk purchases; all others should be retained by the Head of Mission for production if called for. Heads of Mission who choose to vouch on a per capita basis should be able to substantiate the per capita figure with a sample menu if they are called upon to do so.

The system places responsibility on Heads of Mission to keep the Department promptly informed at the end of each representational quarter of the detail of representational expenditure. The rules regarding the acceptability of such expenditure are in Volume 2 of the Department's Manual of Information and Instructions. The text of the relevant paragraphs are repeated below:
Representation allowance is payable in two parts; a vouched representation allowance and a representational supplement.
Representational Allowance
Rules have been drawn up defining which items can be charged against a Head of Mission's vouched representation allowance. They include the following:

1. Entertainment of: (a) Local residents, diplomatic colleagues and members of the press; (b) Representatives of other countries; (c) Australian Ministers and Members of Parliament-both Federal and State; (d) Australian delegations; (e) Prominent Australians; (f) Australian businessmen, where visits have a direct bearing on relations between the two countries otherwise only when not the role guests.

2. (a) Deleted; (b) Invitation cards; (c) Visiting cards for wife; (d) Members of one club (other than that provided for in local allowance); (e) Wedding gifts, flowers, funeral wreaths, associated with events of a representational nature; (f) Donations to charitable causes-when associated with particular functions, occasion and activities; (g) Cost of accommodating Government Ministers and First Division officers and members of their families travelling officially; (h) Cost of accommodating visitors, other than Australian Second and Third Division public servants but only where other suitable accommodation is not available; (i) Flowers and additional servants, including overtime payments for members of the Official Residence domestic establishment, for entertainment in the Official Residence, but these costs should be shown as separate items.
Costs associated with Australian Day functions are not charged to a Head of Mission's representation allowance. They are included in the post's annual estimates and a special allowance is provided.
Representational Supplement

Heads of Mission are paid, on a fortnightly basis, an amount to cover the cost of items not considered to be an appropriate charge against the vouched representation allowance. This allowance does not have to be vouched. The following items should be met from the representational supplement:

(a) Casual social entertainment, including functions given by the Head of Missions's wife for wives of officers, wives of the Australian expatriate community, wives of visiting Australians, visiting officials, delegates, etc.
(b) Entertainment as sole guests of Australian public servants, Australia-based staff, Service Officers, locally-engaged staff
(c) Entertainment of other Australians as sole guests-except where the visit has a direct bearing on relations between the two countries.
(d) Accommodation of Australian Public Servants other than First Division officers and members of their families travelling officially
(e) Accommodation of other guests-where other suitable accommodation is not available
(f) Tips, gratuities to tradesman, businessmen, local officials, general service personnel (garbage collectors, postmen, street cleaners etc.), guards, watchmen, etc.
(g) Gifts and/or donations to retiring local and/or domestic staff
(h) Personal functions for Australia-based and/or local staff (e.g., Christmas parties and wedding receptions)
(i) Christmas or birthday presents, etc., for domestic staff
(j) Farewell gifts for domestic staff
(k) Gifts of liquor and cigarettes to local nationals
(l) Admission fees, flowers, etc., associated with the visits of Australian Ministers and wives, Australian officials, etc.
For other officers on long term overseas postings the guidelines contained in Finance Circular 1982/84 of 8 April 1982 are as follows:
Representation funds for officers on long term postings

Representation funds may be paid, in advance, to an officer who is occupying an established position at an overseas office or overseas Accounting Office, to enable him to establish or maintain the necessary liaison to perform his official duties.

2. Representation funds should not normally be provided to staff below the Class 5 level nor to locally engaged staff but such officers may be provided with representation funds for specific purposes.
Amount and frequency of payment

3. The Permanent Head shall decide that the amount and frequency with which representation funds shall be paid to an officer. If an amount is to be paid fortnightly, the payment shall be calculated on a seven day week basis.
4. Payment of representation funds shall commence on the day the officer takes up duty at the overseas office or overseas Accounting Office and cease on the day he finishes duty at that office.

5. Representation funds shall not be paid during leave taken after completion of a posting. During a `handover' period, a departing officer and his replacement may both be paid representation funds for a period not exceeding two weeks.
Representation funds statement

6. The Permanent Head should ensure that each officer in receipt of representation funds submits a Statement detailing the expenditure of these funds to him within six months of the commencement of payments of representation funds, or submission of the last Statement, and prior to the officer leaving an overseas office or overseas Accounting Office on completion of his posting. Itemised receipts of the expenditure shown on the Statement should be submitted, wherever possible, but it is not necessary that the full amount should be covered by receipts.
Over/under expenditure

7. The balance of any over or under expenditure of representation funds for each expenditure period is to be carried forward to the next expenditure period. However, where the officer ceases duty at the overseas office or overseas Accounting Office any amount unexpended at that time shall be repaid by the officer. Any expenditure in excess of the approved rate is the officer's own responsibility.
Admissible recipients and items
8. Before expending representation funds an officer should decide whether the expenditure is necessary and of specific value to Australia.
9. The rules relating to the expenditure of representation funds are set out in paragraphs 11 and 13. Those items which are not admissible are excluded for one of the following reasons:
the type of expenditure is not normally accepted as necessary to further Australia's interests (e.g. entertaining another public servant as a sole guest);
the item is included in local allowance or other moneys reimbursed to the officer (e.g. cost of servant's uniforms);
the time is included in representation supplement (e.g. gifts).
10. Representation funds normally are expendable only in respect of the country or countries in which the officer is posted.
Recipients
11. The following rules relate to the recipients of hospitality or other forms of representational expenditure:
(a) representatives of government, business and other appropriate circles of the countries in which officer is serving-Admissible
(b) representatives of other countries-Admissible
(c) members of the Australian and State parliaments-Admissible

(d) Permanent Heads of Departments Australian Heads of Mission, and other Australian Officials, eminent visitors or service personnel and Australian Embassy staffs-Only when not the sole guest. Admissible where functions are arranged to enable these people to meet local residents and others of assistance to their business, or where required to assist with or contribute materially to the function.
(e) Locally-engaged staff-Only where not the primary reason for the function and where contributing materially to the function.

It is expected that entertainment involving Australia-based or locally-engaged staff would be neither regular nor frequent. Moreover the proportion of such staff to other guests should reflect the fact that the latter are the raison d'etre for the function.
Items
12. The following rules relate to the admissibility of items for expenditure purposes: (Additional rules relating to Heads of Post are shown in 13)

Accommodation-rental, upkeep, gardening-Not admissible; visitors as boarders if public servants-Not not admissible; other-Admissible provided that the Head of Mission certifies that it has a genuine representational value and suitable hotel accommodation is unavailable at the time.
Babysitting-whilst attending official functions-Admissible, provided local and/or child allowances or reimbursement arrangements do not provide for a full-time servant for the officer.
Cards-greeting-Not admissible; invitation-Admissible; visiting cards for officer-Not admissible (to be met from ``office requisites'' appropriation); visiting cards for spouse-Admissible.
Cigarettes-See Liquor and Cigarettes.
Club Membership-for officer and family-One club primarily for representation purposes is admissible provided a club is not included in the local allowance calculation.
Crockery, cutlery and glassware-purchase of extra-Not admissible; hire of extra for specific representational function-Admissible.

Donations to charitable institutions-Admissible when donation is purely for representational purposes (art unions, lotteries etc. are excluded). Expenditure under this heading may not exceed 10% of the representation funds in a 12 month period.

Entertainment-Casual Drinks-Not admissible. However, the costs of refreshments provided for delegates of other countries and members of the secretariats of international organisations in delegates' lounges or bars at conference posts (e.g. New York, Geneva, Paris, Bangkok) is admissible. Cocktail parties-Admissible. The Departmental guidelines on the use of official entertainment funds in force on 1 September were as follows:
Expenditure by officials on hospitality guidelines (1 April 1982)

Official Ministerial hospitality authorised personally by a Minister is outside the scope of these guidelines. Arrangements for Ministerial hospitality are made through the Office Ceremonial and Hospitality, Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, and any inquiries about such hospitality should be directed to that office.

2. Funds for official hospitality are provided to facilitate the conduct of public business through persons who are able to do so either by advice or service or because of their vocational or business interests. Hospitality may also be extended to overseas visitors where the department or authority concerned has an interest in, or some obligation towards, facilitating the visit, and to members of the diplomatic and consular corps. Official hospitality in the normal course would be extended to an overseas visitor on not more than one occasion during a visit but additional hospitality may be appropriate in the particular circumstances, e.g. an extended stay in Australia, where the visit covers widely spaced locations, or the visitor's interests span the functions of more than one department/authority. A Permanent Head may authorise a Commonwealth official on placement with a company in Australia under the Public Service Board's Interchange Program to return reasonable hospitality extended by the host organisation, or for an officer on exchange with an overseas Government to extend hospitality where representation duties are involved.

3. In general, expenditure should not be authorised on hospitality or entertainment associated with functions of an inter-departmental or intra-Commonwealth Government nature. The principle to be followed is that public funds are not to provide hospitality for Commonwealth Government officials. Some exceptions have been made-for instance, hospitality for annual conferences of heads of State branches of a department or authority. See also paragraph 9 on working lunches.
4. The number of Commonwealth officials attending functions should be restricted to those who will be able to advance public business or who will gain benefits by attending.

5. For large scale functions, the number of Commonwealth officials attending should, as a general rule, comprise a minor proportion of those attending. For smaller functions, say in the order of a dozen people, the number of Commonwealth officials should be in balance with the number of visitors. Where only one visitor is being entertained, normally not more than three Commonwealth officials should attend.
6. Where Commonwealth officials partake of meals the costs of which are charged against official hospitality, the officials should not receive travelling allowance in respect of those meals.

7. Functions may be hosted by the head of department or authority or an authorised officer. Spouses of officials are included where this is appropriate. A function may be hosted by the spouse of the head, or other officer deputed by the head, of the organisation. Other members of the host's family would not normally be included in the list. Hospitality may be provided in the host's private home.

8. Fees incurred by officers representing their organisations at seminars or similar functions are not normally regarded as a charge against hospitality funds. However, expenditure incurred in offering hospitality to a visiting speaker could be appropriate.
9. Expenditure on a lunch which is not otherwise admissible may be acceptable as a working lunch and charged against official hospitality where:
a full day's meeting has been scheduled and there are cost advantages in continuing the meeting through the normal lunch break; or
the lunch is attended by officials from at least one department or authority other than the host department/authority and is for the purpose of transacting official business during the meal.

Working lunches should normally be (a) at the work/meeting location (b) not a regular occurrence and (c) of a simple standard involving relatively low charges per head, for example sandwiches, fruit and tea/coffee at $2.00 per head; salad and tea/coffee at $2.50 per head; light luncheon at $4.50 per head.

10. Expenditure on minor gifts of a protocol or public relations nature is acceptable as a charge against official hospitality where presentation of such gifts is in conformity with a particular department's or authority's functions.
11. Some specific examples of expenditure which is acceptable or not acceptable as official entertainment are listed below to provide guidance for future cases:
Acceptable Expenditure
Payment of gratuities which are reasonable in relation to services performed.
The provision of a liquor cupboard for small scale entertainment.
The purchase of flowers-for use in the home when entertaining officially, or for reciprocal presentation, or for presentation, in special circumstances, to the wife of an important guest.
Non-Acceptable Expenditure
Functions to farewell officers on retirement or on posting or transfer.
Hospitality by officials for Commonwealth Ministers and Members of the Federal Parliament.
Club membership fees; and
Entertainment at a Commonwealth Government-sponsored international conference (such expenditure should be a charge to the conference budget).
These guidelines were revised on 26 September 1985 by the Departmental Circular Number 72/85 as follows:
Official Entertainment Expenditure
(26 September 1985) General

1. Official entertainment or hospitality in the Department is provided under the Secretary's Entertainment Fund. It is funded through the Incidentals item in the Administrative Expenses Division of the Department's Appropriation.
2. The responsibility for deciding whether expenditure on official entertainment is a proper charge on public funds rests with the Secretary.

3. Proposals for the expenditure of funds on official entertainment should be addressed to the Secretary through the Functions Officer in the Protocol Branch. Submissions should bear the endorsement of a Deputy Secretary or First Assistant Secretary and be within the Guidelines on Expenditure by officials on Entertainment provided in Appendix 1. In each case, a test of essentiality will be applied to the proposal. To allow adequate processing time, proposals should reach Protocol with at least five working days notice.
Processing procedures and responsibilities
4. Any proposal should include the following details:
(i) date/time;
(ii) venue;
(iii) host;
(iv) number of guests (including the host);
(v) name, nationality (where applicable) and appointment of each attendee;
(vi) reasons for/purpose of the function and other supporting information.
5. The Functions Officer in the Protocol Branch, after ensuring the proposal accords with the Guidelines and that funds are available, will submit the proposal to the Secretary for approval.
6. On approval, the proposal will be returned to the Functions Officer who will advise the responsible officer accordingly.
7. Restaurant bookings, catering, menus, etc. for the function will be arranged by the Functions Officer.

8. The host or a delegated officer should sign the account. In most cases, the Functions Officer will arrange with the restaurant etc. to forward the account directly to Protocol Branch. Where this is not possible, the host or the delegated officer will be responsible for delivering the account to the Functions Officer. On receipt of the account, the Functions Officer will prepare a Claim for Payment (TF12) and forward it with the original proposal and account to the Director, Finance with a certification that services have been rendered correctly. If the account exceeds the amount approved, covering approval will be sought from the Secretary.
9. The Director, Finance will process the account for payment. It is expected that accounts will be processed and paid within fourteen days of their receipt by the Finance Section.
Special Cases
10. Proposals on short notice or for approval in retrospect will each be considered separately on their merits. However, approval will only be given where compelling circumstances can be shown.
